normalization to maintain training stability in deep architectures.
Theoretically, we prove that minimizing the tripartite loss guarantees
consistent alignment of PRoAs-RoAs, trajectory stability, and non-overlapping
PRoAs. Moreover, we establish stochastic convex separability with tighter
probability bounds and fewer dimensionality requirements to justify the convex
design in Lyapunov functions. Experimentally, Zubov-Net maintains high
classification accuracy while significantly improving robustness against
various stochastic noises and adversarial attacks.

</details>


### [239] [Position: The Hidden Costs and Measurement Gaps of Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21882)
*Aaron Tu,Weihao Xuan,Heli Qi,Xu Huang,Qingcheng Zeng,Shayan Talaei,Yijia Xiao,Peng Xia,Xiangru Tang,Yuchen Zhuang,Bing Hu,Hanqun Cao,Wenqi Shi,Tianang Leng,Rui Yang,Yingjian Chen,Ziqi Wang,Irene Li,Nan Liu,Huaxiu Yao,Li Erran Li,Ge Liu,Amin Saberi,Naoto Yokoya,Jure Leskovec,Yejin Choi,Fang Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: RLVR gains persist under strict parity-controlled evaluation but are inflated by contamination, evaluation pitfalls, and data leakage. A tax-aware, standardized evaluation protocol reduces these biases, yields more reliable reasoning gains, and can revise prior conclusions. Overall RLVR is valuable but requires rigorous measurement and provenance checks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To answer whether reported RLVR gains survive parity-controlled evaluation and whether RLVR is cost-free or imposes a measurable tax. The paper identifies three bias forces—an RLVR tax, evaluation pitfalls, and data contamination—and aims to quantify their impact and propose reliable evaluation protocols.

Method: - Partial-prompt contamination audit to detect data leakage. - Matched-budget reproductions comparing base and RL models under parity constraints. - Development of a tax-aware training/evaluation protocol that co-optimizes accuracy, grounding, and calibrated abstention. - Standardization of budgeting and provenance checks.

Result: Across clean, parity-controlled evaluations, several headline gaps shrink or vanish. The refined protocol yields more reliable estimates of reasoning gains, and in some cases reverses prior conclusions drawn from noisier evaluations.

Conclusion: RLVR is valuable and industry-ready, but requires reliability-focused practices. Adopting the tax-aware, provenance-conscious evaluation protocol can preserve practical gains while improving safety and measurement quality.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) is a practical and
scalable approach to enhancing large language models in areas such as math,
code, and other structured tasks. Two questions motivate this paper: how much
of the reported gains survive under strictly parity-controlled evaluation, and
whether RLVR is cost-free or exacts a measurable tax. We argue that progress is
real, but gains are often overstated due to three forces - an RLVR tax,
evaluation pitfalls, and data contamination. Using a partial-prompt
contamination audit and matched-budget reproductions across base and RL models,
we show that several headline gaps shrink or vanish under clean,
parity-controlled evaluation. We then propose a tax-aware training and
evaluation protocol that co-optimizes accuracy, grounding, and calibrated
abstention and standardizes budgeting and provenance checks. Applied to recent
RLVR setups, this protocol yields more reliable estimates of reasoning gains
and, in several cases, revises prior conclusions. Our position is constructive:
RLVR is valuable and industry-ready; we advocate keeping its practical benefits
while prioritizing reliability, safety, and measurement.

</details>


### [240] [Why High-rank Neural Networks Generalize?: An Algebraic Framework with RKHSs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21895)
*Yuka Hashimoto,Sho Sonoda,Isao Ishikawa,Masahiro Ikeda*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: New Rademacher complexity bound for deep nets using Koopman operators, group representations, and RKHSs; explains why high-rank weight matrices generalize well; extends bounds to broader model classes.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address limitations of existing Rademacher bounds that apply only to restricted model families and provide a bound for more realistic deep networks by leveraging Koopman representations and RKHS.

Method: Introduce an algebraic representation of neural networks and design a kernel function to construct an RKHS; derive a Rademacher complexity bound within the Koopman/group/RKHS framework.

Result: Proposes a new bound applicable to a wider range of models and offers an explanation for the generalization of high-rank weight matrices; establishes a Koopman-based approach for Rademacher bounds.

Conclusion: Koopman-based Rademacher bounds can be extended to practical neural networks via an algebraic representation and RKHS kernels, enabling broader applicability of the theory.

Abstract: We derive a new Rademacher complexity bound for deep neural networks using
Koopman operators, group representations, and reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces
(RKHSs). The proposed bound describes why the models with high-rank weight
matrices generalize well. Although there are existing bounds that attempt to
describe this phenomenon, these existing bounds can be applied to limited types
of models. We introduce an algebraic representation of neural networks and a
kernel function to construct an RKHS to derive a bound for a wider range of
realistic models. This work paves the way for the Koopman-based theory for
Rademacher complexity bounds to be valid for more practical situations.

</details>


### [241] [Closing the Oracle Gap: Increment Vector Transformation for Class Incremental Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21898)
*Zihuan Qiu,Yi Xu,Fanman Meng,Runtong Zhang,Linfeng Xu,Qingbo Wu,Hongliang Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: IVT is a plug-and-play framework for Class Incremental Learning that preserves low-loss linear connectivity to previous-task optima by periodically teleporting model parameters to transformed solutions derived from diagonal Fisher information, boosting accuracy and reducing forgetting across standard benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current CIL methods lag behind oracle models with full historical data. Insights from Linear Mode Connectivity show oracle solutions maintain low-loss linear connections to past task optima, suggesting a geometric strategy to mitigate forgetting.

Method: Increment Vector Transformation (IVT) periodically teleports the model to transformed solutions that preserve linear connectivity to the previous task optimum. The transformation is efficiently approximated with diagonal Fisher Information matrices, enabling exemplar-free and exemplar-based settings and compatibility with various initializations; IVT is a plug-and-play module.

Result: Empirical gains include CIFAR-100: last accuracy +5.12% and forgetting -2.54% over PASS; FGVCAircraft (CLIP-pretrained SLCA): average accuracy +14.93% and last accuracy +21.95%; validated on CIFAR-100, FGVCAircraft, ImageNet-Subset, and ImageNet-Full, with code to be released.

Conclusion: IVT effectively mitigates forgetting by leveraging geometry of LMC in CIL, offering a practical, efficient, and broadly compatible approach that consistently improves strong baselines.

Abstract: Class Incremental Learning (CIL) aims to sequentially acquire knowledge of
new classes without forgetting previously learned ones. Despite recent
progress, current CIL methods still exhibit significant performance gaps
compared to their oracle counterparts-models trained with full access to
historical data. Inspired by recent insights on Linear Mode Connectivity (LMC),
we revisit the geometric properties of oracle solutions in CIL and uncover a
fundamental observation: these oracle solutions typically maintain low-loss
linear connections to the optimum of previous tasks. Motivated by this finding,
we propose Increment Vector Transformation (IVT), a novel plug-and-play
framework designed to mitigate catastrophic forgetting during training. Rather
than directly following CIL updates, IVT periodically teleports the model
parameters to transformed solutions that preserve linear connectivity to
previous task optimum. By maintaining low-loss along these connecting paths,
IVT effectively ensures stable performance on previously learned tasks. The
transformation is efficiently approximated using diagonal Fisher Information
Matrices, making IVT suitable for both exemplar-free and exemplar-based
scenarios, and compatible with various initialization strategies. Extensive
experiments on CIFAR-100, FGVCAircraft, ImageNet-Subset, and ImageNet-Full
demonstrate that IVT consistently enhances the performance of strong CIL
baselines. Specifically, on CIFAR-100, IVT improves the last accuracy of the
PASS baseline by +5.12% and reduces forgetting by 2.54%. For the
CLIP-pre-trained SLCA baseline on FGVCAircraft, IVT yields gains of +14.93% in
average accuracy and +21.95% in last accuracy. The code will be released.

</details>


### [242] [Discrete Guidance Matching: Exact Guidance for Discrete Flow Matching](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21912)
*Zhengyan Wan,Yidong Ouyang,Liyan Xie,Fang Fang,Hongyuan Zha,Guang Cheng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A new discrete-guidance framework for posterior sampling derives exact transition rates from a learned discrete flow-matching model, enabling single-pass sampling per step, improving efficiency and unifying previous guidance approaches; applicable to masked diffusion and demonstrated on energy-guided simulations and multimodal tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Discrete data sampling in diffusion-like models relies on first-order Taylor approximations, which are inaccurate in discrete state spaces and lead to inefficient or biased sampling. An exact transition-rate-guided approach could improve fidelity and efficiency.

Method: Derive the exact transition rate for the desired distribution given a learned discrete flow-matching model. This yields guidance that requires only a single forward pass per sampling step. The framework is general enough to subsume existing guidance methods as special cases and can be applied to masked diffusion models.

Result: Demonstrates effectiveness on energy-guided simulations and preference alignment in text-to-image generation and multimodal understanding tasks; code released at the provided repository.

Conclusion: The proposed discrete guidance framework is general, efficient, and unifies prior guidance methods, with broad applicability to discrete generative modeling and diffusion-like processes.

Abstract: Guidance provides a simple and effective framework for posterior sampling by
steering the generation process towards the desired distribution. When modeling
discrete data, existing approaches mostly focus on guidance with the
first-order Taylor approximation to improve the sampling efficiency. However,
such an approximation is inappropriate in discrete state spaces since the
approximation error could be large. A novel guidance framework for discrete
data is proposed to address this problem: We derive the exact transition rate
for the desired distribution given a learned discrete flow matching model,
leading to guidance that only requires a single forward pass in each sampling
step, significantly improving efficiency. This unified novel framework is
general enough, encompassing existing guidance methods as special cases, and it
can also be seamlessly applied to the masked diffusion model. We demonstrate
the effectiveness of our proposed guidance on energy-guided simulations and
preference alignment on text-to-image generation and multimodal understanding
tasks. The code is available through
https://github.com/WanZhengyan/Discrete-Guidance-Matching/tree/main.

</details>


### [243] [Multiplicative-Additive Constrained Models:Toward Joint Visualization of Interactive and Independent Effects](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21923)
*Fumin Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MACMs extend CESR with a multiplicative–additive structure that preserves visualizable shape functions while decoupling interactive and independent terms, yielding superior predictive performance over CESR and GAMs (neural-network implementation).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In high-stakes domains like healthcare, interpretability is essential. GAMs offer interpretable shape functions but omit higher-order interactions to preserve simplicity, which limits accuracy. A model that visualizes interactions among all features yet improves performance is needed.

Method: Introduce Multiplicative-Additive Constrained Models (MACMs) that combine a multiplicative part (capturing interactions) with an additive part (capturing independent effects). The additive component disentangles coefficients of interaction and main effects, broadening the hypothesis space. Both parts have visualizable shape functions, and the approach is implemented with neural networks (neural-network-based MACMs).

Result: MACMs outperform both CESR and state-of-the-art GAMs in predictive accuracy, with neural-network MACMs showing significant gains over CESR and GAM baselines.

Conclusion: MACMs provide an interpretable and more powerful alternative to CESR and GAMs by coupling a visualizable multiplicative interaction term with an additive component, expanding the hypothesis space and achieving superior predictive performance.

Abstract: Interpretability is one of the considerations when applying machine learning
to high-stakes fields such as healthcare that involve matters of life safety.
Generalized Additive Models (GAMs) enhance interpretability by visualizing
shape functions. Nevertheless, to preserve interpretability, GAMs omit
higher-order interaction effects (beyond pairwise interactions), which imposes
significant constraints on their predictive performance. We observe that Curve
Ergodic Set Regression (CESR), a multiplicative model, naturally enables the
visualization of its shape functions and simultaneously incorporates both
interactions among all features and individual feature effects. Nevertheless,
CESR fails to demonstrate superior performance compared to GAMs. We introduce
Multiplicative-Additive Constrained Models (MACMs), which augment CESR with an
additive part to disentangle the intertwined coefficients of its interactive
and independent terms, thus effectively broadening the hypothesis space. The
model is composed of a multiplicative part and an additive part, whose shape
functions can both be naturally visualized, thereby assisting users in
interpreting how features participate in the decision-making process.
Consequently, MACMs constitute an improvement over both CESR and GAMs. The
experimental results indicate that neural network-based MACMs significantly
outperform both CESR and the current state-of-the-art GAMs in terms of
predictive performance.

</details>


### [244] [Generation Properties of Stochastic Interpolation under Finite Training Set](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21925)
*Yunchen Li,Shaohui Lin,Zhou Yu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: With finite training data, deterministic generation exactly recovers the training samples; stochastic generation adds Gaussian noise to those samples. When estimation errors are present, generation becomes convex combinations of samples with mixed uniform and Gaussian noise; experiments on generation and classification support the theory.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Understand the theoretical behavior of generative models when trained on finite populations and establish generative-specific notions of underfitting and overfitting.

Method: Derive closed-form expressions for the optimal velocity field and score function under a finite training set within a stochastic interpolation framework; compare deterministic and stochastic generative processes; model estimation errors; define/characterize underfitting/overfitting in generative models; validate with experiments on generation and downstream tasks.

Result: Deterministic processes exactly recover training samples; stochastic processes produce samples with added Gaussian noise; with estimation errors, generation yields convex combinations of training samples corrupted by a mixture of uniform and Gaussian noise; empirical results on generation and downstream tasks corroborate the theory.

Conclusion: Provides a finite-data theoretical framework for generative models, formalizes underfitting/overfitting in the generative setting, and is supported by empirical evidence across generation and downstream tasks.

Abstract: This paper investigates the theoretical behavior of generative models under
finite training populations. Within the stochastic interpolation generative
framework, we derive closed-form expressions for the optimal velocity field and
score function when only a finite number of training samples are available. We
demonstrate that, under some regularity conditions, the deterministic
generative process exactly recovers the training samples, while the stochastic
generative process manifests as training samples with added Gaussian noise.
Beyond the idealized setting, we consider model estimation errors and introduce
formal definitions of underfitting and overfitting specific to generative
models. Our theoretical analysis reveals that, in the presence of estimation
errors, the stochastic generation process effectively produces convex
combinations of training samples corrupted by a mixture of uniform and Gaussian
noise. Experiments on generation tasks and downstream tasks such as
classification support our theory.

</details>


### [245] [Extracting Actionable Insights from Building Energy Data using Vision LLMs on Wavelet and 3D Recurrence Representations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21934)
*Amine Bechar,Adel Oulefki,Abbes Amira,Fatih Kurogollu,Yassine Himeur*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Fine-tune visual language LLMs on 3D representations (CWTs and recurrence plots) of 1D building energy time-series to improve anomaly detection and energy-efficiency recommendations, achieving better validation loss than raw-data fine-tuning on real-world data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Complex, nonlinear, multi-scale energy data challenge traditional analysis; need interpretable, scalable approaches that integrate time-series dynamics with visual reasoning.

Method: Convert 1D time-series into 3D encodings using continuous wavelet transforms (CWTs) and recurrence plots (RPs); fine-tune a visual-language LLM (Idefics-7B) on these encodings; evaluate on University of Sharjah energy dataset for anomaly detection and recommendation generation.

Result: Idefics-7B achieves validation losses of 0.0952 (CWTs) and 0.1064 (RPs), outperforming 0.1176 achieved by fine-tuning on raw time-series; framework monitors building states, detects recurring anomalies, and yields optimization recommendations.

Conclusion: Bridges time-series analysis and visualization; offers a scalable, interpretable framework for energy analytics that leverages 3D visual encodings and VLLMs to extract actionable insights.

Abstract: The analysis of complex building time-series for actionable insights and
recommendations remains challenging due to the nonlinear and multi-scale
characteristics of energy data. To address this, we propose a framework that
fine-tunes visual language large models (VLLMs) on 3D graphical representations
of the data. The approach converts 1D time-series into 3D representations using
continuous wavelet transforms (CWTs) and recurrence plots (RPs), which capture
temporal dynamics and localize frequency anomalies. These 3D encodings enable
VLLMs to visually interpret energy-consumption patterns, detect anomalies, and
provide recommendations for energy efficiency. We demonstrate the framework on
real-world building-energy datasets, where fine-tuned VLLMs successfully
monitor building states, identify recurring anomalies, and generate
optimization recommendations. Quantitatively, the Idefics-7B VLLM achieves
validation losses of 0.0952 with CWTs and 0.1064 with RPs on the University of
Sharjah energy dataset, outperforming direct fine-tuning on raw time-series
data (0.1176) for anomaly detection. This work bridges time-series analysis and
visualization, providing a scalable and interpretable framework for energy
analytics.

</details>


### [246] [Statistical Advantage of Softmax Attention: Insights from Single-Location Regression](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21936)
*O. Duranthon,P. Marion,C. Boyer,B. Loureiro,L. Zdeborová*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Softmax attention is Bayes-optimal in the population limit for a single-location regression task, while linear attention is not; in finite samples softmax remains better than linear attention though no longer Bayes-optimal; other activations are evaluated to identify needed properties; gradient-based optimization connections are discussed.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand why softmax often dominates attention mechanisms and how it compares to alternatives beyond linearized analyses, by providing a principled, high-dimensional theory of attention in a simple regression setting.

Method: A high-dimensional, physics-inspired analysis of single-location regression with attention-based predictors. The authors derive an asymptotic description via order parameters in the population limit, compare activation functions (softmax vs linear vs others), and study finite-sample asymptotics.

Result: In the population limit, softmax achieves the Bayes risk for the task, while linear attention falls short. Among other activations, certain properties are identified as necessary for optimal performance. In finite samples, softmax is no longer Bayes-optimal but still consistently outperforms linear attention; the work also discusses how these results relate to gradient-based optimization dynamics.

Conclusion: Softmax exhibits favorable theoretical properties for attention in both population and finite-sample regimes, explaining its empirical dominance and guiding principles for activation design. The analysis highlights the gap between Bayes-optimality and practical performance and connects optimization dynamics to activation choice.

Abstract: Large language models rely on attention mechanisms with a softmax activation.
Yet the dominance of softmax over alternatives (e.g., component-wise or linear)
remains poorly understood, and many theoretical works have focused on the
easier-to-analyze linearized attention. In this work, we address this gap
through a principled study of the single-location regression task, where the
output depends on a linear transformation of a single input token at a random
location. Building on ideas from statistical physics, we develop an analysis of
attention-based predictors in the high-dimensional limit, where generalization
performance is captured by a small set of order parameters. At the population
level, we show that softmax achieves the Bayes risk, whereas linear attention
fundamentally falls short. We then examine other activation functions to
identify which properties are necessary for optimal performance. Finally, we
analyze the finite-sample regime: we provide an asymptotic characterization of
the test error and show that, while softmax is no longer Bayes-optimal, it
consistently outperforms linear attention. We discuss the connection with
optimization by gradient-based algorithms.

</details>


### [247] [Structural Information-based Hierarchical Diffusion for Offline Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21942)
*Xianghua Zeng,Hao Peng,Angsheng Li,Yicheng Pan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SIHD adaptively builds a hierarchical diffusion model for offline RL long-horizon tasks using structural information, with a structural entropy regularizer to promote exploration and improve generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Offline RL with long-horizon tasks and sparse rewards suffers from high variance, distributional shift, and computational challenges; hierarchical diffusion can help but fixed scales limit adaptability. SIHD aims to adapt hierarchy to data and tasks.

Method: Construct diffusion hierarchy from structural information in offline trajectories; use multi-scale diffusion layers; conditioning based on structural information gain of state communities; apply structural entropy regularizer to encourage exploration of underrepresented states and mitigate extrapolation.

Result: SIHD outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on challenging offline RL tasks and generalizes across diverse scenarios.

Conclusion: Adaptive, structure-informed hierarchical diffusion provides stable offline policy learning for long-horizon environments, with better decision-making and generalization and less reliance on dataset-specific reward predictions.

Abstract: Diffusion-based generative methods have shown promising potential for
modeling trajectories from offline reinforcement learning (RL) datasets, and
hierarchical diffusion has been introduced to mitigate variance accumulation
and computational challenges in long-horizon planning tasks. However, existing
approaches typically assume a fixed two-layer diffusion hierarchy with a single
predefined temporal scale, which limits adaptability to diverse downstream
tasks and reduces flexibility in decision making. In this work, we propose
SIHD, a novel Structural Information-based Hierarchical Diffusion framework for
effective and stable offline policy learning in long-horizon environments with
sparse rewards. Specifically, we analyze structural information embedded in
offline trajectories to construct the diffusion hierarchy adaptively, enabling
flexible trajectory modeling across multiple temporal scales. Rather than
relying on reward predictions from localized sub-trajectories, we quantify the
structural information gain of each state community and use it as a
conditioning signal within the corresponding diffusion layer. To reduce
overreliance on offline datasets, we introduce a structural entropy regularizer
that encourages exploration of underrepresented states while avoiding
extrapolation errors from distributional shifts. Extensive evaluations on
challenging offline RL tasks show that SIHD significantly outperforms
state-of-the-art baselines in decision-making performance and demonstrates
superior generalization across diverse scenarios.

</details>


### [248] [Active Attacks: Red-teaming LLMs via Adaptive Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21947)
*Taeyoung Yun,Pierre-Luc St-Charles,Jinkyoo Park,Yoshua Bengio,Minsu Kim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Active Attacks, an RL-based red-teaming method that adaptively explores attacker prompts by periodically fine-tuning the victim LLM, producing an easy-to-hard curriculum that broadens attack-mode coverage and surpasses prior RL baselines in cross-attack success rates.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To generate diverse, multi-modal attack prompts for safety testing of LLMs. Existing diversity-focused RL methods collapse to few modes; attacker LLMs need adaptive exploration as the victim evolves.

Method: Active Attacks integrates an RL red-teaming loop with adaptive exploration inspired by active learning. Attacker prompts are rewarded by a toxicity classifier; periodic safety fine-tuning of the victim reduces rewards in exploited regions, forcing exploration of new vulnerabilities. It acts as a plug‑in to existing RL objectives and builds an easy-to-hard curriculum across local attack modes.

Result: Significant empirical gains: cross-attack success rate improved from ~0.07% (GFlowNets baseline) to 31.28% with only ~6% additional computation, outperforming PPO, REINFORCE, and GFlowNets.

Conclusion: Active Attacks uncovers a wide range of local attack modes step by step, achieving broad multi-modal coverage; the method is simple to integrate and shows substantial improvements in red-teaming effectiveness, with released code for reproducibility.

Abstract: We address the challenge of generating diverse attack prompts for large
language models (LLMs) that elicit harmful behaviors (e.g., insults, sexual
content) and are used for safety fine-tuning. Rather than relying on manual
prompt engineering, attacker LLMs can be trained with reinforcement learning
(RL) to automatically generate such prompts using only a toxicity classifier as
a reward. However, capturing a wide range of harmful behaviors is a significant
challenge that requires explicit diversity objectives. Existing
diversity-seeking RL methods often collapse to limited modes: once high-reward
prompts are found, exploration of new regions is discouraged. Inspired by the
active learning paradigm that encourages adaptive exploration, we introduce
\textit{Active Attacks}, a novel RL-based red-teaming algorithm that adapts its
attacks as the victim evolves. By periodically safety fine-tuning the victim
LLM with collected attack prompts, rewards in exploited regions diminish, which
forces the attacker to seek unexplored vulnerabilities. This process naturally
induces an easy-to-hard exploration curriculum, where the attacker progresses
beyond easy modes toward increasingly difficult ones. As a result, Active
Attacks uncovers a wide range of local attack modes step by step, and their
combination achieves wide coverage of the multi-mode distribution. Active
Attacks, a simple plug-and-play module that seamlessly integrates into existing
RL objectives, unexpectedly outperformed prior RL-based methods -- including
GFlowNets, PPO, and REINFORCE -- by improving cross-attack success rates
against GFlowNets, the previous state-of-the-art, from 0.07% to 31.28% (a
relative gain greater than $400\ \times$) with only a 6% increase in
computation. Our code is publicly available
\href{https://github.com/dbsxodud-11/active_attacks}{here}.

</details>


### [249] [Think Smart, Not Hard: Difficulty Adaptive Reasoning for Large Audio Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21960)
*Zhichao Sheng,Shilin Zhou,Chen Gong,Zhenghua Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a difficulty-adaptive reasoning method for Large Audio Language Models (LALMs) that links reasoning length to problem difficulty via a reward function, achieving better performance with shorter reasoning on easy tasks and deeper reasoning on hard tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the one-size-fits-all reasoning depth in LALMs by enabling adaptive, task-aware reasoning to balance performance and efficiency.

Method: Introduce a reward function that dynamically ties the length of reasoning to the model's estimated problem difficulty, encouraging concise reasoning for easy tasks and elaborate reasoning for complex ones; validate with extensive experiments showing improved performance and reduced reasoning length.

Result: Demonstrates that the adaptive reasoning approach improves task performance while significantly reducing average reasoning length, with further analysis offering insights into reasoning structure paradigms.

Conclusion: Adaptive difficulty-aware reasoning is beneficial for LALMs, enabling efficient and effective reasoning and guiding future exploration of reasoning structures.

Abstract: Large Audio Language Models (LALMs), powered by the chain-of-thought (CoT)
paradigm, have shown remarkable reasoning capabilities. Intuitively, different
problems often require varying depths of reasoning. While some methods can
determine whether to reason for a given problem, they typically lack a
fine-grained mechanism to modulate how much to reason. This often results in a
``one-size-fits-all'' reasoning depth, which generates redundant overthinking
for simple questions while failing to allocate sufficient thought to complex
ones. In this paper, we conduct an in-depth analysis of LALMs and find that an
effective and efficient LALM should reason smartly by adapting its reasoning
depth to the problem's complexity. To achieve this, we propose a
difficulty-adaptive reasoning method for LALMs. Specifically, we propose a
reward function that dynamically links reasoning length to the model's
perceived problem difficulty. This reward encourages shorter, concise reasoning
for easy tasks and more elaborate, in-depth reasoning for complex ones.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method is both effective and
efficient, simultaneously improving task performance and significantly reducing
the average reasoning length. Further analysis on reasoning structure paradigm
offers valuable insights for future work.

</details>


### [250] [GRAM-TDI: adaptive multimodal representation learning for drug target interaction prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21971)
*Feng Jiang,Amina Mollaysa,Hehuan Ma,Tommaso Mansi,Junzhou Huang,Mangal Prakash,Rui Liao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: GRAMDTI is a four-modal pretraining framework for drug–target interaction (DTI) prediction that uses volume-based contrastive learning across modalities, adaptive modality dropout, and IC50 weak supervision, achieving state-of-the-art results on four datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DTI prediction can benefit from rich multimodal information about small molecules and proteins; existing methods underutilize higher-order multimodal signals and rely on limited pairwise alignment.

Method: Integrates four modalities into unified representations; extends volume-based contrastive learning to four modalities; uses adaptive modality dropout to regulate each modality’s contribution during pretraining; optionally incorporates IC50 measurements as weak supervision to ground representations in interaction strength.

Result: Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines on four public DTI datasets, demonstrating robustness, superior performance, and the benefits of higher-order multimodal alignment, adaptive modality utilization, and auxiliary supervision.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that multimodal pretraining with adaptive modality fusion and weak supervision yields robust and generalizable DTI models and provides a blueprint for multimodal representation learning in drug discovery.

Abstract: Drug target interaction (DTI) prediction is a cornerstone of computational
drug discovery, enabling rational design, repurposing, and mechanistic
insights. While deep learning has advanced DTI modeling, existing approaches
primarily rely on SMILES protein pairs and fail to exploit the rich multimodal
information available for small molecules and proteins. We introduce GRAMDTI, a
pretraining framework that integrates multimodal molecular and protein inputs
into unified representations. GRAMDTI extends volume based contrastive learning
to four modalities, capturing higher-order semantic alignment beyond
conventional pairwise approaches. To handle modality informativeness, we
propose adaptive modality dropout, dynamically regulating each modality's
contribution during pre-training. Additionally, IC50 activity measurements,
when available, are incorporated as weak supervision to ground representations
in biologically meaningful interaction strengths. Experiments on four publicly
available datasets demonstrate that GRAMDTI consistently outperforms state of
the art baselines. Our results highlight the benefits of higher order
multimodal alignment, adaptive modality utilization, and auxiliary supervision
for robust and generalizable DTI prediction.

</details>


### [251] [Stage-wise Dynamics of Classifier-Free Guidance in Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22007)
*Cheng Jin,Qitan Shi,Yuantao Gu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CFG under multimodal conditionals unfolds in three stages (Direction Shift, Mode Separation, Concentration); stronger guidance improves semantic alignment but reduces diversity; a time-varying guidance schedule improves both quality and diversity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address incomplete understanding of Classifier-Free Guidance's impact on sampling dynamics, especially under multimodal conditionals, to balance fidelity and diversity.

Method: Theoretical analysis revealing three-stage dynamics in sampling: Direction Shift (bias toward weighted mean), Mode Separation (weak purges of weaker modes), Concentration (within-mode contraction); formalization and controlled experiments varying guidance strength and schedule; proposal and validation of time-varying guidance.

Result: Three-stage dynamics are validated: early strong guidance erodes global diversity, late strong guidance suppresses fine-grained variation; a time-varying schedule improves both generated quality and diversity across setups.

Conclusion: Provides a unified framework for CFG dynamics under multimodal conditionals and practical guidance for scheduling guidance to optimize fidelity and diversity.

Abstract: Classifier-Free Guidance (CFG) is widely used to improve conditional fidelity
in diffusion models, but its impact on sampling dynamics remains poorly
understood. Prior studies, often restricted to unimodal conditional
distributions or simplified cases, provide only a partial picture. We analyze
CFG under multimodal conditionals and show that the sampling process unfolds in
three successive stages. In the Direction Shift stage, guidance accelerates
movement toward the weighted mean, introducing initialization bias and norm
growth. In the Mode Separation stage, local dynamics remain largely neutral,
but the inherited bias suppresses weaker modes, reducing global diversity. In
the Concentration stage, guidance amplifies within-mode contraction,
diminishing fine-grained variability. This unified view explains a widely
observed phenomenon: stronger guidance improves semantic alignment but
inevitably reduces diversity. Experiments support these predictions, showing
that early strong guidance erodes global diversity, while late strong guidance
suppresses fine-grained variation. Moreover, our theory naturally suggests a
time-varying guidance schedule, and empirical results confirm that it
consistently improves both quality and diversity.

</details>


### [252] [Goal-Guided Efficient Exploration via Large Language Model in Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22008)
*Yajie Qi,Wei Wei,Lin Li,Lijun Zhang,Zhidong Gao,Da Wang,Huizhong Song*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SGRL introduces a structured goal-guided RL framework that uses an LLM-based goal planner and a goal-conditioned action pruner to guide exploration and long-horizon planning, achieving state-of-the-art performance on Crafter-like tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world decision-making is complex and open-ended, making exploration inefficient and long-horizon planning difficult for RL agents. Existing LLM-enhanced RL methods often incur frequent, costly LLM calls and suffer from semantic mismatch between goals and actions.

Method: SGRL consists of (1) a structured goal planner that uses LLMs to produce a reusable, structured function for goal generation with prioritized goals; it uses LLM-derived priority weights to create forward-looking goals guiding the policy. (2) A goal-conditioned action pruner that applies action masking to filter out actions not aligned with the current goal, constraining the policy to goal-consistent actions.

Result: Experimental evaluation on Crafter and Craftax-Classic shows that SGRL achieves superior performance compared to existing state-of-the-art methods.

Conclusion: SGRL effectively combines structured goal generation and goal-aligned action pruning to improve exploration efficiency and long-horizon planning in RL, mitigating semantic mismatch and leveraging LLMs more efficiently; the approach yields state-of-the-art results on the tested tasks.

Abstract: Real-world decision-making tasks typically occur in complex and open
environments, posing significant challenges to reinforcement learning (RL)
agents' exploration efficiency and long-horizon planning capabilities. A
promising approach is LLM-enhanced RL, which leverages the rich prior knowledge
and strong planning capabilities of LLMs to guide RL agents in efficient
exploration. However, existing methods mostly rely on frequent and costly LLM
invocations and suffer from limited performance due to the semantic mismatch.
In this paper, we introduce a Structured Goal-guided Reinforcement Learning
(SGRL) method that integrates a structured goal planner and a goal-conditioned
action pruner to guide RL agents toward efficient exploration. Specifically,
the structured goal planner utilizes LLMs to generate a reusable, structured
function for goal generation, in which goals are prioritized. Furthermore, by
utilizing LLMs to determine goals' priority weights, it dynamically generates
forward-looking goals to guide the agent's policy toward more promising
decision-making trajectories. The goal-conditioned action pruner employs an
action masking mechanism that filters out actions misaligned with the current
goal, thereby constraining the RL agent to select goal-consistent policies. We
evaluate the proposed method on Crafter and Craftax-Classic, and experimental
results demonstrate that SGRL achieves superior performance compared to
existing state-of-the-art methods.

</details>


### [253] [Concept-SAE: Active Causal Probing of Visual Model Behavior](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22015)
*Jianrong Ding,Muxi Chen,Chenchen Zhao,Qiang Xu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Concept-SAE introduces a dual-supervised, hybrid disentanglement approach to produce semantically grounded, localized concept tokens from sparse autoencoders, enabling causal intervention and vulnerability localization in models, moving beyond correlational interpretability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard sparse autoencoders yield ambiguous, non-grounded features that are unreliable for causal probing of model behavior. There is a need for semantically meaningful, localized tokens to enable mechanistic understanding and intervention.

Method: A dual-supervision, hybrid disentanglement strategy to derive concept tokens that are faithful and spatially localized. The approach is quantitatively evaluated against alternatives, demonstrating superior disentanglement. Applications include direct intervention to test causal links between concepts and predictions, and systematic localization of adversarial vulnerabilities to specific layers.

Result: Tokens produced by Concept-SAE are remarkably faithful and spatially localized, outperforming alternative disentanglement methods.

Conclusion: Concept-SAE provides a validated blueprint for moving beyond correlational interpretation toward mechanistic, causal probing of model behavior and for diagnosing and localizing vulnerabilities within neural architectures.

Abstract: Standard Sparse Autoencoders (SAEs) excel at discovering a dictionary of a
model's learned features, offering a powerful observational lens. However, the
ambiguous and ungrounded nature of these features makes them unreliable
instruments for the active, causal probing of model behavior. To solve this, we
introduce Concept-SAE, a framework that forges semantically grounded concept
tokens through a novel hybrid disentanglement strategy. We first quantitatively
demonstrate that our dual-supervision approach produces tokens that are
remarkably faithful and spatially localized, outperforming alternative methods
in disentanglement. This validated fidelity enables two critical applications:
(1) we probe the causal link between internal concepts and predictions via
direct intervention, and (2) we probe the model's failure modes by
systematically localizing adversarial vulnerabilities to specific layers.
Concept-SAE provides a validated blueprint for moving beyond correlational
interpretation to the mechanistic, causal probing of model behavior.

</details>


### [254] [AEGIS: Authentic Edge Growth In Sparsity for Link Prediction in Edge-Sparse Bipartite Knowledge Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22017)
*Hugh Xuechen Liu,Kıvanç Tatar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AEGIS proposes edge-only resampling to augment training data in sparse bipartite graphs, preserving nodes and avoiding fake endpoints. It uses simple uniform or inverse-degree biased sampling, plus semantic-KNN augmentation when descriptive node info is available. Evaluated on Amazon, MovieLens, and GDP graph with AUC-ROC and Brier score; results vary by dataset, with semantic-KNN providing strongest gains in dense/text-rich settings and copy-based augmentation matching baselines in some sparse domains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackle data scarcity and edge sparsity in bipartite knowledge graphs to improve link prediction without fabricating endpoints, while leveraging semantic information when available.

Method: Edge-only augmentation by resampling existing training edges. Two resampling strategies: simple uniform sampling and degree-aware inverse-degree bias. Also includes semantic KNN augmentation that uses informative node descriptions. Evaluation uses AUC-ROC (higher is better) and Brier score (lower is better) with two-tailed paired t-tests against sparse baselines. Experiments on naturally sparse graphs (game-pattern network GDP) and percolated denser benchmarks (Amazon, MovieLens).

Result: Copy-based AEGIS variants match the sparse baseline on Amazon and MovieLens; semantic KNN uniquely restores AUC and calibration; random and synthetic edges are detrimental. On GDP, semantic KNN achieves the largest AUC improvement and Brier-score reduction, with simple augmentation also lowering Brier score vs. sparse control.

Conclusion: Authenticity-constrained resampling is a data-efficient strategy for sparse bipartite link prediction; semantic augmentation provides additional gains when informative node descriptions exist.

Abstract: Bipartite knowledge graphs in niche domains are typically data-poor and
edge-sparse, which hinders link prediction. We introduce AEGIS (Authentic Edge
Growth In Sparsity), an edge-only augmentation framework that resamples
existing training edges -either uniformly simple or with inverse-degree bias
degree-aware -thereby preserving the original node set and sidestepping
fabricated endpoints. To probe authenticity across regimes, we consider
naturally sparse graphs (game design pattern's game-pattern network) and induce
sparsity in denser benchmarks (Amazon, MovieLens) via high-rate bond
percolation. We evaluate augmentations on two complementary metrics: AUC-ROC
(higher is better) and the Brier score (lower is better), using two-tailed
paired t-tests against sparse baselines. On Amazon and MovieLens, copy-based
AEGIS variants match the baseline while the semantic KNN augmentation is the
only method that restores AUC and calibration; random and synthetic edges
remain detrimental. On the text-rich GDP graph, semantic KNN achieves the
largest AUC improvement and Brier score reduction, and simple also lowers the
Brier score relative to the sparse control. These findings position
authenticity-constrained resampling as a data-efficient strategy for sparse
bipartite link prediction, with semantic augmentation providing an additional
boost when informative node descriptions are available.

</details>


### [255] [Task-Adaptive Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning for Weather Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22020)
*Shilei Cao,Hehai Lin,Jiashun Cheng,Yang Liu,Guowen Li,Xuehe Wang,Juepeng Zheng,Haoyuan Liang,Meng Jin,Chengwei Qin,Hong Cheng,Haohuan Fu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: WeatherPEFT is a PEFT framework for Weather Foundation Models that uses Task-Adaptive Dynamic Prompting (TADP) and Stochastic Fisher-Guided Adaptive Selection (SFAS) to achieve high performance with far fewer trainable parameters than full fine-tuning, addressing weather-specific data heterogeneity and coverage challenges.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Growing Weather Foundation Models demand heavy computation; current PEFT methods (designed for vision/language) fail to address weather-specific issues such as variable heterogeneity, varying resolution, and spatiotemporal coverage variations, hindering practical deployment.

Method: Two innovations: (1) Task-Adaptive Dynamic Prompting (TADP) injects encoder embedding weights into input tokens during forward pass via internal/external pattern extraction to enable context-aware feature recalibration for downstream tasks. (2) Stochastic Fisher-Guided Adaptive Selection (SFAS) uses Fisher information to identify and update task-critical parameters during backpropagation, with added randomness to stabilize selection, preserving pre-trained knowledge while adapting to tasks.

Result: Empirical evaluation on three downstream weather tasks shows WeatherPEFT closes the gap of PEFT methods to Full-Tuning, achieving parity with Full-Tuning using significantly fewer trainable parameters.

Conclusion: WeatherPEFT provides an effective and efficient framework for adapting Weather Foundation Models to diverse weather tasks, addressing heterogeneity and coverage challenges; code will be released.

Abstract: While recent advances in machine learning have equipped Weather Foundation
Models (WFMs) with substantial generalization capabilities across diverse
downstream tasks, the escalating computational requirements associated with
their expanding scale increasingly hinder practical deployment. Current
Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (PEFT) methods, designed for vision or language
tasks, fail to address the unique challenges of weather downstream tasks, such
as variable heterogeneity, resolution diversity, and spatiotemporal coverage
variations, leading to suboptimal performance when applied to WFMs. To bridge
this gap, we introduce WeatherPEFT, a novel PEFT framework for WFMs
incorporating two synergistic innovations. First, during the forward pass,
Task-Adaptive Dynamic Prompting (TADP) dynamically injects the embedding
weights within the encoder to the input tokens of the pre-trained backbone via
internal and external pattern extraction, enabling context-aware feature
recalibration for specific downstream tasks. Furthermore, during
backpropagation, Stochastic Fisher-Guided Adaptive Selection (SFAS) not only
leverages Fisher information to identify and update the most task-critical
parameters, thereby preserving invariant pre-trained knowledge, but also
introduces randomness to stabilize the selection. We demonstrate the
effectiveness and efficiency of WeatherPEFT on three downstream tasks, where
existing PEFT methods show significant gaps versus Full-Tuning, and WeatherPEFT
achieves performance parity with Full-Tuning using fewer trainable parameters.
The code of this work will be released.

</details>


### [256] [Teaching Transformers to Solve Combinatorial Problems through Efficient Trial & Error](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22023)
*Panagiotis Giannoulis,Yorgos Pantis,Christos Tzamos*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Vanilla GPT-2-based Sudoku solver using imitation learning of simple rules plus explicit DFS/backtracking achieves 99% accuracy, surpassing prior neuro-symbolic methods; connects to a contextual Min-Sum Set Cover framework.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge the gap in solving NP-complete combinatorial problems with language models by showing that a simple decoder-only architecture can perform search and learning for Sudoku without external tools, potentially generalizing to other NP problems.

Method: Imitate simple Sudoku rules within a decoder-only Transformer (GPT-2) and pair it with an explicit Depth-First Search exploration strategy that uses informed guessing and backtracking. The approach avoids external tools or function calls and seeks to minimize the number of guesses. The work also provides a formal connection to a contextual variant of Min-Sum Set Cover.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art Sudoku accuracy of 99% on the considered tasks, outperforming prior neuro-symbolic approaches, using a vanilla GPT-2 model with no external tooling. Demonstrates effective integration of rule imitation and DFS-based search with reduced guessing.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that LLMs can solve NP-class problems by combining simple rule-based imitation with explicit search strategies, without bespoke architectures or tools. Provides a formal link to a well-studied optimization problem (contextual Min-Sum Set Cover), suggesting a theoretical framing for LLM-based problem solving and avenues for future work in algorithmic alignment and efficiency.

Abstract: Despite their proficiency in various language tasks, Large Language Models
(LLMs) struggle with combinatorial problems like Satisfiability, Traveling
Salesman Problem, or even basic arithmetic. We address this gap through a novel
approach for solving problems in the class NP. We focus on the paradigmatic
task of Sudoku and achieve state-of-the-art accuracy (99\%) compared to prior
neuro-symbolic approaches. Unlike prior work that used custom architectures,
our method employs a vanilla decoder-only Transformer (GPT-2) without external
tools or function calling. Our method integrates imitation learning of simple
Sudoku rules with an explicit Depth-First Search (DFS) exploration strategy
involving informed guessing and backtracking. Moving beyond imitation learning,
we seek to minimize the number of guesses until reaching a solution. We provide
a rigorous analysis of this setup formalizing its connection to a contextual
variant of Min-Sum Set Cover, a well-studied problem in algorithms and
stochastic optimization.

</details>


### [257] [MCGM: Multi-stage Clustered Global Modeling for Long-range Interactions in Molecules](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22028)
*Haodong Pan,Yusong Wang,Nanning Zheng,Caijui Jiang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MCGM is a plug-in module that adds hierarchical global context to geometric GNNs via multi-resolution clustering, enabling efficient long-range information flow and improving predictive accuracy with fewer parameters.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Geometric GNNs excel at capturing molecular geometry but locality-biased message passing hinders long-range interactions; existing solutions are costly, lack generality, or require tuning.

Method: Build a multi-stage hierarchy of atomic clusters using dynamic hierarchical clustering to distill global information, propagate it through learned transformations with residual connections, and integrate the module as a plug-in into diverse backbones.

Result: OE62 energy error reduced by an average of 26.2%; on AQM, energy 17.0 meV and forces 4.9 meV/Å; uses 20% fewer parameters than Neural P3M.

Conclusion: MCGM provides a lightweight, plug-and-play approach to inject global context into geometric GNNs, achieving strong accuracy gains with favorable parameter efficiency and broad applicability.

Abstract: Geometric graph neural networks (GNNs) excel at capturing molecular geometry,
yet their locality-biased message passing hampers the modeling of long-range
interactions. Current solutions have fundamental limitations: extending cutoff
radii causes computational costs to scale cubically with distance;
physics-inspired kernels (e.g., Coulomb, dispersion) are often system-specific
and lack generality; Fourier-space methods require careful tuning of multiple
parameters (e.g., mesh size, k-space cutoff) with added computational overhead.
We introduce Multi-stage Clustered Global Modeling (MCGM), a lightweight,
plug-and-play module that endows geometric GNNs with hierarchical global
context through efficient clustering operations. MCGM builds a multi-resolution
hierarchy of atomic clusters, distills global information via dynamic
hierarchical clustering, and propagates this context back through learned
transformations, ultimately reinforcing atomic features via residual
connections. Seamlessly integrated into four diverse backbone architectures,
MCGM reduces OE62 energy prediction error by an average of 26.2%. On AQM, MCGM
achieves state-of-the-art accuracy (17.0 meV for energy, 4.9 meV/{\AA} for
forces) while using 20% fewer parameters than Neural P3M. Code will be made
available upon acceptance.

</details>


### [258] [OrtSAE: Orthogonal Sparse Autoencoders Uncover Atomic Features](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22033)
*Anton Korznikov,Andrey Galichin,Alexey Dontsov,Oleg Rogov,Elena Tutubalina,Ivan Oseledets*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Orthogonal SAE (OrtSAE) introduces a training penalty to enforce feature orthogonality in sparse autoencoders, mitigating feature absorption and composition while maintaining linear scalability, yielding more distinct features and improved downstream robustness with competitive performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: SAEs tend to develop feature absorption (specialized features creating holes) and feature composition (independent features merging into composites), hindering interpretability and robustness. There is a need for disentangled representations that scale efficiently.

Method: A novel training procedure for OrtSAE that penalizes high pairwise cosine similarity among SAE features to enforce orthogonality. The approach scales linearly with SAE size and is evaluated across different models and layers against other methods.

Result: OrtSAE discovers 9% more distinct features, reduces feature absorption by 65% and composition by 15%, improves spurious correlation removal by 6%, and achieves comparable downstream performance to traditional SAEs.

Conclusion: Enforcing feature orthogonality via cosine-similarity penalties effectively mitigates absorption and composition, enabling disentangled representations with modest computational overhead and strong competitive performance across tasks.

Abstract: Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) are a technique for sparse decomposition of neural
network activations into human-interpretable features. However, current SAEs
suffer from feature absorption, where specialized features capture instances of
general features creating representation holes, and feature composition, where
independent features merge into composite representations. In this work, we
introduce Orthogonal SAE (OrtSAE), a novel approach aimed to mitigate these
issues by enforcing orthogonality between the learned features. By implementing
a new training procedure that penalizes high pairwise cosine similarity between
SAE features, OrtSAE promotes the development of disentangled features while
scaling linearly with the SAE size, avoiding significant computational
overhead. We train OrtSAE across different models and layers and compare it
with other methods. We find that OrtSAE discovers 9% more distinct features,
reduces feature absorption (by 65%) and composition (by 15%), improves
performance on spurious correlation removal (+6%), and achieves on-par
performance for other downstream tasks compared to traditional SAEs.

</details>


### [259] [Latent Diffusion : Multi-Dimension Stable Diffusion Latent Space Explorer](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22038)
*Zhihua Zhong,Xuanyang Huang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A diffusion-model framework that adds customizable latent-space operations, enabling direct latent edits for conceptual and spatial manipulation; demonstrated on Infinitepedia and Latent Motion; reveals latent-space regions with semantic meaning and meaningless areas, illuminating diffusion geometry.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Diffusion models like Stable Diffusion lack intuitive latent-vector control (as in GANs), limiting flexible, interpretable artistic expression; a mechanism to manipulate latent representations during diffusion could enhance creative exploration.

Method: Introduce a framework (referred to as \workname) that integrates programmable latent-space operations into the diffusion process, allowing direct manipulation of latent representations—both conceptual and spatial—during generation. The framework is demonstrated through two artworks to show conceptual blending and dynamic motion capabilities.

Result: Demonstrates the viability of latent-space–level edits in diffusion-based art. The approach reveals latent-space structure, including semantic and meaningless regions, and shows creative output in Infinitepedia and Latent Motion, highlighting new avenues for exploring latent-space geometry in diffusion models.

Conclusion: Latent-space structures with both meaningful and meaningless regions exist in diffusion models, and customizing latent-space operations expands creative possibilities. The framework paves the way for richer artistic expression (conceptual blending and motion) and motivates further study of latent-space geometry in diffusion processes.

Abstract: Latent space is one of the key concepts in generative AI, offering powerful
means for creative exploration through vector manipulation. However, diffusion
models like Stable Diffusion lack the intuitive latent vector control found in
GANs, limiting their flexibility for artistic expression. This paper introduces
\workname, a framework for integrating customizable latent space operations
into the diffusion process. By enabling direct manipulation of conceptual and
spatial representations, this approach expands creative possibilities in
generative art. We demonstrate the potential of this framework through two
artworks, \textit{Infinitepedia} and \textit{Latent Motion}, highlighting its
use in conceptual blending and dynamic motion generation. Our findings reveal
latent space structures with semantic and meaningless regions, offering
insights into the geometry of diffusion models and paving the way for further
explorations of latent space.

</details>


### [260] [Convexity-Driven Projection for Point Cloud Dimensionality Reduction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22043)
*Suman Sanyal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CDP is a boundary-free linear dr method that targets detour-induced local non-convexity via a PSD non-convexity structure matrix built from admissible k-NN pairs; projection uses top-k eigenvectors with verifiable guarantees.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address local non-convexity and detour distortions in point clouds with verifiable, data-driven guarantees for dimensionality reduction.

Method: Build a k-NN graph; identify admissible pairs whose Euclidean-to-shortest-path ratio is below a threshold; accumulate their normalized directions to form a PSD non-convexity structure matrix; project data using the top-k eigenvectors of this matrix; provide a-posteriori distortion certificates for admissible pairs and an average-case spectral bound for expected energy captured; report fixed- and reselected-pairs detour errors and certificate quantiles.

Result: The paper proposes a linear projection method with two guarantees (per-pair distortion certificate and an average-case spectral bound) and an evaluation protocol that quantifies detour errors and certificate quantiles across fixed and reselected pairs.

Conclusion: CDP offers a boundary-free, linear DR approach that directly targets detour-related non-convexities, with verifiable guarantees and a practical evaluation protocol to help practitioners assess data-specific distortion risks.

Abstract: We propose Convexity-Driven Projection (CDP), a boundary-free linear method
for dimensionality reduction of point clouds that targets preserving
detour-induced local non-convexity. CDP builds a $k$-NN graph, identifies
admissible pairs whose Euclidean-to-shortest-path ratios are below a threshold,
and aggregates their normalized directions to form a positive semidefinite
non-convexity structure matrix. The projection uses the top-$k$ eigenvectors of
the structure matrix. We give two verifiable guarantees. A pairwise
a-posteriori certificate that bounds the post-projection distortion for each
admissible pair, and an average-case spectral bound that links expected
captured direction energy to the spectrum of the structure matrix, yielding
quantile statements for typical distortion. Our evaluation protocol reports
fixed- and reselected-pairs detour errors and certificate quantiles, enabling
practitioners to check guarantees on their data.

</details>


### [261] [MO-GRPO: Mitigating Reward Hacking of Group Relative Policy Optimization on Multi-Objective Problems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22047)
*Yuki Ichihara,Yuu Jinnai,Tetsuro Morimura,Mitsuki Sakamoto,Ryota Mitsuhashi,Eiji Uchibe*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MO-GRPO extends GRPO to multi-objective RL by normalizing reward components by their variance to balance contributions, mitigating reward hacking and improving stability across tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In multi-objective settings, unscaled or mis-scaled rewards can let a single objective dominate, making GRPO vulnerable to reward hacking; an automatic, scale-less approach is desirable.

Method: Propose MO-GRPO with a simple normalization that reweights reward functions according to their variances; provide analytical proof that contributions to the loss are balanced while preserving the order of preferences; evaluate on four domains.

Result: MO-GRPO yields stable learning by evenly distributing correlations among reward components and outperforms GRPO across domains including bandits, Mo-Gymnasium, WMT En-Ja/En-Zh, and instruction following.

Conclusion: A simple, variance-based normalization makes MO-GRPO a promising method for robust multi-objective RL by eliminating manual reward scaling and reducing reward hacking.

Abstract: Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) has been shown to be an effective
algorithm when an accurate reward model is available. However, such a highly
reliable reward model is not available in many real-world tasks. In this paper,
we particularly focus on multi-objective settings, in which we identify that
GRPO is vulnerable to reward hacking, optimizing only one of the objectives at
the cost of the others. To address this issue, we propose MO-GRPO, an extension
of GRPO with a simple normalization method to reweight the reward functions
automatically according to the variances of their values. We first show
analytically that MO-GRPO ensures that all reward functions contribute evenly
to the loss function while preserving the order of preferences, eliminating the
need for manual tuning of the reward functions' scales. Then, we evaluate
MO-GRPO experimentally in four domains: (i) the multi-armed bandits problem,
(ii) simulated control task (Mo-Gymnasium), (iii) machine translation tasks on
the WMT benchmark (En-Ja, En-Zh), and (iv) instruction following task. MO-GRPO
achieves stable learning by evenly distributing correlations among the
components of rewards, outperforming GRPO, showing MO-GRPO to be a promising
algorithm for multi-objective reinforcement learning problems.

</details>


### [262] [BrainPro: Towards Large-scale Brain State-aware EEG Representation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22050)
*Yi Ding,Muyun Jiang,Weibang Jiang,Shuailei Zhang,Xinliang Zhou,Chenyu Liu,Shanglin Li,Yong Li,Cuntai Guan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: BrainPro is a large EEG foundation model with a retrieval-based spatial learning block and a brain state-decoupling block, enabling flexible channel/region interactions across electrode layouts and state-aware self-supervised learning, achieving state-of-the-art across nine BCI datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current EEG foundation models struggle to capture channel-to-channel and region-to-region interactions across varying electrode layouts, and rarely learn state-aware representations during self-supervised pre-training. This limits flexibility and generalization across datasets and hardware.

Method: Introduce a retrieval-based spatial learning block to flexibly capture channel- and region-level interactions across varying electrode layouts. Add a brain state-decoupling block with parallel encoders and decoupling/regional reconstruction losses to enable state-aware representation learning. Pre-train on a large EEG corpus and evaluate across diverse BCI tasks.

Result: BrainPro achieves state-of-the-art performance and robust generalization across nine public BCI datasets.

Conclusion: BrainPro can adapt to diverse tasks and hardware settings; the planned release of code and pre-trained weights will facilitate adoption and replication.

Abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) is a non-invasive technique for recording brain
electrical activity, widely used in brain-computer interface (BCI) and
healthcare. Recent EEG foundation models trained on large-scale datasets have
shown improved performance and generalizability over traditional decoding
methods, yet significant challenges remain. Existing models often fail to
explicitly capture channel-to-channel and region-to-region interactions, which
are critical sources of information inherently encoded in EEG signals. Due to
varying channel configurations across datasets, they either approximate spatial
structure with self-attention or restrict training to a limited set of common
channels, sacrificing flexibility and effectiveness. Moreover, although EEG
datasets reflect diverse brain states such as emotion, motor, and others,
current models rarely learn state-aware representations during self-supervised
pre-training. To address these gaps, we propose BrainPro, a large EEG model
that introduces a retrieval-based spatial learning block to flexibly capture
channel- and region-level interactions across varying electrode layouts, and a
brain state-decoupling block that enables state-aware representation learning
through parallel encoders with decoupling and region-aware reconstruction
losses. This design allows BrainPro to adapt seamlessly to diverse tasks and
hardware settings. Pre-trained on an extensive EEG corpus, BrainPro achieves
state-of-the-art performance and robust generalization across nine public BCI
datasets. Our codes and the pre-trained weights will be released.

</details>


### [263] [Enriching Knowledge Distillation with Intra-Class Contrastive Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22053)
*Hua Yuan,Ning Xu,Xin Geng,Yong Rui*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes an intra-class contrastive loss during teacher training to enrich intra-class diversity in soft labels for knowledge distillation, aided by a margin loss to stabilize training; supported by theoretical analysis and empirical results.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Soft labels carry multi-view intra-class variation that can help generalization, but current distillation focuses on ground-truth targets and neglects intra-class diversity, limiting student performance.

Method: Introduce an intra-class contrastive loss in teacher training to enrich intra-class information in soft labels; add a margin loss to stabilize training and speed up convergence; provide theoretical analysis of intra/inter-class distances; validate with experiments.

Result: The margin-augmented intra-class contrastive loss enhances intra-class diversity in soft labels and improves distillation performance, with reported gains in training stability and convergence; empirical results support effectiveness.

Conclusion: Incorporating intra-class contrastive learning with a margin loss during teacher training can enrich soft-label representations by capturing intra-class variation, leading to improved knowledge distillation outcomes.

Abstract: Since the advent of knowledge distillation, much research has focused on how
the soft labels generated by the teacher model can be utilized effectively.
Existing studies points out that the implicit knowledge within soft labels
originates from the multi-view structure present in the data. Feature
variations within samples of the same class allow the student model to
generalize better by learning diverse representations. However, in existing
distillation methods, teacher models predominantly adhere to ground-truth
labels as targets, without considering the diverse representations within the
same class. Therefore, we propose incorporating an intra-class contrastive loss
during teacher training to enrich the intra-class information contained in soft
labels. In practice, we find that intra-class loss causes instability in
training and slows convergence. To mitigate these issues, margin loss is
integrated into intra-class contrastive learning to improve the training
stability and convergence speed. Simultaneously, we theoretically analyze the
impact of this loss on the intra-class distances and inter-class distances. It
has been proved that the intra-class contrastive loss can enrich the
intra-class diversity. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of
the proposed method.

</details>


### [264] [Towards Understanding Feature Learning in Parameter Transfer](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22056)
*Hua Yuan,Xuran Meng,Qiufeng Wang,Shiyu Xia,Ning Xu,Xu Yang,Jing Wang,Xin Geng,Yong Rui*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR:  analyzes partial transfer of parameters in ReLU CNNs, derives conditions under which inherited weights help or hurt target performance, and validates theory with experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses a theoretical gap: there is limited understanding of when transferring a subset of upstream parameters is beneficial and what governs its effectiveness.

Method: Theoretical analysis of upstream/downstream CNNs with ReLU activations, modeling inherited parameters as carriers of universal knowledge; derivation of factors that amplify/limit transfer benefits; empirical validation via numerical and real-world experiments.

Result: Characterizes conditions under which partial parameter transfer improves the target task, and identifies key factors that amplify benefit; explains cases where transfer harms performance relative to training from scratch; supports findings with numerical and real-world data experiments.

Conclusion: Partial parameter transfer can be beneficial under specific conditions and mechanisms; awareness of universal-knowledge carriers and identified factors can guide practice; empirical validation corroborates the theory.

Abstract: Parameter transfer is a central paradigm in transfer learning, enabling
knowledge reuse across tasks and domains by sharing model parameters between
upstream and downstream models. However, when only a subset of parameters from
the upstream model is transferred to the downstream model, there remains a lack
of theoretical understanding of the conditions under which such partial
parameter reuse is beneficial and of the factors that govern its effectiveness.
To address this gap, we analyze a setting in which both the upstream and
downstream models are ReLU convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Within this
theoretical framework, we characterize how the inherited parameters act as
carriers of universal knowledge and identify key factors that amplify their
beneficial impact on the target task. Furthermore, our analysis provides
insight into why, in certain cases, transferring parameters can lead to lower
test accuracy on the target task than training a new model from scratch.
Numerical experiments and real-world data experiments are conducted to
empirically validate our theoretical findings.

</details>


### [265] [The Rogue Scalpel: Activation Steering Compromises LLM Safety](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22067)
*Anton Korznikov,Andrey Galichin,Alexey Dontsov,Oleg Y. Rogov,Ivan Oseledets,Elena Tutubalina*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Activation steering, supposedly a safe, interpretable way to steer LLMs, can backfire: random or semantically meaningful directions can increase harmful compliance; combining many random vectors yields a universal jailbreak; interpretability does not guarantee containment of model behavior.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To empirically test whether activation steering provides reliable and safe control over model behavior, challenging the claim that interpretability-based steering can enforce alignment safeguards.

Method: Systematic experiments across multiple model families. Apply steering vectors to hidden states: random directions and SAE-derived interpretable directions. Measure tendency to comply with harmful prompts. Test a composite attack by summing 20 random vectors to jailbreak a single prompt and evaluate on unseen requests.

Result: Random steering increases harmful compliance from 0% to 2–27%. Steering SAE-derived benign features raises this rate by an additional 2–4%. A 20-vector universal attack markedly boosts harmful compliance on unseen prompts.

Conclusion: Safety-through-interpretability is not guaranteed. Directly manipulating model internals via activation steering can undermine alignment safeguards, suggesting the need for more robust safety mechanisms beyond interpretable directions.

Abstract: Activation steering is a promising technique for controlling LLM behavior by
adding semantically meaningful vectors directly into a model's hidden states
during inference. It is often framed as a precise, interpretable, and
potentially safer alternative to fine-tuning. We demonstrate the opposite:
steering systematically breaks model alignment safeguards, making it comply
with harmful requests. Through extensive experiments on different model
families, we show that even steering in a random direction can increase the
probability of harmful compliance from 0% to 2-27%. Alarmingly, steering benign
features from a sparse autoencoder (SAE), a common source of interpretable
directions, increases these rates by a further 2-4%. Finally, we show that
combining 20 randomly sampled vectors that jailbreak a single prompt creates a
universal attack, significantly increasing harmful compliance on unseen
requests. These results challenge the paradigm of safety through
interpretability, showing that precise control over model internals does not
guarantee precise control over model behavior.

</details>


### [266] [Non-Linear Trajectory Modeling for Multi-Step Gradient Inversion Attacks in Federated Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22082)
*Li Xia,Zheng Liu,Sili Huang,Wei Tang,Xuan Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: NL-SME introduces a nonlinear surrogate for gradient inversion attacks in FedAVG by using learnable quadratic Bézier curves to model SGD trajectories, outperforming linear SMEs and revealing stronger privacy weaknesses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: FL preserves data privacy but GIAs threaten data privacy; in multi-step updates, only aggregated gradients are available, and linear SMEs underestimate SGD complexity; need more expressive models to recover data.

Method: Replace linear interpolation with learnable quadratic Bézier curves controlled by points; apply regularization and dvec scaling; train NL-SME to fit observed aggregated gradients and reconstruct data.

Result: On CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST, NL-SME outperforms baselines on all metrics, achieving order-of-magnitude improvements in cosine similarity loss with maintained computational efficiency.

Conclusion: Highlights heightened privacy vulnerabilities in FL's multi-step updates and provides a direction for designing defense strategies, prompting further work on robust defenses.

Abstract: Federated Learning (FL) preserves privacy by keeping raw data local, yet
