Gradient Inversion Attacks (GIAs) pose significant threats. In FedAVG
multi-step scenarios, attackers observe only aggregated gradients, making data
reconstruction challenging. Existing surrogate model methods like SME assume
linear parameter trajectories, but we demonstrate this severely underestimates
SGD's nonlinear complexity, fundamentally limiting attack effectiveness. We
propose Non-Linear Surrogate Model Extension (NL-SME), the first method to
introduce nonlinear parametric trajectory modeling for GIAs. Our approach
replaces linear interpolation with learnable quadratic B\'ezier curves that
capture SGD's curved characteristics through control points, combined with
regularization and dvec scaling mechanisms for enhanced expressiveness.
Extensive experiments on CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST datasets show NL-SME
significantly outperforms baselines across all metrics, achieving
order-of-magnitude improvements in cosine similarity loss while maintaining
computational efficiency.This work exposes heightened privacy vulnerabilities
in FL's multi-step update paradigm and offers novel perspectives for developing
robust defense strategies.

</details>


### [267] [SHAKE-GNN: Scalable Hierarchical Kirchhoff-Forest Graph Neural Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22100)
*Zhipu Cui,Johannes Lutzeyer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SHAKE-GNN introduces a scalable, graph-level GNN that uses a hierarchy of Kirchhoff Forests to build stochastic, multi-resolution representations, enabling scalable trade-offs between speed and accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Graph-level tasks on very large graphs face substantial scalability challenges. A scalable framework that provides multi-scale representations can improve efficiency without sacrificing accuracy too much.

Method: The method constructs a hierarchy of Kirchhoff Forests (random spanning forests) to create stochastic multi-resolution decompositions of the graph, producing multi-scale representations. It includes a data-driven strategy to select the trade-off parameter and provides time-complexity analysis.

Result: Experimental results on large-scale graph classification benchmarks show SHAKE-GNN achieves competitive performance while offering improved scalability, demonstrating effective efficiency-accuracy tradeoffs.

Conclusion: SHAKE-GNN offers a scalable, flexible framework for graph-level GNNs, enabling efficient processing of large graphs with competitive performance through hierarchical, multi-resolution representations.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have achieved remarkable success across a range
of learning tasks. However, scaling GNNs to large graphs remains a significant
challenge, especially for graph-level tasks. In this work, we introduce
SHAKE-GNN, a novel scalable graph-level GNN framework based on a hierarchy of
Kirchhoff Forests, a class of random spanning forests used to construct
stochastic multi-resolution decompositions of graphs. SHAKE-GNN produces
multi-scale representations, enabling flexible trade-offs between efficiency
and performance. We introduce an improved, data-driven strategy for selecting
the trade-off parameter and analyse the time-complexity of SHAKE-GNN.
Experimental results on multiple large-scale graph classification benchmarks
demonstrate that SHAKE-GNN achieves competitive performance while offering
improved scalability.

</details>


### [268] [Reinforcement Learning for Durable Algorithmic Recourse](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22102)
*Marina Ceccon,Alessandro Fabris,Goran Radanović,Asia J. Biega,Gian Antonio Susto*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A time-aware recourse framework using reinforcement learning to model adaptive candidate populations and ensure durability of recommendations over a horizon T, outperforming baselines in simulations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional algorithmic recourse emphasizes robustness to model updates but largely ignores how applicant pools evolve in response to recommendations. In competitive, resource-constrained settings, recommendations must be durable and valid over time as populations adapt.

Method: Introduce a time-aware framework that explicitly models candidate population dynamics and a reinforcement learning–based recourse algorithm that generates feasible and valid recommendations with durability over a horizon T. Validate through extensive simulations in complex environments.

Result: The proposed approach substantially outperforms existing baselines by achieving a better balance between feasibility and long-term validity, with empirical evidence of durable recommendations across the time horizon.

Conclusion: Incorporating temporal and behavioral dynamics is crucial for practical recourse design. A durable, RL-based recourse framework better handles evolving environments and population responses, suggesting fruitful directions for future dynamic recourse research.

Abstract: Algorithmic recourse seeks to provide individuals with actionable
recommendations that increase their chances of receiving favorable outcomes
from automated decision systems (e.g., loan approvals). While prior research
has emphasized robustness to model updates, considerably less attention has
been given to the temporal dynamics of recourse--particularly in competitive,
resource-constrained settings where recommendations shape future applicant
pools. In this work, we present a novel time-aware framework for algorithmic
recourse, explicitly modeling how candidate populations adapt in response to
recommendations. Additionally, we introduce a novel reinforcement learning
(RL)-based recourse algorithm that captures the evolving dynamics of the
environment to generate recommendations that are both feasible and valid. We
design our recommendations to be durable, supporting validity over a predefined
time horizon T. This durability allows individuals to confidently reapply after
taking time to implement the suggested changes. Through extensive experiments
in complex simulation environments, we show that our approach substantially
outperforms existing baselines, offering a superior balance between feasibility
and long-term validity. Together, these results underscore the importance of
incorporating temporal and behavioral dynamics into the design of practical
recourse systems.

</details>


### [269] [Modeling Psychological Profiles in Volleyball via Mixed-Type Bayesian Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22111)
*Maria Iannario,Dae-Jin Lee,Manuele Leonelli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Presents latent MMHC, a hybrid structure learner for mixed-type variables, to infer directed networks; shows superior performance in simulations and meaningful sport-psychology insights from volleyball data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Psychological attributes interact in networks; need interpretable, data-driven methods to uncover directional relationships among mixed-type traits for athlete development.

Method: Latent MMHC integrates a latent Gaussian copula with a constraint-based skeleton and a constrained score-based refinement to produce a single DAG; includes a bootstrap-aggregated variant; evaluated via simulations across sample size, sparsity, and dimension; applied to Italian female volleyball players' data.

Result: Latent MMHC achieves lower structural Hamming distance and higher edge recall than recent copula-based learners while maintaining high specificity; in application, reveals networks around goal setting and self-confidence, links between emotional arousal, motivation, and anxiety, and up- and downstream placement of Big-Five traits; scenario analyses show how skill improvements propagate to preparation, confidence, and self-esteem.

Conclusion: The approach offers an interpretable, data-driven framework for profiling psychological traits in sport and can support athlete development decisions.

Abstract: Psychological attributes rarely operate in isolation: coaches reason about
networks of related traits. We analyze a new dataset of 164 female volleyball
players from Italy's C and D leagues that combines standardized psychological
profiling with background information. To learn directed relationships among
mixed-type variables (ordinal questionnaire scores, categorical demographics,
continuous indicators), we introduce latent MMHC, a hybrid structure learner
that couples a latent Gaussian copula and a constraint-based skeleton with a
constrained score-based refinement to return a single DAG. We also study a
bootstrap-aggregated variant for stability. In simulations spanning sample
size, sparsity, and dimension, latent Max-Min Hill-Climbing (MMHC) attains
lower structural Hamming distance and higher edge recall than recent
copula-based learners while maintaining high specificity. Applied to
volleyball, the learned network organizes mental skills around goal setting and
self-confidence, with emotional arousal linking motivation and anxiety, and
locates Big-Five traits (notably neuroticism and extraversion) upstream of
skill clusters. Scenario analyses quantify how improvements in specific skills
propagate through the network to shift preparation, confidence, and
self-esteem. The approach provides an interpretable, data-driven framework for
profiling psychological traits in sport and for decision support in athlete
development.

</details>


### [270] [Countering adversarial evasion in regression analysis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22113)
*David Benfield,Phan Tu Vuong,Alain Zemkoho*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a pessimistic bilevel optimization approach for regression to defend against adversarial data, relaxing convexity and uniqueness assumptions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Adversarial ML challenges the assumption of a fixed data distribution; adversaries adapt data to influence outcomes in applications like spam filtering, malware detection, and fake-image generation. Pessimistic bilevel optimization has shown promise for classification but has not yet been applied to regression.

Method: Formulates a pessimistic bilevel optimization program for regression that makes no assumptions about convexity or uniqueness of the adversary's solutions, thus capturing a fully antagonistic interaction.

Result: Introduces the regression-focused pessimistic bilevel formulation and discusses its theoretical properties and potential robustness benefits; the abstract does not report empirical results.

Conclusion: Proposes a regression framework using pessimistic bilevel optimization to mitigate adversarial threats under minimal assumptions about the adversary.

Abstract: Adversarial machine learning challenges the assumption that the underlying
distribution remains consistent throughout the training and implementation of a
prediction model. In particular, adversarial evasion considers scenarios where
adversaries adapt their data to influence particular outcomes from established
prediction models, such scenarios arise in applications such as spam email
filtering, malware detection and fake-image generation, where security methods
must be actively updated to keep up with the ever-improving generation of
malicious data. Game theoretic models have been shown to be effective at
modelling these scenarios and hence training resilient predictors against such
adversaries. Recent advancements in the use of pessimistic bilevel optimsiation
which remove assumptions about the convexity and uniqueness of the adversary's
optimal strategy have proved to be particularly effective at mitigating threats
to classifiers due to its ability to capture the antagonistic nature of the
adversary. However, this formulation has not yet been adapted to regression
scenarios. This article serves to propose a pessimistic bilevel optimisation
program for regression scenarios which makes no assumptions on the convexity or
uniqueness of the adversary's solutions.

</details>


### [271] [Learning More with Less: A Dynamic Dual-Level Down-Sampling Framework for Efficient Policy Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22115)
*Chao Wang,Tao Yang,Hongtao Tian,Yunsheng Shi,Qiyao Ma,Xiaotao Liu,Ting Yao,Wenbo Ding*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: D^3S: a two-level dynamic down-sampling framework that selects informative rollouts and tokens to accelerate policy optimization in critic-free RL, with a curriculum-based schedule.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Critic-free methods reduce memory but suffer slow learning due to abundant uninformative samples. There is a need for targeted data selection to boost learning efficiency and generalization.

Method: Two-level selection: (1) sample-level selects rollouts to maximize advantage variance (Var(A)); (2) token-level prioritizes tokens by the product |A|×H to focus on uncertain, impactful updates; employs a dynamic curriculum to progressively relax down-sampling.

Result: On Qwen2.5 and Llama3.1, D^3S-enhanced methods achieve state-of-the-art performance and generalization with fewer samples and tokens across diverse reasoning benchmarks.

Conclusion: D^3S effectively prioritizes informative data to improve efficiency and robustness of critic-free RL; the approach balances rapid early learning with robust generalization, with code to be released.

Abstract: Critic-free methods like GRPO reduce memory demands by estimating advantages
from multiple rollouts but tend to converge slowly, as critical learning
signals are diluted by an abundance of uninformative samples and tokens. To
tackle this challenge, we propose the \textbf{Dynamic Dual-Level Down-Sampling
(D$^3$S)} framework that prioritizes the most informative samples and tokens
across groups to improve the efficient of policy optimization. D$^3$S operates
along two levels: (1) the sample-level, which selects a subset of rollouts to
maximize advantage variance ($\text{Var}(A)$). We theoretically proven that
this selection is positively correlated with the upper bound of the policy
gradient norms, yielding higher policy gradients. (2) the token-level, which
prioritizes tokens with a high product of advantage magnitude and policy
entropy ($|A_{i,t}|\times H_{i,t}$), focusing updates on tokens where the
policy is both uncertain and impactful. Moreover, to prevent overfitting to
high-signal data, D$^3$S employs a dynamic down-sampling schedule inspired by
curriculum learning. This schedule starts with aggressive down-sampling to
accelerate early learning and gradually relaxes to promote robust
generalization. Extensive experiments on Qwen2.5 and Llama3.1 demonstrate that
integrating D$^3$S into advanced RL algorithms achieves state-of-the-art
performance and generalization while requiring \textit{fewer} samples and
tokens across diverse reasoning benchmarks. Our code is added in the
supplementary materials and will be made publicly available.

</details>


### [272] [Mind the Missing: Variable-Aware Representation Learning for Irregular EHR Time Series using Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22121)
*Jeong Eul Kwon,Joo Heung Yoon,Hyo Kyung Lee*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A variable-aware LLM framework (VITAL) for irregularly sampled EHR time series.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Irregular sampling and high missingness in EHR time series hinder learning; need models that leverage temporal structure and handle missing data effectively.

Method: VITAL re-encodes vital signs into the language space to capture temporal context with explicit missing-value encoding, while laboratories are embedded via summary statistics or a learnable [Not measured] token; the approach distinguishes variable types (vital signs vs labs).

Result: Empirical evaluation on PhysioNet datasets shows VITAL outperforms state-of-the-art methods for irregular time series and remains robust under high missingness.

Conclusion: A variable-aware, LLM-based framework can effectively model irregular clinical time series by customizing representations for different variable types and explicit missing-value handling.

Abstract: Irregular sampling and high missingness are intrinsic challenges in modeling
time series derived from electronic health records (EHRs),where clinical
variables are measured at uneven intervals depending on workflow and
intervention timing. To address this, we propose VITAL, a variable-aware, large
language model (LLM) based framework tailored for learning from irregularly
sampled physiological time series. VITAL differentiates between two distinct
types of clinical variables: vital signs, which are frequently recorded and
exhibit temporal patterns, and laboratory tests, which are measured
sporadically and lack temporal structure. It reprograms vital signs into the
language space, enabling the LLM to capture temporal context and reason over
missing values through explicit encoding. In contrast, laboratory variables are
embedded either using representative summary values or a learnable [Not
measured] token, depending on their availability. Extensive evaluations on the
benchmark datasets from the PhysioNet demonstrate that VITAL outperforms state
of the art methods designed for irregular time series. Furthermore, it
maintains robust performance under high levels of missingness, which is
prevalent in real world clinical scenarios where key variables are often
unavailable.

</details>


### [273] [Slicing Wasserstein Over Wasserstein Via Functional Optimal Transport](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22138)
*Moritz Piening,Robert Beinert*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A scalable double-sliced Wasserstein (DSW) distance for meta-measures is proposed, leveraging the 1D Wasserstein isometry to L2 quantile functions and Gaussian-process projections to achieve stable, efficient comparisons of distributions over measures across data domains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Wasserstein over Wasserstein (WoW) is powerful but computationally expensive. Existing sliced WoW methods rely on parametric meta-measures or higher-order moments, which can cause numerical instability. A general, stable, scalable metric for meta-measures is needed.

Method: Introduce a general sliced Wasserstein framework for arbitrary Banach spaces. Utilize the 1D-Wasserstein isometry with quantile functions in L2([0,1]). Define 1D meta-measure slices via infinite-dimensional L2 projections parameterized by Gaussian processes. Combine with integration over the unit sphere to form the double-sliced Wasserstein (DSW) distance for general meta-measures.

Result: Show that DSW minimization is equivalent to WoW minimization for discretized meta-measures and avoids unstable higher-order moments, yielding computational savings. Numerical experiments on datasets, shapes, and images validate DSW as a scalable substitute for WoW.

Conclusion: DSW provides a stable, scalable alternative to WoW for comparing meta-measures across diverse domains, reducing computational cost and instability while maintaining fidelity on discretized representations.

Abstract: Wasserstein distances define a metric between probability measures on
arbitrary metric spaces, including meta-measures (measures over measures). The
resulting Wasserstein over Wasserstein (WoW) distance is a powerful, but
computationally costly tool for comparing datasets or distributions over images
and shapes. Existing sliced WoW accelerations rely on parametric meta-measures
or the existence of high-order moments, leading to numerical instability. As an
alternative, we propose to leverage the isometry between the 1d Wasserstein
space and the quantile functions in the function space $L_2([0,1])$. For this
purpose, we introduce a general sliced Wasserstein framework for arbitrary
Banach spaces. Due to the 1d Wasserstein isometry, this framework defines a
sliced distance between 1d meta-measures via infinite-dimensional
$L_2$-projections, parametrized by Gaussian processes. Combining this 1d
construction with classical integration over the Euclidean unit sphere yields
the double-sliced Wasserstein (DSW) metric for general meta-measures. We show
that DSW minimization is equivalent to WoW minimization for discretized
meta-measures, while avoiding unstable higher-order moments and computational
savings. Numerical experiments on datasets, shapes, and images validate DSW as
a scalable substitute for the WoW distance.

</details>


### [274] [Pushing Toward the Simplex Vertices: A Simple Remedy for Code Collapse in Smoothed Vector Quantization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22161)
*Takashi Morita*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A lightweight regularizer for smoothed vector quantization that jointly enforces near-onehot codes and full codebook usage by aligning each codebook entry with its K-nearest smoothed quantizers; improves codebook utilization and downstream performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Non-differentiable quantization obstructs gradient flow. Existing smoothing methods often optimize either approximation quality or codebook usage in isolation; a single approach that achieves both is desirable for stable training and strong representations.

Method: Introduce a simple regularization term that minimizes the distance between each simplex vertex (codebook entry) and its K-nearest smoothed quantizers (weighted combinations of codebook entries). This encourages quantizers to stay close to onehot-like vertices while ensuring diverse utilization of all codebook entries.

Result: Empirical evaluation on discrete image autoencoding and contrastive speech representation learning shows improved codebook utilization and better performance compared with prior smoothing methods.

Conclusion: The proposed regularization effectively enforces both tight onehot-like quantization and full codebook usage in a single objective, offering a simple and effective improvement over existing smoothed quantization approaches.

Abstract: Vector quantization, which discretizes a continuous vector space into a
finite set of representative vectors (a codebook), has been widely adopted in
modern machine learning. Despite its effectiveness, vector quantization poses a
fundamental challenge: the non-differentiable quantization step blocks gradient
backpropagation. Smoothed vector quantization addresses this issue by relaxing
the hard assignment of a codebook vector into a weighted combination of
codebook entries, represented as the matrix product of a simplex vector and the
codebook. Effective smoothing requires two properties: (1) smoothed quantizers
should remain close to a onehot vector, ensuring tight approximation, and (2)
all codebook entries should be utilized, preventing code collapse. Existing
methods typically address these desiderata separately. By contrast, the present
study introduces a simple and intuitive regularization that promotes both
simultaneously by minimizing the distance between each simplex vertex and its
$K$-nearest smoothed quantizers. Experiments on representative benchmarks,
including discrete image autoencoding and contrastive speech representation
learning, demonstrate that the proposed method achieves more reliable codebook
utilization and improves performance compared to prior approaches.

</details>


### [275] [Lightweight error mitigation strategies for post-training N:M activation sparsity in LLMs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22166)
*Shirin Alanova,Kristina Kazistova,Ekaterina Galaeva,Alina Kostromina,Vladimir Smirnov,Redko Dmitry,Alexey Dontsov,Maxim Zhelnin,Evgeny Burnaev,Egor Shvetsov*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Post-training N:M activation pruning in LLMs outperforms weight pruning at the same sparsity in preserving generative abilities. Among patterns, 16:32 approaches unstructured sparsity in performance, but 8:16 offers the best hardware-friendly trade-off; results enable practical activation pruning methods and motivate hardware to support flexible sparsity. Code provided by authors.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Efficient LLM inference is hampered by high compute and I/O costs. Activation pruning via N:M sparsity promises dynamic, input-adaptive compression and reduced I/O, but has been underexplored compared to weight pruning. This work investigates post-training activation pruning to deliver practical, hardware-friendly sparsity.

Method: Conduct a comprehensive, post-training analysis of N:M activation pruning across multiple LLMs. Evaluate pruning criteria and lightweight error mitigation techniques. Compare standard 2:4 patterns with alternative sparsity patterns (16:32 and 8:16). Assess generative quality preservation versus weight pruning at equivalent sparsity and establish hardware-friendly baselines with minimal calibration.

Result: Activation pruning preserves generative capabilities better than weight pruning at equal sparsity. Larger N:M patterns (16:32) nearly match unstructured sparsity in performance; however, the 8:16 pattern offers a favorable balance between performance and hardware implementation complexity. The study provides practical pruning methods and supports the case for hardware that supports more flexible sparsity patterns.

Conclusion: The work delivers actionable activation-pruning methods that are hardware-friendly and highlights a path for future hardware to support flexible N:M sparsity. It also provides a code resource for replication and further exploration.

Abstract: The demand for efficient large language model (LLM) inference has intensified
the focus on sparsification techniques. While semi-structured (N:M) pruning is
well-established for weights, its application to activation pruning remains
underexplored despite its potential for dynamic, input-adaptive compression and
reductions in I/O overhead. This work presents a comprehensive analysis of
methods for post-training N:M activation pruning in LLMs. Across multiple LLMs,
we demonstrate that pruning activations enables superior preservation of
generative capabilities compared to weight pruning at equivalent sparsity
levels. We evaluate lightweight, plug-and-play error mitigation techniques and
pruning criteria, establishing strong hardware-friendly baselines that require
minimal calibration. Furthermore, we explore sparsity patterns beyond NVIDIA's
standard 2:4, showing that the 16:32 pattern achieves performance nearly on par
with unstructured sparsity. However, considering the trade-off between
flexibility and hardware implementation complexity, we focus on the 8:16
pattern as a superior candidate. Our findings provide both effective practical
methods for activation pruning and a motivation for future hardware to support
more flexible sparsity patterns. Our code is available
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/Structured-Sparse-Activations-Inference-EC3C/README.md .

</details>


### [276] [Efficiency Boost in Decentralized Optimization: Reimagining Neighborhood Aggregation with Minimal Overhead](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22174)
*Durgesh Kalwar,Mayank Baranwal,Harshad Khadilkar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: DYNAWEIGHT dynamically allocates weights to neighboring servers based on their local losses, accelerating decentralized learning with minimal communication and memory overhead, outperforming static schemes like Metropolis in heterogeneous-data settings; it is compatible with any server-level optimization algorithm.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In privacy-sensitive, data-centralized contexts, distributed learning is essential. In fully decentralized systems with no central aggregator, local processing dominates. Data heterogeneity across servers calls for adaptive information aggregation to speed up convergence while keeping overhead low.

Method: Introduce DYNAWEIGHT, a framework that assigns adaptive weights to neighboring servers according to their relative losses on local datasets. This dynamic weighting favors diverse information and is designed to incur minimal extra communication and memory. It is a general aggregation scheme that can be plugged into any underlying server-level optimization algorithm.

Result: Empirical evaluation on MNIST, CIFAR10, and CIFAR100 across varying server counts and graph topologies shows significant training speedups. DYNAWEIGHT provides acceleration with minimal overhead and demonstrates versatility as an aggregation component compatible with existing optimization methods.

Conclusion: DYNAWEIGHT offers a flexible, efficient aggregation mechanism for decentralized learning that improves training speed in heterogeneous data settings and can be integrated with a wide range of optimization algorithms, suggesting broad applicability in decentralized AI systems.

Abstract: In today's data-sensitive landscape, distributed learning emerges as a vital
tool, not only fortifying privacy measures but also streamlining computational
operations. This becomes especially crucial within fully decentralized
infrastructures where local processing is imperative due to the absence of
centralized aggregation. Here, we introduce DYNAWEIGHT, a novel framework to
information aggregation in multi-agent networks. DYNAWEIGHT offers substantial
acceleration in decentralized learning with minimal additional communication
and memory overhead. Unlike traditional static weight assignments, such as
Metropolis weights, DYNAWEIGHT dynamically allocates weights to neighboring
servers based on their relative losses on local datasets. Consequently, it
favors servers possessing diverse information, particularly in scenarios of
substantial data heterogeneity. Our experiments on various datasets MNIST,
CIFAR10, and CIFAR100 incorporating various server counts and graph topologies,
demonstrate notable enhancements in training speeds. Notably, DYNAWEIGHT
functions as an aggregation scheme compatible with any underlying server-level
optimization algorithm, underscoring its versatility and potential for
widespread integration.

</details>


### [277] [Learning Equivariant Functions via Quadratic Forms](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22184)
*Pavan Karjol,Vivek V Kashyap,Rohan Kashyap,Prathosh A P*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A framework to learn group equivariant functions by estimating the quadratic form x^T A x for an (assumed) orthogonal symmetry, yielding invariant norm-preserving models and product-structured equivariants; extends to multi-input tuples with angular and scale-invariant components; demonstrates on polynomial regression, top quark tagging, and moment of inertia prediction, outperforming baselines in symmetry discovery and efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To automatically discover and leverage symmetries in data by recovering the underlying orthogonal group via a single quadratic form, enabling inductive biases that simplify models and improve learning of equivariant functions.

Method: Learn the symmetric matrix A defining the quadratic form x^T A x from data, exploiting its diagonal form for network design to obtain a norm-preserving invariant and a product-structured equivariant model; extend to tuples with a diagonal (product) group action by decomposing equivariance into an angular component from the first vector’s normalization and a scale-invariant component from the Gram matrix of the tuple.

Result: The proposed framework yields models that successfully discover the underlying symmetry and learn the corresponding equivariant functions, outperforming baselines across tasks.

Conclusion: A principled approach to recovering and exploiting group symmetry—particularly orthogonal groups—through a quadratic-form representation leads to simpler, efficient architectures and extends naturally to multi-input settings with interpretable decompositions of equivariant behavior.

Abstract: In this study, we introduce a method for learning group (known or unknown)
equivariant functions by learning the associated quadratic form $x^T A x$
corresponding to the group from the data. Certain groups, known as orthogonal
groups, preserve a specific quadratic form, and we leverage this property to
uncover the underlying symmetry group under the assumption that it is
orthogonal. By utilizing the corresponding unique symmetric matrix and its
inherent diagonal form, we incorporate suitable inductive biases into the
neural network architecture, leading to models that are both simplified and
efficient. Our approach results in an invariant model that preserves norms,
while the equivariant model is represented as a product of a norm-invariant
model and a scale-invariant model, where the ``product'' refers to the group
action.
  Moreover, we extend our framework to a more general setting where the
function acts on tuples of input vectors via a diagonal (or product) group
action. In this extension, the equivariant function is decomposed into an
angular component extracted solely from the normalized first vector and a
scale-invariant component that depends on the full Gram matrix of the tuple.
This decomposition captures the inter-dependencies between multiple inputs
while preserving the underlying group symmetry.
  We assess the effectiveness of our framework across multiple tasks, including
polynomial regression, top quark tagging, and moment of inertia matrix
prediction. Comparative analysis with baseline methods demonstrates that our
model consistently excels in both discovering the underlying symmetry and
efficiently learning the corresponding equivariant function.

</details>


### [278] [Mechanistic Independence: A Principle for Identifiable Disentangled Representations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22196)
*Stefan Matthes,Zhiwei Han,Hao Shen*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A unified mechanistic-independence framework enables identifiability of disentangled representations via multiple independence criteria (support, sparsity, higher-order), even under nonlinear/non-invertible mixing, with latent subspaces identified as connected components through a graph-theoretic view, without relying on latent-density statistics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Identifiability in disentangled representations remains unresolved and often depends on statistical assumptions about latent densities. A framework based on how latent factors mechanistically affect observed data should preserve identifiability despite changes in latent-density and dependencies.

Method: Introduce mechanistic independence as the organizing principle. Propose multiple related independence criteria (support-based, sparsity-based, higher-order). Prove identifiability of latent subspaces under nonlinear, non-invertible mixing. Establish a hierarchy among criteria and a graph-theoretic characterization of latent subspaces as connected components.

Result: Each independence criterion yields identifiability of latent subspaces, even with complex mixing. The framework is invariant to latent-density changes, and a hierarchy among criteria is established with a graph-based representation that connects latent subspaces as connected components.

Conclusion: The paper clarifies when disentangled representations can be identified without statistical assumptions, offering a unified framework and structural (graph-theoretic) insights into latent subspace identification.

Abstract: Disentangled representations seek to recover latent factors of variation
underlying observed data, yet their identifiability is still not fully
understood. We introduce a unified framework in which disentanglement is
achieved through mechanistic independence, which characterizes latent factors
by how they act on observed variables rather than by their latent distribution.
This perspective is invariant to changes of the latent density, even when such
changes induce statistical dependencies among factors. Within this framework,
we propose several related independence criteria -- ranging from support-based
and sparsity-based to higher-order conditions -- and show that each yields
identifiability of latent subspaces, even under nonlinear, non-invertible
mixing. We further establish a hierarchy among these criteria and provide a
graph-theoretic characterization of latent subspaces as connected components.
Together, these results clarify the conditions under which disentangled
representations can be identified without relying on statistical assumptions.

</details>


### [279] [Kernel Regression of Multi-Way Data via Tensor Trains with Hadamard Overparametrization: The Dynamic Graph Flow Case](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22197)
*Duc Thien Nguyen,Konstantinos Slavakis,Eleftherios Kofidis,Dimitris Pados*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces KReTTaH, a regression-based, interpretable framework for imputing missing multi-way data using kernel regression on tensors with fixed TT-rank, enhanced by Hadamard overparametrization to promote sparsity; learns on a Riemannian manifold and can incorporate graph priors.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the need for interpretable, parameter-efficient imputation of high-dimensional, structured (multi-way) data. Combines nonparametric RKHS regression with low-rank tensor representations to handle missing data, particularly in time-varying graphs.

Method: Nonparametric regression in RKHS with tensor-train (TT) representations of fixed rank. Hadamard overparametrization to induce sparsity in TT parameters. Learning framed as a smooth inverse problem on the Riemannian manifold of fixed TT-rank tensors. Application to dynamic graph flows with graph-topological priors.

Result: Empirical studies on real-world graph datasets show KReTTaH consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, including nonparametric tensor-based and neural-network-based imputers, at imputing missing, time-varying edge flows.

Conclusion: KReTTaH offers a flexible, parameter-efficient, and interpretable framework for multi-way data imputation, capable of exploiting graph priors and achieving superior performance on dynamic graph flow tasks.

Abstract: A regression-based framework for interpretable multi-way data imputation,
termed Kernel Regression via Tensor Trains with Hadamard overparametrization
(KReTTaH), is introduced. KReTTaH adopts a nonparametric formulation by casting
imputation as regression via reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces. Parameter
efficiency is achieved through tensors of fixed tensor-train (TT) rank, which
reside on low-dimensional Riemannian manifolds, and is further enhanced via
Hadamard overparametrization, which promotes sparsity within the TT parameter
space. Learning is accomplished by solving a smooth inverse problem posed on
the Riemannian manifold of fixed TT-rank tensors. As a representative
application, the estimation of dynamic graph flows is considered. In this
setting, KReTTaH exhibits flexibility by seamlessly incorporating graph-based
(topological) priors via its inverse problem formulation. Numerical tests on
real-world graph datasets demonstrate that KReTTaH consistently outperforms
state-of-the-art alternatives-including a nonparametric tensor- and a
neural-network-based methods-for imputing missing, time-varying edge flows.

</details>


### [280] [Reversible GNS for Dissipative Fluids with Consistent Bidirectional Dynamics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22207)
*Mu Huang,Linning Xu,Mingyue Dai,Yidi Shao,Bo Dai*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Reversible Graph Network Simulator (R-GNS) that unifies forward and inverse dissipative fluid simulation in a single invertible graph neural network, enabling fast inverse inference and accurate forward dynamics with fewer parameters.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Inverse inference for dissipative fluids is hard due to irreversibility and instability of optimization-based solvers. A fast, stable method that can recover plausible initial states while ensuring bidirectional consistency is needed.

Method: A mathematically invertible design based on residual reversible message passing with shared parameters within a single graph architecture to couple forward dynamics with inverse inference, rather than reversing physics.

Result: On three dissipative benchmarks (Water-3D, WaterRamps, WaterDrop), R-GNS achieves higher accuracy and consistency with only one quarter the parameters, and enables inverse inference more than 100x faster than optimization-based baselines. Forward simulation speed is on par with strong GNS baselines; goal-conditioned tasks avoid iterative optimization and reach orders-of-magnitude speedups, closely matching physically plausible target trajectories and complex shapes (e.g., characters).

Conclusion: This work presents the first reversible framework that unifies forward and inverse simulation for dissipative fluid systems, delivering faster, more accurate predictions and enabling efficient goal-directed control.

Abstract: Simulating physically plausible trajectories toward user-defined goals is a
fundamental yet challenging task in fluid dynamics. While particle-based
simulators can efficiently reproduce forward dynamics, inverse inference
remains difficult, especially in dissipative systems where dynamics are
irreversible and optimization-based solvers are slow, unstable, and often fail
to converge. In this work, we introduce the Reversible Graph Network Simulator
(R-GNS), a unified framework that enforces bidirectional consistency within a
single graph architecture. Unlike prior neural simulators that approximate
inverse dynamics by fitting backward data, R-GNS does not attempt to reverse
the underlying physics. Instead, we propose a mathematically invertible design
based on residual reversible message passing with shared parameters, coupling
forward dynamics with inverse inference to deliver accurate predictions and
efficient recovery of plausible initial states. Experiments on three
dissipative benchmarks (Water-3D, WaterRamps, and WaterDrop) show that R-GNS
achieves higher accuracy and consistency with only one quarter of the
parameters, and performs inverse inference more than 100 times faster than
optimization-based baselines. For forward simulation, R-GNS matches the speed
of strong GNS baselines, while in goal-conditioned tasks it eliminates
iterative optimization and achieves orders-of-magnitude speedups. On
goal-conditioned tasks, R-GNS further demonstrates its ability to complex
target shapes (e.g., characters "L" and "N") through vivid, physically
consistent trajectories. To our knowledge, this is the first reversible
framework that unifies forward and inverse simulation for dissipative fluid
systems.

</details>


### [281] [A Law of Data Reconstruction for Random Features (and Beyond)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22214)
*Leonardo Iurada,Simone Bombari,Tatiana Tommasi,Marco Mondelli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A theory and method show that in the random features regime, when the number of parameters p exceeds dn (d = data dimensionality), the training data can be fully reconstructed from model parameters, revealing a data-reconstruction law across architectures.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand memorization not only as label fitting but as the ability to reconstruct training data from the model, and to quantify how this capability scales with data dimensionality and parameter count.

Method: Theoretical analysis in the random-features model showing that the subspace spanned by training samples in feature space contains enough information to identify input-space samples. Proposes an optimization procedure to reconstruct the dataset from model parameters and validates the approach on random features, two-layer fully-connected networks, and deep residual networks.

Result: Demonstrates that, when p ≫ dn, the entire training dataset can be recovered; the subspace of feature-space training samples suffices to identify individual inputs; the reconstruction method performs well across tested architectures.

Conclusion: Data reconstruction memorization follows a dn-threshold law: once the parameter count surpasses dn, the training data can be fully recovered from the model, highlighting privacy and memorization concerns and suggesting bounds on p relative to dn to mitigate leakage.

Abstract: Large-scale deep learning models are known to memorize parts of the training
set. In machine learning theory, memorization is often framed as interpolation
or label fitting, and classical results show that this can be achieved when the
number of parameters $p$ in the model is larger than the number of training
samples $n$. In this work, we consider memorization from the perspective of
data reconstruction, demonstrating that this can be achieved when $p$ is larger
than $dn$, where $d$ is the dimensionality of the data. More specifically, we
show that, in the random features model, when $p \gg dn$, the subspace spanned
by the training samples in feature space gives sufficient information to
identify the individual samples in input space. Our analysis suggests an
optimization method to reconstruct the dataset from the model parameters, and
we demonstrate that this method performs well on various architectures (random
features, two-layer fully-connected and deep residual networks). Our results
reveal a law of data reconstruction, according to which the entire training
dataset can be recovered as $p$ exceeds the threshold $dn$.

</details>


### [282] [Automatic Discovery of One Parameter Subgroups of $SO(n)$](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22219)
*Pavan Karjol,Vivek V Kashyap,Rohan Kashyap,Prathosh A P*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A framework to automatically discover one-parameter subgroups of SO(n) using the Jordan form of skew-symmetric matrices, providing canonical orbit forms and symmetry-aware representations, with applications in mechanics and physics.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: One-parameter subgroups of SO(n) underpin many symmetric models in robotics, quantum mechanics, and molecular analysis. Automatic discovery and interpretable representations of these subgroups can enhance learning and interpretation, especially for invariant functions.

Method: Utilizes the Jordan form of skew-symmetric matrices (the Lie algebra of SO(n)) to derive a canonical form for orbits under H_gamma. Learns subgroup parameters gamma to identify the underlying H_gamma. Constructs standardized representations for H_gamma-invariant functions to enable symmetry-aware learning.

Result: Empirically validates the approach on tasks such as double pendulum modeling, moment of inertia prediction, top quark tagging, and invariant polynomial regression, recovering meaningful subgroup structure and producing interpretable representations.

Conclusion: The framework enables automatic discovery of one-parameter subgroups with interpretable, symmetry-aware representations across diverse domains; it highlights a practical methodology for leveraging Lie-theoretic structure in learning tasks.

Abstract: We introduce a novel framework for the automatic discovery of one-parameter
subgroups ($H_{\gamma}$) of $SO(3)$ and, more generally, $SO(n)$. One-parameter
subgroups of $SO(n)$ are crucial in a wide range of applications, including
robotics, quantum mechanics, and molecular structure analysis. Our method
utilizes the standard Jordan form of skew-symmetric matrices, which define the
Lie algebra of $SO(n)$, to establish a canonical form for orbits under the
action of $H_{\gamma}$. This canonical form is then employed to derive a
standardized representation for $H_{\gamma}$-invariant functions. By learning
the appropriate parameters, the framework uncovers the underlying one-parameter
subgroup $H_{\gamma}$. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is
demonstrated through tasks such as double pendulum modeling, moment of inertia
prediction, top quark tagging and invariant polynomial regression, where it
successfully recovers meaningful subgroup structure and produces interpretable,
symmetry-aware representations.

</details>


### [283] [Fairness-Aware Reinforcement Learning (FAReL): A Framework for Transparent and Balanced Sequential Decision-Making](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22232)
*Alexandra Cimpean,Nicole Orzan,Catholijn Jonker,Pieter Libin,Ann Nowé*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A fairness-aware RL framework (fMDP) is proposed to explore multiple performance–fairness trade-offs in sequential decision problems. It encodes individuals and groups, formalizes time-aware fairness notions, and learns policies that achieve higher fairness with only modest performance loss across hiring and fraud-detection scenarios. The results show group and individual fairness notions can diverge, and the paper provides guidelines for applying the framework across settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world sequential decisions must balance performance with fairness, but the desired trade-off is hard to specify a priori. A framework that can explore multiple trade-offs and provide actionable insights can help stakeholders select appropriate policies.

Method: Introduce fMDP, an extended Markov decision process that explicitly encodes individuals and groups. Formalize fairness notions in sequential decision contexts and compute fairness measures over time. Use RL to learn policies that trade off performance and fairness and evaluate on two scenarios: job hiring and fraud detection.

Result: The framework learns policies that are more fair across multiple scenarios with only minor degradation in performance rewards. It also reveals that group and individual fairness notions do not necessarily imply one another, underscoring the value of examining both.

Conclusion: A practical framework for fairness-aware sequential decision making that enables exploration of trade-offs, guides policy selection, and is adaptable to diverse problem settings; includes guidelines for applying the approach across domains.

Abstract: Equity in real-world sequential decision problems can be enforced using
fairness-aware methods. Therefore, we require algorithms that can make suitable
and transparent trade-offs between performance and the desired fairness
notions. As the desired performance-fairness trade-off is hard to specify a
priori, we propose a framework where multiple trade-offs can be explored.
Insights provided by the reinforcement learning algorithm regarding the
obtainable performance-fairness trade-offs can then guide stakeholders in
selecting the most appropriate policy. To capture fairness, we propose an
extended Markov decision process, $f$MDP, that explicitly encodes individuals
and groups. Given this $f$MDP, we formalise fairness notions in the context of
sequential decision problems and formulate a fairness framework that computes
fairness measures over time. We evaluate our framework in two scenarios with
distinct fairness requirements: job hiring, where strong teams must be composed
while treating applicants equally, and fraud detection, where fraudulent
transactions must be detected while ensuring the burden on customers is fairly
distributed. We show that our framework learns policies that are more fair
across multiple scenarios, with only minor loss in performance reward.
Moreover, we observe that group and individual fairness notions do not
necessarily imply one another, highlighting the benefit of our framework in
settings where both fairness types are desired. Finally, we provide guidelines
on how to apply this framework across different problem settings.

</details>


### [284] [ASSESS: A Semantic and Structural Evaluation Framework for Statement Similarity](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22246)
*Xiaoyang Liu,Tao Zhu,Zineng Dong,Yuntian Liu,Qingfeng Guo,Zhaoxuan Liu,Yu Chen,Tao Luo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ASSESS combines semantic and structural evaluation for statement similarity in autoformalization, via Operator Trees and a semantic-aware Tree Edit Distance (TransTED), and introduces EPLA, a benchmark with expert-annotated pairs demonstrating state-of-the-art performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing metrics for formal statement similarity either capture syntax (string-based) but miss semantics, or validate semantic provability (proof-based) but ignore structural nuances and fail to provide graded similarity when proofs fail. There is a need for a continuous, combined semantic-structural similarity measure.

Method: Formal statements are converted into Operator Trees to capture syntax; TransTED, a Transformation Tree Edit Distance, extends traditional tree edit distance with semantic-aware transformations to compute similarity; EPLA benchmark (524 expert-annotated pairs from miniF2F and ProofNet) labels both semantic provability and structural likeness; code and dataset to be released.

Result: TransTED Similarity achieves state-of-the-art accuracy and the highest Cohen’s kappa on EPLA, outperforming existing methods. EPLA provides a rigorous, graded evaluation for both semantic and structural aspects of autoformalization statements.

Conclusion: The ASSESS framework offers a unified, continuous measure of statement similarity that integrates semantic and structural information, supported by the EPLA benchmark, with code to be released to facilitate progress in autoformalization evaluation.

Abstract: Statement autoformalization, the automated translation of statements from
natural language into formal languages, has seen significant advancements, yet
the development of automated evaluation metrics remains limited. Existing
metrics for formal statement similarity often fail to balance semantic and
structural information. String-based approaches capture syntactic structure but
ignore semantic meaning, whereas proof-based methods validate semantic
equivalence but disregard structural nuances and, critically, provide no graded
similarity score in the event of proof failure. To address these issues, we
introduce ASSESS (A Semantic and Structural Evaluation Framework for Statement
Similarity), which comprehensively integrates semantic and structural
information to provide a continuous similarity score. Our framework first
transforms formal statements into Operator Trees to capture their syntactic
structure and then computes a similarity score using our novel TransTED
(Transformation Tree Edit Distance) Similarity metric, which enhances
traditional Tree Edit Distance by incorporating semantic awareness through
transformations. For rigorous validation, we present EPLA (Evaluating
Provability and Likeness for Autoformalization), a new benchmark of 524
expert-annotated formal statement pairs derived from miniF2F and ProofNet, with
labels for both semantic provability and structural likeness. Experiments on
EPLA demonstrate that TransTED Similarity outperforms existing methods,
achieving state-of-the-art accuracy and the highest Kappa coefficient. The
benchmark, and implementation code will be made public soon.

</details>


### [285] [Wavelet-Induced Rotary Encodings: RoPE Meets Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22259)
*Isaac Reid,Arijit Sehanobish,Cedrik Höfs,Bruno Mlodozeniec,Leonhard Vulpius,Federico Barbero,Adrian Weller,Krzysztof Choromanski,Richard E. Turner,Petar Veličković*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: WIRE generalizes RoPE to graphs, providing wavelet-inspired rotary encodings with permutation equivariance and linear-attention compatibility; it recovers RoPE on grid graphs and performs well on graph-aware tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Extend effective positional encodings to graph-structured data to leverage attention while respecting permutation symmetry and graph topology.

Method: Define Wavelet-Induced Rotary Encoding (WIRE) that generalizes RoPE to graphs, proving permutation equivariance, linear-attention compatibility, and (under assumptions) asymptotic dependence on resistive distance; show RoPE as a special case on grid graphs; evaluate on synthetic and real graph tasks.

Result: WIRE is effective for tasks where graph structure matters, recovering RoPE in grid cases and performing well on tasks like monochromatic subgraph detection and point-cloud segmentation, among standard graph benchmarks.

Conclusion: WIRE provides a general, theoretically principled positional encoding for graphs that extends RoPE, preserving key properties while enabling graph-aware attention mechanisms.

Abstract: We introduce WIRE: Wavelet-Induced Rotary Encodings. WIRE extends Rotary
Position Encodings (RoPE), a popular algorithm in LLMs and ViTs, to
graph-structured data. We demonstrate that WIRE is more general than RoPE,
recovering the latter in the special case of grid graphs. WIRE also enjoys a
host of desirable theoretical properties, including equivariance under node
ordering permutation, compatibility with linear attention, and (under select
assumptions) asymptotic dependence on graph resistive distance. We test WIRE on
a range of synthetic and real-world tasks, including identifying monochromatic
subgraphs, semantic segmentation of point clouds, and more standard graph
benchmarks. We find it to be effective in settings where the underlying graph
structure is important.

</details>


### [286] [Erase or Hide? Suppressing Spurious Unlearning Neurons for Robust Unlearning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22263)
*Nakyeong Yang,Dong-Kyum Kim,Jea Kwon,Minsung Kim,Kyomin Jung,Meeyoung Cha*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Current unlearning methods for LLMs perform shallow erasure, creating spurious negative influence; proposed Ssiuu uses attribution-guided regularization to faithfully erase target knowledge and outperforms baselines in adversarial and benign retraining scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Memorization of private data by large language models poses privacy risks. Existing unlearning methods can be bypassed by relearning, and suffer from shallow alignment, failing to faithfully erase knowledge.

Method: Introduce Ssiuu, a new class of unlearning methods that uses attribution-guided regularization to prevent spurious negative influence and faithfully remove target knowledge during retraining.

Result: Empirical results show reliable erasure of target knowledge and superior performance over strong baselines across two retraining scenarios: (1) adversarial injection of private data, and (2) benign instruction-following benchmark.

Conclusion: Robust and faithful unlearning is essential for safe deployment of language models; Ssiuu presents a promising approach to achieve faithful knowledge erasure.

Abstract: Large language models trained on web-scale data can memorize private or
sensitive knowledge, raising significant privacy risks. Although some
unlearning methods mitigate these risks, they remain vulnerable to "relearning"
during subsequent training, allowing a substantial portion of forgotten
knowledge to resurface. In this paper, we show that widely used unlearning
methods cause shallow alignment: instead of faithfully erasing target
knowledge, they generate spurious unlearning neurons that amplify negative
influence to hide it. To overcome this limitation, we introduce Ssiuu, a new
class of unlearning methods that employs attribution-guided regularization to
prevent spurious negative influence and faithfully remove target knowledge.
Experimental results confirm that our method reliably erases target knowledge
and outperforms strong baselines across two practical retraining scenarios: (1)
adversarial injection of private data, and (2) benign attack using an
instruction-following benchmark. Our findings highlight the necessity of robust
and faithful unlearning methods for safe deployment of language models.

</details>


### [287] [Towards a more realistic evaluation of machine learning models for bearing fault diagnosis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22267)
*João Paulo Vieira,Victor Afonso Bauler,Rodrigo Kobashikawa Rosa,Danilo Silva*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Leakage-aware evaluation is essential; bearing-wise split prevents data leakage and multi-label approach with Macro AUROC; dataset diversity (unique bearings) key for generalization; validated on CWRU, PU, UORED-VAFCLS; provides guidelines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current ML-based bearing fault diagnosis often reports inflated performance due to data leakage in dataset splits; real-world generalization remains questionable. The study aims to diagnose leakage issues and establish robust evaluation protocols; also to enable detection of co-occurring faults and to assess how dataset diversity affects generalization.

Method: 1) Propose leakage-free evaluation via bearing-wise partitioning with no overlap of physical components between training and test; 2) Reformulate as multi-label classification to handle co-occurring fault types; 3) Use Macro AUROC to evaluate performance independent of class prevalence; 4) Investigate effect of dataset diversity by varying number of unique bearings in training; 5) Empirically evaluate on CWRU, PU, UORED-VAFCLS.

Result: Leakage-free evaluation yields lower, more realistic performance; spurious correlations in segment-wise/condition-wise splits inflate metrics; Macro AUROC provides stable comparison; increase in unique training bearings improves generalization; cross-dataset variability indicates the need for diverse data; leakage-aware guidelines for partitioning, model selection, validation.

Conclusion: Evaluations in ML-based bearing fault diagnosis must account for data leakage; bearing-wise partitioning and a multi-label, Macro AUROC framework yield trustworthy assessments; dataset diversity is a crucial determinant of generalization; the work provides practical guidelines to advance robust, trustworthy industrial fault diagnosis.

Abstract: Reliable detection of bearing faults is essential for maintaining the safety
and operational efficiency of rotating machinery. While recent advances in
machine learning (ML), particularly deep learning, have shown strong
performance in controlled settings, many studies fail to generalize to
real-world applications due to methodological flaws, most notably data leakage.
This paper investigates the issue of data leakage in vibration-based bearing
fault diagnosis and its impact on model evaluation. We demonstrate that common
dataset partitioning strategies, such as segment-wise and condition-wise
splits, introduce spurious correlations that inflate performance metrics. To
address this, we propose a rigorous, leakage-free evaluation methodology
centered on bearing-wise data partitioning, ensuring no overlap between the
physical components used for training and testing. Additionally, we reformulate
the classification task as a multi-label problem, enabling the detection of
co-occurring fault types and the use of prevalence-independent metrics such as
Macro AUROC. Beyond preventing leakage, we also examine the effect of dataset
diversity on generalization, showing that the number of unique training
bearings is a decisive factor for achieving robust performance. We evaluate our
methodology on three widely adopted datasets: CWRU, Paderborn University (PU),
and University of Ottawa (UORED-VAFCLS). This study highlights the importance
of leakage-aware evaluation protocols and provides practical guidelines for
dataset partitioning, model selection, and validation, fostering the
development of more trustworthy ML systems for industrial fault diagnosis
applications.

</details>


### [288] [Fine-Grained Uncertainty Decomposition in Large Language Models: A Spectral Approach](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22272)
*Nassim Walha,Sebastian G. Gruber,Thomas Decker,Yinchong Yang,Alireza Javanmardi,Eyke Hüllermeier,Florian Buettner*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Spectral Uncertainty, a Von Neumann entropy–based framework to decompose total uncertainty in LLMs into aleatoric and epistemic parts, aided by a fine-grained semantic similarity representation; claims superior accuracy over baselines on multiple models and benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a critical need for reliable predictive uncertainty in LLMs. Existing methods struggle to cleanly separate aleatoric (data-inherent) from epistemic (model-related) uncertainty. The work aims to provide a rigorous, semantically aware decomposition.

Method: Define total uncertainty via Von Neumann entropy; decompose into aleatoric and epistemic components; incorporate a fine-grained representation of semantic similarity to distinguish semantic interpretations; evaluate against baselines across diverse models and benchmark datasets.

Result: Spectral Uncertainty outperforms state-of-the-art methods in estimating both aleatoric and total uncertainty across diverse models and benchmark datasets.

Conclusion: Provides a rigorous foundation for uncertainty decomposition in LLMs using spectral methods and semantic similarity; demonstrates empirical advantages and potential for broader applicability.

Abstract: As Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly integrated in diverse
applications, obtaining reliable measures of their predictive uncertainty has
become critically important. A precise distinction between aleatoric
uncertainty, arising from inherent ambiguities within input data, and epistemic
uncertainty, originating exclusively from model limitations, is essential to
effectively address each uncertainty source. In this paper, we introduce
Spectral Uncertainty, a novel approach to quantifying and decomposing
uncertainties in LLMs. Leveraging the Von Neumann entropy from quantum
information theory, Spectral Uncertainty provides a rigorous theoretical
foundation for separating total uncertainty into distinct aleatoric and
epistemic components. Unlike existing baseline methods, our approach
incorporates a fine-grained representation of semantic similarity, enabling
nuanced differentiation among various semantic interpretations in model
responses. Empirical evaluations demonstrate that Spectral Uncertainty
outperforms state-of-the-art methods in estimating both aleatoric and total
uncertainty across diverse models and benchmark datasets.

</details>


### [289] [Unlocking the Power of Mixture-of-Experts for Task-Aware Time Series Analytics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22279)
*Xingjian Wu,Zhengyu Li,Hanyin Cheng,Xiangfei Qiu,Jilin Hu,Chenjuan Guo,Bin Yang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PatchMoE is a task-aware MoE framework for time series that uses Recurrent Noisy Gating and token-level routing across time and channels with a load-balancing loss, achieving state-of-the-art results on five downstream tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) struggles in time series due to task-agnostic routing and poor modeling of channel correlations. Time-series tasks (e.g., forecasting, classification) exhibit hierarchical representations that vary by task, necessitating task-aware routing and better cross-task knowledge utilization.

Method: PatchMoE introduces a general MoE-based time-series framework. It employs Recurrent Noisy Gating to exploit hierarchical representations for different tasks. Routing operates on time-series tokens in both temporal and channel dimensions and is guided by a Temporal & Channel Load Balancing Loss to model temporal and channel correlations.

Result: Extensive experiments on five downstream tasks demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, validating the effectiveness of task-aware routing and the proposed load-balancing strategy.

Conclusion: PatchMoE provides task-aware knowledge utilization for time-series analysis by enabling task-specific routing and capturing temporal-channel correlations, achieving strong generalization across diverse time-series tasks.

Abstract: Time Series Analysis is widely used in various real-world applications such
as weather forecasting, financial fraud detection, imputation for missing data
in IoT systems, and classification for action recognization. Mixture-of-Experts
(MoE), as a powerful architecture, though demonstrating effectiveness in NLP,
still falls short in adapting to versatile tasks in time series analytics due
to its task-agnostic router and the lack of capability in modeling channel
correlations. In this study, we propose a novel, general MoE-based time series
framework called PatchMoE to support the intricate ``knowledge'' utilization
for distinct tasks, thus task-aware. Based on the observation that hierarchical
representations often vary across tasks, e.g., forecasting vs. classification,
we propose a Recurrent Noisy Gating to utilize the hierarchical information in
routing, thus obtaining task-sepcific capability. And the routing strategy is
operated on time series tokens in both temporal and channel dimensions, and
encouraged by a meticulously designed Temporal \& Channel Load Balancing Loss
to model the intricate temporal and channel correlations. Comprehensive
experiments on five downstream tasks demonstrate the state-of-the-art
performance of PatchMoE.

</details>


### [290] [Conditional Denoising Diffusion Autoencoders for Wireless Semantic Communications](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22282)
*Mehdi Letafati,Samad Ali,Matti Latva-aho*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Diffusion autoencoders are proposed for wireless semantic communication to map semantics to the ground-truth distribution, using a semantic encoder at the transmitter and a conditional diffusion model at the receiver to denoise with channel latents. The method aims to decouple encoding/decoding and model signal distribution; it is claimed to be a consistent estimator and is evaluated on CIFAR-10/MNIST with extensions to multi-user scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address gaps in current SemCom work that overemphasizes channel-adaptive neural encoding/decoding and tightly-coupled autoencoders. There is a need to explicitly model the signal distribution and to enable scalable, decoupled decoding that can better handle diverse channels and multi-user settings.

Method: Train a semantic encoder to extract high-level semantics from source data. Use a conditional diffusion model (CDiff) at the receiver conditioned on the received latent signals to perform signal-space denoising and steer reconstruction toward the transmitter's intended semantics. Prove consistency: the decoder is a consistent estimator of the ground-truth data. Evaluate via simulations on CIFAR-10 and MNIST, compare against autoencoders and VAEs, and extend to multi-user scenarios to identify dominating factors.

Result: The diffusion-based SemCom framework shows improved semantic fidelity over legacy autoencoders and VAEs on CIFAR-10 and MNIST. It demonstrates robustness to channel impairments and provides a decoupled transmitter/receiver design with scalable decoding. Multi-user experiments reveal key interference and design factors, suggesting practical guidelines for deployment.

Conclusion: Diffusion autoencoder-based wireless SemCom is a promising direction that achieves better alignment with ground-truth distributions and offers scalability advantages over traditional autoencoder-based schemes. Further work is needed to optimize computational efficiency, latency, and performance in more realistic channel models and complex multi-user networks.

Abstract: Semantic communication (SemCom) systems aim to learn the mapping from
low-dimensional semantics to high-dimensional ground-truth. While this is more
akin to a "domain translation" problem, existing frameworks typically emphasize
on channel-adaptive neural encoding-decoding schemes, lacking full exploration
of signal distribution. Moreover, such methods so far have employed
autoencoder-based architectures, where the encoding is tightly coupled to a
matched decoder, causing scalability issues in practice. To address these gaps,
diffusion autoencoder models are proposed for wireless SemCom. The goal is to
learn a "semantic-to-clean" mapping, from the semantic space to the
ground-truth probability distribution. A neural encoder at semantic transmitter
extracts the high-level semantics, and a conditional diffusion model (CDiff) at
the semantic receiver exploits the source distribution for signal-space
denoising, while the received semantic latents are incorporated as the
conditioning input to "steer" the decoding process towards the semantics
intended by the transmitter. It is analytically proved that the proposed
decoder model is a consistent estimator of the ground-truth data. Furthermore,
extensive simulations over CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets are provided along with
design insights, highlighting the performance compared to legacy autoencoders
and variational autoencoders (VAE). Simulations are further extended to the
multi-user SemCom, identifying the dominating factors in a more realistic
setup.

</details>


### [291] [A Multi-Level Framework for Multi-Objective Hypergraph Partitioning: Combining Minimum Spanning Tree and Proximal Gradient](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22294)
*Yingying Li,Mingxuan Xie,Hailong You,Yongqiang Yao,Hongwei Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An efficient hypergraph partitioning framework that combines a multi-objective non-convex constrained relaxation with MST-based strategies and refinement, achieving consistent, modest improvements over KaHyPar and state-of-the-art on weighted graphs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Improve hypergraph partition quality and scalability by escaping local optima and handling large-scale data, through diverse vertex representations, scalable MST-based partitioning, and refinement procedures.

Method: Introduce a novel multi-objective non-convex constrained relaxation model; employ a modified accelerated proximal gradient to generate diverse k-dimensional vertex features; design two MST-based strategies for small- and large-scale data (Prim-based MST with pruning for small data; representative-node subset to form a smaller MST for large data, followed by node assignment); apply refinement strategies including greedy migration, swapping, and recursive MST-based clustering.

Result: Average cut size reductions of ~2–5% vs KaHyPar in 2-, 3-, and 4-way partitioning, with up to 35% improvements on specific instances; on weighted vertex sets, outperform KaHyPar, hMetis, Mt-KaHyPar, and K-SpecPart; refinement improves hMetis partitions by up to 16%; comprehensive evaluation validates competitiveness and characterizes performance trade-offs.

Conclusion: The framework delivers competitive partition quality across scales and weight configurations, driven by the integration of non-convex optimization, MST-based partitioning, and refinement, with clear trade-offs and robust performance evidence.

Abstract: This paper proposes an efficient hypergraph partitioning framework based on a
novel multi-objective non-convex constrained relaxation model. A modified
accelerated proximal gradient algorithm is employed to generate diverse
$k$-dimensional vertex features to avoid local optima and enhance partition
quality. Two MST-based strategies are designed for different data scales: for
small-scale data, the Prim algorithm constructs a minimum spanning tree
followed by pruning and clustering; for large-scale data, a subset of
representative nodes is selected to build a smaller MST, while the remaining
nodes are assigned accordingly to reduce complexity. To further improve
partitioning results, refinement strategies including greedy migration,
swapping, and recursive MST-based clustering are introduced for partitions.
  Experimental results on public benchmark sets demonstrate that the proposed
algorithm achieves reductions in cut size of approximately 2\%--5\% on average
compared to KaHyPar in 2, 3, and 4-way partitioning, with improvements of up to
35\% on specific instances. Particularly on weighted vertex sets, our algorithm
outperforms state-of-the-art partitioners including KaHyPar, hMetis,
Mt-KaHyPar, and K-SpecPart, highlighting its superior partitioning quality and
competitiveness. Furthermore, the proposed refinement strategy improves hMetis
partitions by up to 16\%. A comprehensive evaluation based on virtual instance
methodology and parameter sensitivity analysis validates the algorithm's
competitiveness and characterizes its performance trade-offs.

</details>


### [292] [Aurora: Towards Universal Generative Multimodal Time Series Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22295)
*Xingjian Wu,Jianxin Jin,Wanghui Qiu,Peng Chen,Yang Shu,Bin Yang,Chenjuan Guo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Aurora is a multimodal time series foundation model that enables cross-domain generalization and zero-shot inference by leveraging text and image modalities. It uses tokenization, encoding, and distillation to extract domain knowledge, injected via a Modality-Guided Multi-head Self-Attention, with Prototype-Guided Flow Matching for probabilistic forecasting, and achieves state-of-the-art results on TimeMMD, TSFM-Bench, and ProbTS.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Cross-domain generalization in time series forecasting is hampered by domain-specific patterns. Unimodal foundation models lack explicit incorporation of text/image knowledge, while end-to-end multimodal models often can't perform zero-shot cross-domain inference.

Method: Pretrain on a Cross-domain Multimodal Time Series Corpus. Extract and distill domain knowledge from text/image modalities through tokenization and encoding. Use Modality-Guided Multi-head Self-Attention to inject multimodal knowledge into temporal representations. Decode by producing conditions and prototypes for future tokens, enabling Prototype-Guided Flow Matching for probabilistic forecasting.

Result: Reported state-of-the-art performance on both unimodal and multimodal settings across TimeMMD, TSFM-Bench, and ProbTS benchmarks.

Conclusion: Aurora demonstrates strong cross-domain generalization and zero-shot inference by leveraging multimodal domain knowledge, effectively guiding temporal modeling and probabilistic forecasting.

Abstract: Cross-domain generalization is very important in Time Series Forecasting
because similar historical information may lead to distinct future trends due
to the domain-specific characteristics. Recent works focus on building unimodal
time series foundation models and end-to-end multimodal supervised models.
Since domain-specific knowledge is often contained in modalities like texts,
the former lacks the explicit utilization of them, thus hindering the
performance. The latter is tailored for end-to-end scenarios and does not
support zero-shot inference for cross-domain scenarios. In this work, we
introduce Aurora, a Multimodal Time Series Foundation Model, which supports
multimodal inputs and zero-shot inference. Pretrained on Corss-domain
Multimodal Time Series Corpus, Aurora can adaptively extract and focus on key
domain knowledge contained in corrsponding text or image modalities, thus
possessing strong Cross-domain generalization capability. Through tokenization,
encoding, and distillation, Aurora can extract multimodal domain knowledge as
guidance and then utilizes a Modality-Guided Multi-head Self-Attention to
inject them into the modeling of temporal representations. In the decoding
phase, the multimodal representations are used to generate the conditions and
prototypes of future tokens, contributing to a novel Prototype-Guided Flow
Matching for generative probabilistic forecasting. Comprehensive experiments on
well-recognized benchmarks, including TimeMMD, TSFM-Bench and ProbTS,
demonstrate the consistent state-of-the-art performance of Aurora on both
unimodal and multimodal scenarios.

</details>
