### [293] [HEAPr: Hessian-based Efficient Atomic Expert Pruning in Output Space](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22299)
*Ke Li,Zheng Yang,Zhongbin Zhou,Feng Xue,Zhonglin Jiang,Wenxiao Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: HEAPr introduces atomic-expert pruning for mixture-of-experts (MoE) models, using second-order OBS-like importance to prune at the atomic-expert level, achieving near lossless compression at 20–25% with ~20% FLOPs reduction on models like DeepSeek MoE and Qwen MoE.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce memory and compute bottlenecks of large MoE-based LLMs to enable practical deployment without large accuracy losses.

Method: Decompose each expert into smaller atomic experts; compute importance using second-order information transformed from expert parameters to atomic parameters and then to atomic outputs; reduce space complexity from O(d^4) to O(d^2); require two forward passes and one backward pass on a small calibration set; prune atomic experts to meet target compression.

Result: HEAPr outperforms existing expert-level pruning methods across various compression ratios and benchmarks; achieves near lossless compression at 20–25% pruning and ~20% FLOPs reduction on MoE models (e.g., DeepSeek MoE, Qwen MoE family).

Conclusion: Fine-grained atomic-expert pruning guided by second-order importance is effective and practical for large MoE LLMs, enabling substantial memory/compute savings with minimal accuracy loss and offering a scalable pruning paradigm.

Abstract: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architectures in large language models (LLMs)
deliver exceptional performance and reduced inference costs compared to dense
LLMs. However, their large parameter counts result in prohibitive memory
requirements, limiting practical deployment. While existing pruning methods
primarily focus on expert-level pruning, this coarse granularity often leads to
substantial accuracy degradation. In this work, we introduce HEAPr, a novel
pruning algorithm that decomposes experts into smaller, indivisible atomic
experts, enabling more precise and flexible atomic expert pruning. To measure
the importance of each atomic expert, we leverage second-order information
based on principles similar to Optimal Brain Surgeon (OBS) theory. To address
the computational and storage challenges posed by second-order information,
HEAPr exploits the inherent properties of atomic experts to transform the
second-order information from expert parameters into that of atomic expert
parameters, and further simplifies it to the second-order information of atomic
expert outputs. This approach reduces the space complexity from $O(d^4)$, where
d is the model's dimensionality, to $O(d^2)$. HEAPr requires only two forward
passes and one backward pass on a small calibration set to compute the
importance of atomic experts. Extensive experiments on MoE models, including
DeepSeek MoE and Qwen MoE family, demonstrate that HEAPr outperforms existing
expert-level pruning methods across a wide range of compression ratios and
benchmarks. Specifically, HEAPr achieves nearly lossless compression at
compression ratios of 20% ~ 25% in most models, while also reducing FLOPs
nearly by 20%. The code can be found at
\href{https://github.com/LLIKKE/HEAPr}{https://github.com/LLIKKE/HEAPr}.

</details>


### [294] [SoDaDE: Solvent Data-Driven Embeddings with Small Transformer Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22302)
*Gabriel Kitso Gibberd,Jose Pablo Folch,Antonio Del Rio Chanona*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SoDaDE provides a data-driven solvent fingerprint using a small transformer trained on solvent properties, enabling improved yield predictions and low-data, solvent-specific representations for green solvent research.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generic fingerprints lack solvent-specific physical context and climate-relevant considerations; chemical data are limited, motivating domain-specific representations that can work with small datasets to support green solvent replacement.

Method: Develop a small transformer-based embedding (SoDaDE) trained on solvent property data to produce solvent fingerprints; validate by predicting yields on a published dataset and comparing with prior representations; demonstrate a workflow applicable to other domains.

Result: SoDaDE outperforms previous representations in yield prediction on the tested dataset; shows that meaningful solvent fingerprints can be learned from small datasets; establishes a reusable workflow for data-driven fingerprints in chemistry.

Conclusion: Data-driven, solvent-specific fingerprints are feasible and beneficial, particularly for green solvent research, and the approach can be extended to other applications with limited data.

Abstract: Computational representations have become crucial in unlocking the recent
growth of machine learning algorithms for chemistry. Initially hand-designed,
machine learning has shown that meaningful representations can be learnt from
data. Chemical datasets are limited and so the representations learnt from data
are generic, being trained on broad datasets which contain shallow information
on many different molecule types. For example, generic fingerprints lack
physical context specific to solvents. However, the use of harmful solvents is
a leading climate-related issue in the chemical industry, and there is a surge
of interest in green solvent replacement. To empower this research, we propose
a new solvent representation scheme by developing Solvent Data Driven
Embeddings (SoDaDE). SoDaDE uses a small transformer model and solvent property
dataset to create a fingerprint for solvents. To showcase their effectiveness,
we use SoDaDE to predict yields on a recently published dataset, outperforming
previous representations. We demonstrate through this paper that data-driven
fingerprints can be made with small datasets and set-up a workflow that can be
explored for other applications.

</details>


### [295] [Adaptive Policy Backbone via Shared Network](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22310)
*Bumgeun Park,Donghwan Lee*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Adaptive Policy Backbone (APB) is a meta-transfer RL method that inserts lightweight linear adapters around a shared backbone to enable parameter-efficient fine-tuning, preserving prior knowledge while adapting to new tasks, including out-of-distribution (OOD) ones.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reinforcement learning often requires large interaction data. Priors (datasets or reference policies) help but their usefulness degrades when training and deployment tasks differ. There is a need for methods that adapt to task mismatch, especially for OOD tasks, without overhauling core knowledge.

Method: APB inserts simple linear adapters before and after a shared backbone, enabling parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) within a meta-transfer RL framework. This allows adapting to new tasks with minimal parameter updates while preserving prior knowledge.

Result: APB improves sample efficiency compared to standard RL and enables adaptation to OOD tasks where existing meta-RL baselines typically fail.

Conclusion: APB provides a practical PEFT-based approach for RL with priors, achieving better data efficiency and robustness to task mismatch by maintaining a stable backbone and small, adaptable adapters.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has achieved impressive results across domains,
yet learning an optimal policy typically requires extensive interaction data,
limiting practical deployment. A common remedy is to leverage priors, such as
pre-collected datasets or reference policies, but their utility degrades under
task mismatch between training and deployment. While prior work has sought to
address this mismatch, it has largely been restricted to in-distribution
settings. To address this challenge, we propose Adaptive Policy Backbone (APB),
a meta-transfer RL method that inserts lightweight linear layers before and
after a shared backbone, thereby enabling parameter-efficient fine-tuning
(PEFT) while preserving prior knowledge during adaptation. Our results show
that APB improves sample efficiency over standard RL and adapts to
out-of-distribution (OOD) tasks where existing meta-RL baselines typically
fail.

</details>


### [296] [Progressive Weight Loading: Accelerating Initial Inference and Gradually Boosting Performance on Resource-Constrained Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22319)
*Hyunwoo Kim,Junha Lee,Mincheol Choi,Jeonghwan Lee,Jaeshin Cho*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Progressive Weight Loading (PWL) enables fast initial inference with a small student model and gradually substitutes teacher layers to converge to the full teacher accuracy, balancing latency and performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Large DL models cause high memory and compute; loading times and initial latency hurt mobile and latency-sensitive deployments; KD compresses but at performance cost; PWL aims to preserve speed while maintaining or achieving teacher-level accuracy.

Method: Train a method to align intermediate features between student and teacher layers and improve student output; start inference with lightweight student, progressively replace layers with pre-trained teacher layers during deployment; evaluate across VGG, ResNet, ViT.

Result: PWL maintains competitive distillation performance and shows gradual accuracy improvement as teacher layers are loaded, eventually matching final teacher accuracy without sacrificing initial inference speed.

Conclusion: PWL is well-suited for dynamic, resource-constrained deployments requiring responsiveness and high performance, offering a practical trade-off between latency and accuracy.

Abstract: Deep learning models have become increasingly large and complex, resulting in
higher memory consumption and computational demands. Consequently, model
loading times and initial inference latency have increased, posing significant
challenges in mobile and latency-sensitive environments where frequent model
loading and unloading are required, which directly impacts user experience.
While Knowledge Distillation (KD) offers a solution by compressing large
teacher models into smaller student ones, it often comes at the cost of reduced
performance. To address this trade-off, we propose Progressive Weight Loading
(PWL), a novel technique that enables fast initial inference by first deploying
a lightweight student model, then incrementally replacing its layers with those
of a pre-trained teacher model. To support seamless layer substitution, we
introduce a training method that not only aligns intermediate feature
representations between student and teacher layers, but also improves the
overall output performance of the student model. Our experiments on VGG,
ResNet, and ViT architectures demonstrate that models trained with PWL maintain
competitive distillation performance and gradually improve accuracy as teacher
layers are loaded-matching the final accuracy of the full teacher model without
compromising initial inference speed. This makes PWL particularly suited for
dynamic, resource-constrained deployments where both responsiveness and
performance are critical.

</details>


### [297] [Distributed Associative Memory via Online Convex Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22321)
*Bowen Wang,Matteo Zecchin,Osvaldo Simeone*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Distributed online gradient descent for local associative memories at agents connected by routing trees; achieves sublinear regret and outperforms online optimization baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Associative memory enables cue-response recall and is increasingly implicated in modern neural architectures (e.g., Transformers). In a distributed setting, agents maintain local AMs and exchange selective information to recall both their own and others’ associations. The work addresses scalable memory-based learning via a routing-tree communication topology.

Method: Each agent maintains a local associative memory and updates it via online gradient descent. Updates are coordinated through communication over routing trees, enabling information sharing while preserving locality. The paper provides a theoretical regret analysis showing sublinear regret and validates the approach with experiments comparing against existing online optimization baselines.

Result: The proposed protocol consistently outperforms standard online optimization baselines across experiments, demonstrating improved learning and recall in the distributed AM setting.

Conclusion: Distributed online gradient descent with routing-tree communication is an effective framework for scalable, memory-augmented learning in multi-agent systems, achieving sublinear regret and practical performance gains over baselines.

Abstract: An associative memory (AM) enables cue-response recall, and associative
memorization has recently been noted to underlie the operation of modern neural
architectures such as Transformers. This work addresses a distributed setting
where agents maintain a local AM to recall their own associations as well as
selective information from others. Specifically, we introduce a distributed
online gradient descent method that optimizes local AMs at different agents
through communication over routing trees. Our theoretical analysis establishes
sublinear regret guarantees, and experiments demonstrate that the proposed
protocol consistently outperforms existing online optimization baselines.

</details>


### [298] [Spectral Collapse Drives Loss of Plasticity in Deep Continual Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22335)
*Naicheng He,Kaicheng Guo,Arjun Prakash,Saket Tiwari,Ruo Yu Tao,Tyrone Serapio,Amy Greenwald,George Konidaris*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Hessian spectral collapse at new-task onset causes loss of plasticity in deep continual learning; introducing tau-trainability to define a necessary training condition and unifying plasticity-preserving methods; using Kronecker-factored Hessian to motivate two regularizers—preserving high feature rank and L2 penalties—for sustained plasticity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand why deep networks forget or fail to learn new tasks in continual learning, and to identify conditions under which training can succeed, by linking plasticity loss to curvature (Hessian) properties and unifying existing methods.

Method: Analyze Hessian spectra at new-task initialization; define tau-trainability as a criterion for trainability; relate plasticity-preserving algorithms to this framework; employ Kronecker-factored approximation of the Hessian to motivate two regularizers: (1) maintain high effective feature rank, (2) apply L2 penalties; validate via experiments.

Result: Regularizers designed around Hessian structure and feature rank help prevent spectral collapse and preserve plasticity; combining both regularizers yields effective continual learning performance on both supervised and reinforcement learning tasks.

Conclusion: Hessian spectral collapse is a precursor to plasticity loss; tau-trainability captures the necessary condition for successful training; Kronecker-factored Hessian insights motivate practical regularizers that preserve plasticity across tasks in continual learning.

Abstract: We investigate why deep neural networks suffer from \emph{loss of plasticity}
in deep continual learning, failing to learn new tasks without reinitializing
parameters. We show that this failure is preceded by Hessian spectral collapse
at new-task initialization, where meaningful curvature directions vanish and
gradient descent becomes ineffective. To characterize the necessary condition
for successful training, we introduce the notion of $\tau$-trainability and
show that current plasticity preserving algorithms can be unified under this
framework. Targeting spectral collapse directly, we then discuss the Kronecker
factored approximation of the Hessian, which motivates two regularization
enhancements: maintaining high effective feature rank and applying $L2$
penalties. Experiments on continual supervised and reinforcement learning tasks
confirm that combining these two regularizers effectively preserves plasticity.

</details>


### [299] [SurvDiff: A Diffusion Model for Generating Synthetic Data in Survival Analysis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22352)
*Marie Brockschmidt,Maresa Schröder,Stefan Feuerriegel*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SurvDiff introduces a diffusion-based generator for synthetic survival data that jointly models covariates, event times, and censoring, achieving superior fidelity and downstream task performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Clinical survival data require faithful replication of both the event-time distribution and the censoring mechanism in synthetic data; existing generative approaches may not capture censoring well, hindering downstream survival analyses.

Method: An end-to-end diffusion model (SurvDiff) that jointly generates mixed-type covariates, event times, and right-censoring, guided by a survival-tailored loss that encodes time-to-event structure and optimizes downstream survival tasks.

Result: SurvDiff consistently outperforms state-of-the-art generative baselines on multiple medical datasets in both distributional fidelity and downstream evaluation metrics.

Conclusion: SurvDiff is the first diffusion model explicitly designed for generating synthetic survival data, capable of reproducing realistic event-time distributions and censoring mechanisms.

Abstract: Survival analysis is a cornerstone of clinical research by modeling
time-to-event outcomes such as metastasis, disease relapse, or patient death.
Unlike standard tabular data, survival data often come with incomplete event
information due to dropout, or loss to follow-up. This poses unique challenges
for synthetic data generation, where it is crucial for clinical research to
faithfully reproduce both the event-time distribution and the censoring
mechanism. In this paper, we propose SurvDiff, an end-to-end diffusion model
specifically designed for generating synthetic data in survival analysis.
SurvDiff is tailored to capture the data-generating mechanism by jointly
generating mixed-type covariates, event times, and right-censoring, guided by a
survival-tailored loss function. The loss encodes the time-to-event structure
and directly optimizes for downstream survival tasks, which ensures that
SurvDiff (i) reproduces realistic event-time distributions and (ii) preserves
the censoring mechanism. Across multiple datasets, we show that \survdiff
consistently outperforms state-of-the-art generative baselines in both
distributional fidelity and downstream evaluation metrics across multiple
medical datasets. To the best of our knowledge, SurvDiff is the first diffusion
model explicitly designed for generating synthetic survival data.

</details>


### [300] [Context and Diversity Matter: The Emergence of In-Context Learning in World Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22353)
*Fan Wang,Zhiyuan Chen,Yuxuan Zhong,Sunjian Zheng,Pengtao Shao,Bo Yu,Shaoshan Liu,Jianan Wang,Ning Ding,Yang Cao,Yu Kang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Formalizes in-context environment learning (ICEL) for world models, identifying environment recognition and environment learning as two core mechanisms, deriving their error bounds, and empirically validating their existence and dependence on data distribution and architecture; highlights long context and diverse environments as essential for ICEL.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current static world models struggle with novel or rare configurations, limiting adaptability. ICEL aims to enable self-adapting world models by leveraging long context and diverse environments.

Method: Formalize ICEL, derive error upper-bounds for environment recognition and environment learning, and conduct empirical studies to observe distinct ICEL mechanisms and how data distribution and model architecture affect ICEL.

Result: Two ICEL mechanisms exist (environment recognition and environment learning); error bounds derived; empirical evidence shows emergence of ICEL mechanisms and that performance depends on context length, data diversity, and architecture.

Conclusion: ICEL shows promise for self-adapting world models; long context and diverse environments are key factors; future work could optimize data strategies and architectures to maximize ICEL potential.

Abstract: The capability of predicting environmental dynamics underpins both biological
neural systems and general embodied AI in adapting to their surroundings. Yet
prevailing approaches rest on static world models that falter when confronted
with novel or rare configurations. We investigate in-context environment
learning (ICEL), shifting attention from zero-shot performance to the growth
and asymptotic limits of the world model. Our contributions are three-fold: (1)
we formalize in-context learning of a world model and identify two core
mechanisms: environment recognition and environment learning; (2) we derive
error upper-bounds for both mechanisms that expose how the mechanisms emerge;
and (3) we empirically confirm that distinct ICL mechanisms exist in the world
model, and we further investigate how data distribution and model architecture
affect ICL in a manner consistent with theory. These findings demonstrate the
potential of self-adapting world models and highlight the key factors behind
the emergence of ICEL, most notably the necessity of long context and diverse
environments.

</details>


### [301] [Stochastic activations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22358)
*Maria Lomeli,Matthijs Douze,Gergely Szilvasy,Loic Cabannes,Jade Copet,Sainbayar Sukhbaatar,Jason Weston,Gabriel Synnaeve,Pierre-Emmanuel Mazaré,Hervé Jégou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Stochastic activations randomly switch between SiLU and ReLU in the feed-forward of LLMs to address dead-gradient issues, reduce inference cost, and diversify generation, with competitive performance overall.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: ReLU's dead-region gradient can hinder optimization and learning dynamics. A stochastic mix with SiLU may retain gradient flow benefits while enabling sparse inference at deployment; also aims to offer a simple mechanism to diversify text generation.

Method: Introduce a Bernoulli-driven switch between SiLU and ReLU in the feed-forward blocks during training. During pre-training use stochastic activations; fine-tune with ReLU so inference yields sparse latent vectors and faster CPU inference. Evaluate generation by continuing stochastic activations, comparing to deterministic nonlinearities (notably SiLU with temperature scaling).

Result: Pretraining with stochastic activations + ReLU finetuning yields CPU FLOP reductions and speedups, with better results than training from scratch with ReLU. In generation, stochastic activations perform reasonably well, only slightly below the best deterministic nonlinearity (SiLU with temperature scaling), while offering a controlled way to increase text diversity.

Conclusion: Stochastic activations provide a practical approach to speed up inference and tune generation diversity, with competitive performance. Further work should examine hyperparameter sensitivity (Bernoulli probability), stability, and broader task evaluations.

Abstract: We introduce stochastic activations. This novel strategy randomly selects
between several non-linear functions in the feed-forward layer of a large
language model. In particular, we choose between SILU or RELU depending on a
Bernoulli draw. This strategy circumvents the optimization problem associated
with RELU, namely, the constant shape for negative inputs that prevents the
gradient flow. We leverage this strategy in two ways:
  (1) We use stochastic activations during pre-training and fine-tune the model
with RELU, which is used at inference time to provide sparse latent vectors.
This reduces the inference FLOPs and translates into a significant speedup in
the CPU. Interestingly, this leads to much better results than training from
scratch with the RELU activation function.
  (2) We evaluate stochastic activations for generation. This strategy performs
reasonably well: it is only slightly inferior to the best deterministic
non-linearity, namely SILU combined with temperature scaling. This offers an
alternative to existing strategies by providing a controlled way to increase
the diversity of the generated text.

</details>


### [302] [Neural Feature Geometry Evolves as Discrete Ricci Flow](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22362)
*Moritz Hehl,Max von Renesse,Melanie Weber*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Neural feature geometry in deep nets evolves on similarity graphs in a manner akin to discrete Ricci flow, with nonlinear activations shaping the geometry; class separability emerges with community structure in graph representations; a local geometric-evolution framework yields practical design heuristics like geometry-informed early stopping and depth selection.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To deepen understanding of neural feature representations by analyzing their geometric evolution on approximated data manifolds, linking continuous neural transformations to discrete geometric flow, and to derive practically useful diagnostics for model design.

Method: Construct geometric graphs over inferred data manifolds to capture local similarities; study how these graphs evolve during feedforward training and relate their evolution to discrete Ricci flow dynamics; perform large-scale empirical analysis on over 20,000 fully-connected networks trained on binary classification tasks across synthetic and real-world datasets; develop a framework for locally evaluating geometric transformations by comparison with discrete Ricci flow.

Result: Nonlinear activations significantly influence the shaping of feature geometry during training; the graph-based feature transformations exhibit dynamics resembling discrete Ricci flow; emergence of class separability aligns with the rise of community structure in the graph representations; the proposed geometric framework enables local assessment and yields design principles.

Conclusion: Viewing neural feature geometry through the lens of discrete Ricci flow provides an interpretable, graph-based diagnostic tool. This perspective supports practical guidelines for model design, including geometry-informed early stopping and depth selection, and suggests a path toward more principled architecture choices grounded in the evolution of feature geometry.

Abstract: Deep neural networks learn feature representations via complex geometric
transformations of the input data manifold. Despite the models' empirical
success across domains, our understanding of neural feature representations is
still incomplete. In this work we investigate neural feature geometry through
the lens of discrete geometry. Since the input data manifold is typically
unobserved, we approximate it using geometric graphs that encode local
similarity structure. We provide theoretical results on the evolution of these
graphs during training, showing that nonlinear activations play a crucial role
in shaping feature geometry in feedforward neural networks. Moreover, we
discover that the geometric transformations resemble a discrete Ricci flow on
these graphs, suggesting that neural feature geometry evolves analogous to
Ricci flow. This connection is supported by experiments on over 20,000
feedforward neural networks trained on binary classification tasks across both
synthetic and real-world datasets. We observe that the emergence of class
separability corresponds to the emergence of community structure in the
associated graph representations, which is known to relate to discrete Ricci
flow dynamics. Building on these insights, we introduce a novel framework for
locally evaluating geometric transformations through comparison with discrete
Ricci flow dynamics. Our results suggest practical design principles, including
a geometry-informed early-stopping heuristic and a criterion for selecting
network depth.

</details>


### [303] [Investigating Faithfulness in Large Audio Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22363)
*Lovenya Jain,Pooneh Mousavi,Mirco Ravanelli,Cem Subakan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LALMs' chain-of-thoughts are generally faithful explanations of their decisions, even under targeted perturbations, across two audio-language reasoning datasets (SAKURA, MMAR).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To determine whether CoTs from audio-language models faithfully reflect the model's decision process, addressing concerns from prior work on text-based LLMs and the added complexity of audio inputs for reasoning.

Method: Apply targeted interventions to CoTs (paraphrasing, filler token injection, early answering, introducing mistakes) and evaluate faithfulness across two challenging datasets, SAKURA and MMAR (and multiple tasks).

Result: Experiments suggest that LALMs produce CoTs that appear faithful to their underlying decision processes, even after perturbations.

Conclusion: CoTs from LALMs can be reliable explanations for audio-language reasoning, though findings are cautious and may depend on datasets and tasks; further work is needed to confirm generalizability and safety implications.

Abstract: Faithfulness measures whether chain-of-thought (CoT) representations
accurately reflect a model's decision process and can be used as reliable
explanations. Prior work has shown that CoTs from text-based LLMs are often
unfaithful. This question has not been explored for large audio-language models
(LALMs), where faithfulness is critical for safety-sensitive applications.
Reasoning in LALMs is also more challenging, as models must first extract
relevant clues from audio before reasoning over them. In this paper, we
investigate the faithfulness of CoTs produced by several LALMs by applying
targeted interventions, including paraphrasing, filler token injection, early
answering, and introducing mistakes, on two challenging reasoning datasets:
SAKURA and MMAR. After going through the aforementioned interventions across
several datasets and tasks, our experiments suggest that, LALMs generally
produce CoTs that appear to be faithful to their underlying decision processes.

</details>


### [304] [SpinGPT: A Large-Language-Model Approach to Playing Poker Correctly](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22387)
*Narada Maugin,Tristan Cazenave*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SpinGPT is an LLM-based agent for Spin & Go that matches solver actions well and yields competitive results against Slumbot, showing promise for multi-player imperfect-information games.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CFR's exponential complexity with more players and lack of equilibrium guarantees in multi-player settings limit CFR in tournaments; recent LLM successes motivate applying LLMs to complex multi-player poker.

Method: Two-stage training: Supervised Fine-Tuning on 320k expert decisions; Reinforcement Learning on 270k solver-generated hands; evaluation with tolerant accuracy (78%); deep-stack heuristic yielding 13.4 ± 12.9 BB/100 vs Slumbot over 30k hands.

Result: SpinGPT achieves 78% tolerant accuracy to solver actions; competitive heads-up performance against Slumbot; demonstrates feasibility of LLMs for multi-player imperfect-information games.

Conclusion: LLMs are a promising new approach for complex multi-player poker and could extend the reach of AI in imperfect-information games beyond CFR.

Abstract: The Counterfactual Regret Minimization (CFR) algorithm and its variants have
enabled the development of pokerbots capable of beating the best human players
in heads-up (1v1) cash games and competing with them in six-player formats.
However, CFR's computational complexity rises exponentially with the number of
players. Furthermore, in games with three or more players, following Nash
equilibrium no longer guarantees a non-losing outcome. These limitations, along
with others, significantly restrict the applicability of CFR to the most
popular formats: tournaments. Motivated by the recent success of Large Language
Models (LLM) in chess and Diplomacy, we present SpinGPT, the first LLM tailored
to Spin & Go, a popular three-player online poker format. SpinGPT is trained in
two stages: (1) Supervised Fine-Tuning on 320k high-stakes expert decisions;
(2) Reinforcement Learning on 270k solver-generated hands. Our results show
that SpinGPT matches the solver's actions in 78% of decisions (tolerant
accuracy). With a simple deep-stack heuristic, it achieves 13.4 +/- 12.9 BB/100
versus Slumbot in heads-up over 30,000 hands (95% CI). These results suggest
that LLMs could be a new way to deal with multi-player imperfect-information
games like poker.

</details>


### [305] [Role-Aware Multi-modal federated learning system for detecting phishing webpages](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22369)
*Bo Wang,Imran Khan,Martin White,Natalia Beloff*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A federated, multi-modal phishing detector enabling URL/HTML/IMAGE inputs with modality-agnostic inference; uses role-aware bucket aggregation on FedProx with hard gating.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To detect phishing in privacy-preserving federated settings while supporting multiple data modalities and avoiding fixed modality binding during inference; address cross-embedding conflicts and training instability.

Method: Introduce role-aware bucket aggregation on top of FedProx, inspired by Mixture-of-Experts and FedMM, using hard gating to select modality-specific experts and aggregate separately; no learnable routing; separate modality parameter aggregation; modality-specific heads; embeddings: GraphCodeBERT for URLs, early three-way embedding for HTML; evaluate on datasets TR-OP and WebPhish.

Result: Fusion head achieves Acc 97.5% and FPR 2.4% on TR-OP across two data types; image subset Ablation: Acc 95.5%, FPR 5.9%; Text: GraphCodeBERT for URLs; on WebPhish (HTML): 96.5%/1.8%; on TR-OP (raw HTML): 95.1%/4.6%.

Conclusion: Bucket aggregation with hard-gated experts enables stable federated training under strict privacy and improves usability and flexibility of multi-modal phishing detection.

Abstract: We present a federated, multi-modal phishing website detector that supports
URL, HTML, and IMAGE inputs without binding clients to a fixed modality at
inference: any client can invoke any modality head trained elsewhere.
Methodologically, we propose role-aware bucket aggregation on top of FedProx,
inspired by Mixture-of-Experts and FedMM. We drop learnable routing and use
hard gating (selecting the IMAGE/HTML/URL expert by sample modality), enabling
separate aggregation of modality-specific parameters to isolate cross-embedding
conflicts and stabilize convergence. On TR-OP, the Fusion head reaches Acc
97.5% with FPR 2.4% across two data types; on the image subset (ablation) it
attains Acc 95.5% with FPR 5.9%. For text, we use GraphCodeBERT for URLs and an
early three-way embedding for raw, noisy HTML. On WebPhish (HTML) we obtain Acc
96.5% / FPR 1.8%; on TR-OP (raw HTML) we obtain Acc 95.1% / FPR 4.6%. Results
indicate that bucket aggregation with hard-gated experts enables stable
federated training under strict privacy, while improving the usability and
flexibility of multi-modal phishing detection.

</details>


### [306] [Enhancing Credit Risk Prediction: A Meta-Learning Framework Integrating Baseline Models, LASSO, and ECOC for Superior Accuracy](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22381)
*Haibo Wang,Lutfu S. Sua,Jun Huang,Figen Balo,Burak Dolar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A meta-learning ensemble integrating supervised, unsupervised, deep learning, LASSO feature selection, and ECOC meta-classifier with permutation feature importance, applied to Corporate Credit Ratings dataset; improves classification of credit rating migrations and default probability estimation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Tackle high-dimensional data, interpretability, rare events, and multi-class imbalance in credit risk; provide holistic, transparent risk assessment.

Method: Combine XGBoost, Random Forest, SVM, Decision Tree, KNN, MLP; LASSO for feature selection/dimensionality reduction; Error-Correcting Output Codes as meta-classifier for multi-class imbalances; permutation feature importance across classes; evaluation on Corporate Credit Ratings dataset (2,029 US companies).

Result: Meta-learning framework significantly enhances accuracy for credit rating migration classification and default probability estimation compared to baselines.

Conclusion: Supports more accurate and reliable credit risk decision support; demonstrates effective integration of diverse modeling paradigms and interpretability tools to address core challenges.

Abstract: Effective credit risk management is fundamental to financial decision-making,
necessitating robust models for default probability prediction and financial
entity classification. Traditional machine learning approaches face significant
challenges when confronted with high-dimensional data, limited
interpretability, rare event detection, and multi-class imbalance problems in
risk assessment. This research proposes a comprehensive meta-learning framework
that synthesizes multiple complementary models: supervised learning algorithms,
including XGBoost, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Decision Tree;
unsupervised methods such as K-Nearest Neighbors; deep learning architectures
like Multilayer Perceptron; alongside LASSO regularization for feature
selection and dimensionality reduction; and Error-Correcting Output Codes as a
meta-classifier for handling imbalanced multi-class problems. We implement
Permutation Feature Importance analysis for each prediction class across all
constituent models to enhance model transparency. Our framework aims to
optimize predictive performance while providing a more holistic approach to
credit risk assessment. This research contributes to the development of more
accurate and reliable computational models for strategic financial decision
support by addressing three fundamental challenges in credit risk modeling. The
empirical validation of our approach involves an analysis of the Corporate
Credit Ratings dataset with credit ratings for 2,029 publicly listed US
companies. Results demonstrate that our meta-learning framework significantly
enhances the accuracy of financial entity classification regarding credit
rating migrations (upgrades and downgrades) and default probability estimation.

</details>


### [307] [(Sometimes) Less is More: Mitigating the Complexity of Rule-based Representation for Interpretable Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22384)
*Luca Bergamin,Roberto Confalonieri,Fabio Aiolli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Differentiable L0 regularization is applied to a logic-based neural network (MLLP) to reduce the complexity of its discrete interpretable version (CRS) without sacrificing performance, compared against a random weight binarization baseline; highlights a trade-off between CRS simplicity and accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enhance interpretability and sparsity in concept-rule-based networks by using a differentiable L0 penalty, addressing the gap between high performance and transparent, compact models.

Method: Incorporate a differentiable approximation of L0 regularization into the Multi-layer Logical Perceptron (MLLP); train with this regularizer to reduce CRS complexity; compare results to Random Binarization of network weights as a baseline; analyze the resulting complexity-performance trade-off.

Result: The differentiable L0 regularization approach yields a sparser, less complex CRS while preserving (or closely matching) performance, and it outperforms the Random Binarization baseline in producing compact, accurate models.

Conclusion: Differentiable L0 regularization effectively reduces complexity in logic-based neural networks (MLLP/CRS) without sacrificing performance, supporting its use for interpretable AI systems and guiding future work on scalable, sparse, interpretable architectures.

Abstract: Deep neural networks are widely used in practical applications of AI,
however, their inner structure and complexity made them generally not easily
interpretable. Model transparency and interpretability are key requirements for
multiple scenarios where high performance is not enough to adopt the proposed
solution. In this work, a differentiable approximation of $L_0$ regularization
is adapted into a logic-based neural network, the Multi-layer Logical
Perceptron (MLLP), to study its efficacy in reducing the complexity of its
discrete interpretable version, the Concept Rule Set (CRS), while retaining its
performance. The results are compared to alternative heuristics like Random
Binarization of the network weights, to determine if better results can be
achieved when using a less-noisy technique that sparsifies the network based on
the loss function instead of a random distribution. The trade-off between the
CRS complexity and its performance is discussed.

</details>


### [308] [Partial Parameter Updates for Efficient Distributed Training](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22418)
*Anastasiia Filippova,Angelos Katharopoulos,David Grangier,Ronan Collobert*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A memory- and compute-efficient low-communication distributed training method that freezes most parameters during local steps, updating only a fixed subset to reduce memory and FLOPs, while still performing a full forward pass. It matches prior low-communication approaches in perplexity on a 1.3B-parameter model trained on 32 nodes under the same budgets, with lower computation and peak memory.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce memory footprint, computation, and communication overhead in distributed training. Existing low-communication methods rely on multiple local updates with infrequent global sync and often incur higher memory and FLOPs due to backprop across all parameters.

Method: During local steps, each node updates only a fixed subset of parameters while keeping the remaining parameters frozen. A full forward pass is performed over all parameters, which eliminates the need for cross-node activation exchange during backpropagation.

Result: Experiments on a 1.3B-parameter language model trained across 32 nodes show the method matches the perplexity of prior low-communication approaches under identical token and bandwidth budgets, while reducing training FLOPs and peak memory usage.

Conclusion: Constraining backpropagation to a fixed subset of parameters substantially reduces memory and compute without sacrificing model performance under given communication budgets; the approach eliminates cross-node activation exchange and can enable more scalable distributed training.

Abstract: We introduce a memory- and compute-efficient method for low-communication
distributed training. Existing methods reduce communication by performing
multiple local updates between infrequent global synchronizations. We
demonstrate that their efficiency can be significantly improved by restricting
backpropagation: instead of updating all the parameters, each node updates only
a fixed subset while keeping the remainder frozen during local steps. This
constraint substantially reduces peak memory usage and training FLOPs, while a
full forward pass over all parameters eliminates the need for cross-node
activation exchange. Experiments on a $1.3$B-parameter language model trained
across $32$ nodes show that our method matches the perplexity of prior
low-communication approaches under identical token and bandwidth budgets while
reducing training FLOPs and peak memory.

</details>


### [309] [Improving accuracy in short mortality rate series: Exploring Multi-step Forecasting Approaches in Hybrid Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22395)
*Filipe C. L. Duarte,Paulo S. G. de Mattos Neto,Paulo R. A. Firmino*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Hybrid statistical-ML mortality forecasts: ARIMA-LSTM with a recursive multi-step approach provides superior accuracy across 12 datasets and 21 models, showing the importance of both the multi-step method and ML-choice.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In a context of declining interest rates and economic stabilization, accurate mortality forecasting is vital for insurance, pensions, and public health planning. Multi-step forecasts are needed but data-limited; hybrid models help capture linear and nonlinear patterns.

Method: Compared several multi-step forecasting strategies (Recursive, Direct, Multi-Input Multi-Output) and ML models within hybrid systems; evaluated across 12 datasets and 21 configurations; found ARIMA-LSTM with recursive approach often outperforms others.

Result: Performance is highly sensitive to the chosen multi-step approach and ML model; ARIMA-LSTM recursive hybrid achieved the best results in most cases.

Conclusion: Selecting an appropriate multi-step strategy and ML model is crucial for improving forecast accuracy in mortality rate forecasting; recursive ARIMA-LSTM hybrid is a strong default, with potential for further improvements by exploring additional hybrids and datasets.

Abstract: The decline in interest rates and economic stabilization has heightened the
importance of accurate mortality rate forecasting, particularly in insurance
and pension markets. Multi-step-ahead predictions are crucial for public
health, demographic planning, and insurance risk assessments; however, they
face challenges when data are limited. Hybrid systems that combine statistical
and Machine Learning (ML) models offer a promising solution for handling both
linear and nonlinear patterns. This study evaluated the impact of different
multi-step forecasting approaches (Recursive, Direct, and Multi-Input
Multi-Output) and ML models on the accuracy of hybrid systems. Results from 12
datasets and 21 models show that the selection of both the multi-step approach
and the ML model is essential for improving performance, with the ARIMA-LSTM
hybrid using a recursive approach outperforming other models in most cases.

</details>


### [310] [Global Convergence in Neural ODEs: Impact of Activation Functions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22436)
*Tianxiang Gao,Siyuan Sun,Hailiang Liu,Hongyang Gao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Activation smoothness and nonlinearity are crucial for training Neural ODEs: smoothness ensures globally unique forward/backward solutions, nonlinearity preserves the NTK spectrum, together enabling global convergence under gradient descent in overparameterized regimes, supported by numerical experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address training challenges in Neural ODEs—particularly gradient accuracy and convergence—by understanding how activation function properties influence forward/backward dynamics and kernel behavior.

Method: Theoretical analysis connecting activation function smoothness to well-posed forward and backward ODEs and sufficient nonlinearity to maintain NV (NTK) spectral properties during training; analysis is complemented by numerical experiments to validate theory and derive practical scaling guidelines.

Result: Proves global convergence of Neural ODEs under gradient descent in overparameterized regimes; demonstrates that smooth activations yield unique solutions for forward and backward passes while nonlinearities preserve NTK spectrum; numerical experiments validate theory and offer guidelines for scaling Neural ODEs for faster training and improved performance.

Conclusion: Activation function design—ensuring smoothness and sufficient nonlinearity—is key to training stability and global convergence in Neural ODEs, providing theoretical guarantees and practical guidelines for scaling and deployment.

Abstract: Neural Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) have been successful in various
applications due to their continuous nature and parameter-sharing efficiency.
However, these unique characteristics also introduce challenges in training,
particularly with respect to gradient computation accuracy and convergence
analysis. In this paper, we address these challenges by investigating the
impact of activation functions. We demonstrate that the properties of
activation functions, specifically smoothness and nonlinearity, are critical to
the training dynamics. Smooth activation functions guarantee globally unique
solutions for both forward and backward ODEs, while sufficient nonlinearity is
essential for maintaining the spectral properties of the Neural Tangent Kernel
(NTK) during training. Together, these properties enable us to establish the
global convergence of Neural ODEs under gradient descent in overparameterized
regimes. Our theoretical findings are validated by numerical experiments, which
not only support our analysis but also provide practical guidelines for scaling
Neural ODEs, potentially leading to faster training and improved performance in
real-world applications.

</details>


### [311] [Bridging Kolmogorov Complexity and Deep Learning: Asymptotically Optimal Description Length Objectives for Transformers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22445)
*Peter Shaw,James Cohan,Jacob Eisenstein,Kristina Toutanova*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: The paper defines asymptotically optimal description length objectives (AO-DLO) grounded in Kolmogorov complexity to tackle model complexity in neural networks. It proves such objectives exist for Transformers, makes them tractable via a variational objective with an adaptive Gaussian mixture prior, and empirically shows these objectives promote low-complexity, well-generalizing solutions, though optimization is challenging; the work outlines a framework toward training models with better compression and generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MDL and Occam's razor offer a principled approach to model complexity, but neural networks lack a universal complexity measure. The authors seek a theoretically grounded, asymptotically optimal description length objective that can apply to powerful models like Transformers, with concrete guarantees and practical tractability.

Method: (1) Prove the existence of asymptotically optimal description length objectives for Transformers by leveraging their computational universality. (2) Propose a tractable, differentiable variational objective based on an adaptive Gaussian mixture prior. (3) Empirically evaluate on an algorithmic task, showing the objective favors low-complexity solutions and strong generalization, while noting optimization challenges with random initialization.

Result: Theoretical framework establishing AO-DLO existence for Transformers; a variational, tractable surrogate using adaptive Gaussian mixtures; empirical evidence that the objective promotes compression and generalization, but standard optimizers may fail to reach such solutions from random starts.

Conclusion: The work provides a rigorous framework for constructing description-length objectives with strong asymptotic guarantees and demonstrates a practical variational approach that could enable more compressed, generalizable neural networks in the future, while acknowledging current optimization hurdles.

Abstract: The Minimum Description Length (MDL) principle offers a formal framework for
applying Occam's razor in machine learning. However, its application to neural
networks such as Transformers is challenging due to the lack of a principled,
universal measure for model complexity. This paper introduces the theoretical
notion of asymptotically optimal description length objectives, grounded in the
theory of Kolmogorov complexity. We establish that a minimizer of such an
objective achieves optimal compression, for any dataset, up to an additive
constant, in the limit as model resource bounds increase. We prove that
asymptotically optimal objectives exist for Transformers, building on a new
demonstration of their computational universality. We further show that such
objectives can be tractable and differentiable by constructing and analyzing a
variational objective based on an adaptive Gaussian mixture prior. Our
empirical analysis shows that this variational objective selects for a
low-complexity solution with strong generalization on an algorithmic task, but
standard optimizers fail to find such solutions from a random initialization,
highlighting key optimization challenges. More broadly, by providing a
theoretical framework for identifying description length objectives with strong
asymptotic guarantees, we outline a potential path towards training neural
networks that achieve greater compression and generalization.

</details>


### [312] [MoveFM-R: Advancing Mobility Foundation Models via Language-driven Semantic Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22403)
*Fanjin Meng,Yuan Yuan,Jingtao Ding,Jie Feng,Chonghua Han,Yong Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MoveFM-R integrates mobility foundation models with language models by introducing semantically enhanced location encoding, a progressive curriculum, and an interactive self-reflection mechanism, enabling semantically guided, realistic trajectory generation and strong zero-shot generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MFMs are limited by data scale and a shallow understanding of semantics, while LLMs lack innate spatio-temporal statistics necessary for plausible mobility trajectories. There is a gap between continuous geographic coordinates and discrete language tokens, as well as between MFM latent vectors and LLM semantics.

Method: Three core innovations: (1) semantically enhanced location encoding to bridge geography-language gap, (2) a progressive curriculum to align the LLM’s reasoning with mobility patterns, and (3) an interactive self-reflection mechanism for conditional trajectory generation.

Result: MoveFM-R significantly outperforms both MFM-based and LLM-based baselines, demonstrates robust zero-shot generalization, and excels at generating realistic trajectories from natural language instructions.

Conclusion: By combining the statistical power of MFMs with the deep semantic understanding of LLMs, MoveFM-R establishes a new paradigm for interpretable and powerful mobility modeling, enabling semantically guided trajectory generation and broader applicability.

Abstract: Mobility Foundation Models (MFMs) have advanced the modeling of human
movement patterns, yet they face a ceiling due to limitations in data scale and
semantic understanding. While Large Language Models (LLMs) offer powerful
semantic reasoning, they lack the innate understanding of spatio-temporal
statistics required for generating physically plausible mobility trajectories.
To address these gaps, we propose MoveFM-R, a novel framework that unlocks the
full potential of mobility foundation models by leveraging language-driven
semantic reasoning capabilities. It tackles two key challenges: the vocabulary
mismatch between continuous geographic coordinates and discrete language
tokens, and the representation gap between the latent vectors of MFMs and the
semantic world of LLMs. MoveFM-R is built on three core innovations: a
semantically enhanced location encoding to bridge the geography-language gap, a
progressive curriculum to align the LLM's reasoning with mobility patterns, and
an interactive self-reflection mechanism for conditional trajectory generation.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that MoveFM-R significantly outperforms
existing MFM-based and LLM-based baselines. It also shows robust generalization
in zero-shot settings and excels at generating realistic trajectories from
natural language instructions. By synthesizing the statistical power of MFMs
with the deep semantic understanding of LLMs, MoveFM-R pioneers a new paradigm
that enables a more comprehensive, interpretable, and powerful modeling of
human mobility. The implementation of MoveFM-R is available online at
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/MoveFM-R-CDE7/.

</details>


### [313] [Physics-informed GNN for medium-high voltage AC power flow with edge-aware attention and line search correction operator](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22458)
*Changhun Kim,Timon Conrad,Redwanul Karim,Julian Oelhaf,David Riebesel,Tomás Arias-Vergara,Andreas Maier,Johann Jäger,Siming Bayer*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Edge-aware PIGNN with a backtracking line-search delivers accurate, fast AC power-flow inference, outperforming NR and PIGNN baselines on multi-bus grids.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current physics-informed GNNs (PIGNNs) struggle to maintain parity-accurate results at fast inference; the physics loss is inactive during inference, hindering adoption for large-scenario tasks.

Method: Introduce an edge-aware attention mechanism with per-edge biases encoding line physics to capture grid anisotropy, plus a backtracking line-search-based global correction operator to enforce a decrease criterion at inference. Train/test on HV/MV scenario generator with NR only for references.

Result: On held-out HV cases with 4–32-bus grids, the model achieves RMSE of 0.00033 p.u. in voltage and 0.08 degrees in angle, surpassing PIGNN-MLP by 99.5% and 87.1% respectively. Streaming micro-batches yield 2–5x faster batched inference than NR on 4–1024-bus grids.

Conclusion: The combination delivers both high accuracy and substantial speed gains, enabling practical adoption of PIGNN-based power-flow solvers for large-scale, multi-scenario workloads; the inference-time physics enforcement comes from the correction operator, addressing the prior inoperativeness of physics loss.

Abstract: Physics-informed graph neural networks (PIGNNs) have emerged as fast AC
power-flow solvers that can replace classic Newton--Raphson (NR) solvers,
especially when thousands of scenarios must be evaluated. However, current
PIGNNs still need accuracy improvements at parity speed; in particular, the
physics loss is inoperative at inference, which can deter operational adoption.
We address this with PIGNN-Attn-LS, combining an edge-aware attention mechanism
that explicitly encodes line physics via per-edge biases, capturing the grid's
anisotropy, with a backtracking line-search-based globalized correction
operator that restores an operative decrease criterion at inference. Training
and testing use a realistic High-/Medium-Voltage scenario generator, with NR
used only to construct reference states. On held-out HV cases consisting of
4--32-bus grids, PIGNN-Attn-LS achieves a test RMSE of 0.00033 p.u. in voltage
and 0.08$^\circ$ in angle, outperforming the PIGNN-MLP baseline by 99.5\% and
87.1\%, respectively. With streaming micro-batches, it delivers 2--5$\times$
faster batched inference than NR on 4--1024-bus grids.

</details>


### [314] [Fast-Forward Lattice Boltzmann: Learning Kinetic Behaviour with Physics-Informed Neural Operators](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22411)
*Xiao Xue,Marco F. P. ten Eikelder,Mingyang Gao,Xiaoyuan Cheng,Yiming Yang,Yi He,Shuo Wang,Sibo Cheng,Yukun Hu,Peter V. Coveney*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A physics-informed neural operator for the lattice Boltzmann equation enabling long-horizon predictions and kinetic super-resolution by embedding moment-matching and equivariance constraints, grid-invariant and collision-model-agnostic, validated on complex flows.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To reduce the computational cost of LBE simulations by avoiding step-by-step collision-kernel integration, and to enable generalization across lattice resolutions and across diverse kinetic datasets.

Method: A neural operator framework that enforces intrinsic LBE moment-matching constraints and global distribution equivariance, is discretization-invariant (trained on coarse lattices and generalizes to finer lattices), and is agnostic to the specific collision model; applied to diverse kinetic datasets and flow scenarios.

Result: Demonstrates robustness in complex flows (von Karman vortex shedding, ligament breakup, bubble adhesion) and the ability to predict over large time horizons without explicit collision-kernel solving, enabling kinetic super-resolution.

Conclusion: Provides a data-driven pathway for modeling kinetic systems, expanding LBE modeling capability beyond stepwise integration, with cross-grid generalization and collision-model-agnostic applicability.

Abstract: The lattice Boltzmann equation (LBE), rooted in kinetic theory, provides a
powerful framework for capturing complex flow behaviour by describing the
evolution of single-particle distribution functions (PDFs). Despite its
success, solving the LBE numerically remains computationally intensive due to
strict time-step restrictions imposed by collision kernels. Here, we introduce
a physics-informed neural operator framework for the LBE that enables
prediction over large time horizons without step-by-step integration,
effectively bypassing the need to explicitly solve the collision kernel. We
incorporate intrinsic moment-matching constraints of the LBE, along with global
equivariance of the full distribution field, enabling the model to capture the
complex dynamics of the underlying kinetic system. Our framework is
discretization-invariant, enabling models trained on coarse lattices to
generalise to finer ones (kinetic super-resolution). In addition, it is
agnostic to the specific form of the underlying collision model, which makes it
naturally applicable across different kinetic datasets regardless of the
governing dynamics. Our results demonstrate robustness across complex flow
scenarios, including von Karman vortex shedding, ligament breakup, and bubble
adhesion. This establishes a new data-driven pathway for modelling kinetic
systems.

</details>


### [315] [Learning the Neighborhood: Contrast-Free Multimodal Self-Supervised Molecular Graph Pretraining](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22468)
*Boshra Ariguib,Mathias Niepert,Andrei Manolache*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: C-FREE is a simple, negative-free self-supervised framework that combines 2D molecular graphs with ensembles of 3D conformers via ego-nets, predicting subgraph embeddings in latent space; it achieves state-of-the-art MoleculeNet performance and robust transfer to diverse chemical domains.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: High-quality molecular representations are scarce due to limited labeled data; many self-supervised methods rely on 2D topology, hand-crafted augmentations, or complex objectives, leaving 3D information underutilized; there is a need to leverage 3D structure for improved prediction and design.

Method: Integrate 2D graphs with multiple conformers using fixed-radius ego-nets as modeling units; learn by predicting subgraph embeddings from complementary latent-space neighborhoods; use a hybrid GNN-Transformer backbone; avoid negatives, positional encodings, or expensive pre-processing.

Result: Pretraining on GEOM yields state-of-the-art results on MoleculeNet, outperforming contrastive, generative, and multimodal SSL methods; strong transfer to datasets of varying sizes and chemistries, confirming 3D-informed representations improve generalization.

Conclusion: 3D-informed molecular representations via simple, negative-free SSL on ego-nets facilitate better property prediction and molecular design, with strong transfer across chemical domains.

Abstract: High-quality molecular representations are essential for property prediction
and molecular design, yet large labeled datasets remain scarce. While
self-supervised pretraining on molecular graphs has shown promise, many
existing approaches either depend on hand-crafted augmentations or complex
generative objectives, and often rely solely on 2D topology, leaving valuable
3D structural information underutilized. To address this gap, we introduce
C-FREE (Contrast-Free Representation learning on Ego-nets), a simple framework
that integrates 2D graphs with ensembles of 3D conformers. C-FREE learns
molecular representations by predicting subgraph embeddings from their
complementary neighborhoods in the latent space, using fixed-radius ego-nets as
modeling units across different conformers. This design allows us to integrate
both geometric and topological information within a hybrid Graph Neural Network
(GNN)-Transformer backbone, without negatives, positional encodings, or
expensive pre-processing. Pretraining on the GEOM dataset, which provides rich
3D conformational diversity, C-FREE achieves state-of-the-art results on
MoleculeNet, surpassing contrastive, generative, and other multimodal
self-supervised methods. Fine-tuning across datasets with diverse sizes and
molecule types further demonstrates that pretraining transfers effectively to
new chemical domains, highlighting the importance of 3D-informed molecular
representations.

</details>


### [316] [One Prompt Fits All: Universal Graph Adaptation for Pretrained Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22416)
*Yongqi Huang,Jitao Zhao,Dongxiao He,Xiaobao Wang,Yawen Li,Yuxiao Huang,Di Jin,Zhiyong Feng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes UniPrompt to unify Graph Prompt Learning by theoretically analyzing GPL mechanisms, identifying representation-level prompts as akin to downstream classifier fine-tuning, and showing UniPrompt can adapt pretrained models while preserving graph structure to achieve strong in-domain and cross-domain performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GPL lacks consensus on how prompts interact with pretrained graph models and struggles with data distribution shifts across downstream tasks; a unified theory and adaptable method are needed.

Method: The paper theoretically analyzes existing GPL approaches to show representation-level prompts function like fine-tuning a classifier; based on this, proposes UniPrompt that adapts pretrained models to graphs without modifying the graph structure; validates compatibility with various pretrained models and tests on in-domain and cross-domain tasks including distribution shifts.

Result: UniPrompt integrates with various pretrained models and achieves strong performance in both in-domain and cross-domain scenarios, demonstrating improved adaptability to distribution shifts while preserving graph structure.

Conclusion: GPL should focus on unlocking the capabilities of pretrained models rather than modifying inputs; a unified approach like UniPrompt provides robust, adaptable graph learning across diverse tasks.

Abstract: Graph Prompt Learning (GPL) has emerged as a promising paradigm that bridges
graph pretraining models and downstream scenarios, mitigating label dependency
and the misalignment between upstream pretraining and downstream tasks.
Although existing GPL studies explore various prompt strategies, their
effectiveness and underlying principles remain unclear. We identify two
critical limitations: (1) Lack of consensus on underlying mechanisms: Despite
current GPLs have advanced the field, there is no consensus on how prompts
interact with pretrained models, as different strategies intervene at varying
spaces within the model, i.e., input-level, layer-wise, and
representation-level prompts. (2) Limited scenario adaptability: Most methods
fail to generalize across diverse downstream scenarios, especially under data
distribution shifts (e.g., homophilic-to-heterophilic graphs). To address these
issues, we theoretically analyze existing GPL approaches and reveal that
representation-level prompts essentially function as fine-tuning a simple
downstream classifier, proposing that graph prompt learning should focus on
unleashing the capability of pretrained models, and the classifier adapts to
downstream scenarios. Based on our findings, we propose UniPrompt, a novel GPL
method that adapts any pretrained models, unleashing the capability of
pretrained models while preserving the structure of the input graph. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that our method can effectively integrate with various
pretrained models and achieve strong performance across in-domain and
cross-domain scenarios.

</details>


### [317] [OFMU: Optimization-Driven Framework for Machine Unlearning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22483)
*Sadia Asif,Mohammad Mohammadi Amiri*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: OFMU is a penalty-based bi-level optimization framework for machine unlearning that prioritizes forgetting via an inner maximization with a similarity-aware gradient penalty and outer minimization to preserve utility, offering convergence guarantees and improved forgetting-utility trade-offs on vision and language tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is a growing need to unlearn targeted data in deployed LLMs and other models without full retraining, due to regulatory, privacy, and safety requirements. Traditional scalarization approaches for multi-objective forgetting/retention often yield unstable training and degraded utility.

Method: A two-loop bi-level optimization. Inner loop performs forgetting with a similarity-aware penalty to decorrelate gradients between forgetting and retention objectives; outer loop minimizes retention to restore utility. The framework includes convergence proofs for convex and non-convex regimes and a scalable algorithm with provable rates.

Result: Empirical results on vision and language benchmarks show OFMU consistently outperforms existing unlearning methods in forgetting efficacy while preserving retained utility.

Conclusion: OFMU provides a scalable, theoretically grounded approach to machine unlearning, achieving better forgetting-utility trade-offs and offering convergence guarantees, thereby supporting regulatory/privacy-safe deployment in practice.

Abstract: Large language models deployed in sensitive applications increasingly require
the ability to unlearn specific knowledge, such as user requests, copyrighted
materials, or outdated information, without retraining from scratch to ensure
regulatory compliance, user privacy, and safety. This task, known as machine
unlearning, aims to remove the influence of targeted data (forgetting) while
maintaining performance on the remaining data (retention). A common approach is
to formulate this as a multi-objective problem and reduce it to a
single-objective problem via scalarization, where forgetting and retention
losses are combined using a weighted sum. However, this often results in
unstable training dynamics and degraded model utility due to conflicting
gradient directions. To address these challenges, we propose OFMU, a
penalty-based bi-level optimization framework that explicitly prioritizes
forgetting while preserving retention through a hierarchical structure. Our
method enforces forgetting via an inner maximization step that incorporates a
similarity-aware penalty to decorrelate the gradients of the forget and
retention objectives, and restores utility through an outer minimization step.
To ensure scalability, we develop a two-loop algorithm with provable
convergence guarantees under both convex and non-convex regimes. We further
provide a rigorous theoretical analysis of convergence rates and show that our
approach achieves better trade-offs between forgetting efficacy and model
utility compared to prior methods. Extensive experiments across vision and
language benchmarks demonstrate that OFMU consistently outperforms existing
unlearning methods in both forgetting efficacy and retained utility.

</details>


### [318] [A Machine Learning Pipeline for Multiple Sclerosis Biomarker Discovery: Comparing explainable AI and Traditional Statistical Approaches](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22484)
*Samuele Punzo,Silvia Giulia Galfrè,Francesco Massafra,Alessandro Maglione,Corrado Priami,Alina Sîrbu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A ML-based pipeline integrates eight PBMC microarray datasets to discover MS biomarkers using XGBoost with Bayesian hyperparameter optimization; SHAP identifies key features, which are compared to Differential Expression Analysis (DEA). SHAP and DEA yield overlapping and unique biomarkers; enrichment connects SHAP features to MS-relevant pathways, illustrating the value of combining explainable AI with traditional statistics for mechanistic insight.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To identify robust biomarkers for Multiple Sclerosis by leveraging multi-dataset machine learning with model explainability, and to assess whether explainable AI features align with classical differential expression signals to provide complementary information and mechanistic insight.

Method: Integrate eight publicly available PBMC microarray datasets; robust preprocessing; train an XGBoost classifier; optimize hyperparameters via Bayesian search; compute SHAP values to identify top features for model prediction; compare SHAP-selected genes with those from Differential Expression Analysis (DEA); perform enrichment analysis to link SHAP genes to MS-related pathways.

Result: SHAP identified key features that overlap with but also extend beyond DEA genes; SHAP-identified genes show enrichment in sphingolipid signaling, Th1/Th2/Th17 differentiation, and Epstein-Barr virus infection pathways, supporting biological relevance; the study highlights complementary strengths of xAI and traditional statistics in biomarker discovery.

Conclusion: Explainable AI (SHAP) combined with classical differential expression analysis provides complementary biomarker discovery insights in MS; the approach validates biologically relevant pathways and demonstrates the value of integrating xAI with conventional statistics to deepen understanding of disease mechanisms.

Abstract: We present a machine learning pipeline for biomarker discovery in Multiple
Sclerosis (MS), integrating eight publicly available microarray datasets from
Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cells (PBMC). After robust preprocessing we
trained an XGBoost classifier optimized via Bayesian search. SHapley Additive
exPlanations (SHAP) were used to identify key features for model prediction,
indicating thus possible biomarkers. These were compared with genes identified
through classical Differential Expression Analysis (DEA). Our comparison
revealed both overlapping and unique biomarkers between SHAP and DEA,
suggesting complementary strengths. Enrichment analysis confirmed the
biological relevance of SHAP-selected genes, linking them to pathways such as
sphingolipid signaling, Th1/Th2/Th17 cell differentiation, and Epstein-Barr
virus infection all known to be associated with MS. This study highlights the
value of combining explainable AI (xAI) with traditional statistical methods to
gain deeper insights into disease mechanism.

</details>


### [319] [Learning from Delayed Feedback in Games via Extra Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22426)
*Yuma Fujimoto,Kenshi Abe,Kaito Ariu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: This paper investigates time-delayed rewards in learning in games and proposes Weighted OFTRL (WOFTRL) to offset delays. It shows that delays degrade regret and convergence for optimistic FTRL, but with sufficient optimistic weighting the method achieves constant regret (O(1)) in general-sum games and best-iterate convergence to Nash equilibria in zero-sum poly-matrix games, supported by experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In multi-agent learning, agents update strategies based on past rewards. Delays in observing rewards create misalignment among agents and degrade learning performance. The study seeks a method that remains robust to such delays.

Method: Introduce Weighted OFTRL (WOFTRL) by amplifying the next reward prediction by a factor n. Argue that the optimistic weight offsets time delay. Prove that if the optimistic weight exceeds the time delay, regret is O(1) in general-sum normal-form games, and strategies converge (best-iterate) to Nash equilibria in poly-matrix zero-sum games. Support with experiments.

Result: Theoretical guarantees: O(1)-regret in general-sum normal-form games; best-iterate convergence to Nash equilibria in poly-matrix zero-sum games. Empirical results corroborate the theory.

Conclusion: WOFTRL can overcome time-delayed feedback in learning in games when the optimistic weight is sufficiently large relative to the delay, restoring favorable regret and convergence properties. The approach is supported by experiments.

Abstract: This study raises and addresses the problem of time-delayed feedback in
learning in games. Because learning in games assumes that multiple agents
independently learn their strategies, a discrepancy in optimization often
emerges among the agents. To overcome this discrepancy, the prediction of the
future reward is incorporated into algorithms, typically known as Optimistic
Follow-the-Regularized-Leader (OFTRL). However, the time delay in observing the
past rewards hinders the prediction. Indeed, this study firstly proves that
even a single-step delay worsens the performance of OFTRL from the aspects of
regret and convergence. This study proposes the weighted OFTRL (WOFTRL), where
the prediction vector of the next reward in OFTRL is weighted $n$ times. We
further capture an intuition that the optimistic weight cancels out this time
delay. We prove that when the optimistic weight exceeds the time delay, our
WOFTRL recovers the good performances that the regret is constant
($O(1)$-regret) in general-sum normal-form games, and the strategies converge
to the Nash equilibrium as a subsequence (best-iterate convergence) in
poly-matrix zero-sum games. The theoretical results are supported and
strengthened by our experiments.

</details>


### [320] [Activation Function Design Sustains Plasticity in Continual Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22562)
*Lute Lillo,Nick Cheney*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Activation design (Smooth-Leaky variants) preserves plasticity in continual learning across supervised and RL tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In continual learning, models face plasticity loss beyond forgetting; the role of non-linearities is understudied and activation choices may offer a robust, architecture-agnostic solution.

Method: Propose two drop-in nonlinearities (Smooth-Leaky and Randomized Smooth-Leaky), analyze their negative-branch shape and saturation, and evaluate on supervised class-incremental benchmarks and RL with non-stationary MuJoCo environments; introduce a stress protocol and diagnostics to link activation shape to adaptation.

Result: Activation choice emerges as a primary lever to mitigate plasticity loss, with the proposed activations sustaining adaptation without added capacity or task-specific tuning across domains.

Conclusion: Thoughtful activation design provides a lightweight, domain-general strategy to maintain plasticity in continual learning.

Abstract: In independent, identically distributed (i.i.d.) training regimes, activation
functions have been benchmarked extensively, and their differences often shrink
once model size and optimization are tuned. In continual learning, however, the
picture is different: beyond catastrophic forgetting, models can progressively
lose the ability to adapt (referred to as loss of plasticity) and the role of
the non-linearity in this failure mode remains underexplored. We show that
activation choice is a primary, architecture-agnostic lever for mitigating
plasticity loss. Building on a property-level analysis of negative-branch shape
