and saturation behavior, we introduce two drop-in nonlinearities (Smooth-Leaky
and Randomized Smooth-Leaky) and evaluate them in two complementary settings:
(i) supervised class-incremental benchmarks and (ii) reinforcement learning
with non-stationary MuJoCo environments designed to induce controlled
distribution and dynamics shifts. We also provide a simple stress protocol and
diagnostics that link the shape of the activation to the adaptation under
change. The takeaway is straightforward: thoughtful activation design offers a
lightweight, domain-general way to sustain plasticity in continual learning
without extra capacity or task-specific tuning.

</details>


### [321] [From Parameters to Behavior: Unsupervised Compression of the Policy Space](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22566)
*Davide Tenedini,Riccardo Zamboni,Mirco Mutti,Marcello Restelli*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Unsupervised compression of policy parameter space into a latent manifold to improve sample efficiency and enable latent-space policy gradient, achieving up to 1e5× parameter reduction with preserved expressivity.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: DRL is notoriously sample-inefficient due to high-dimensional, redundant parameter space, and inefficiencies are compounded in multi-task settings; a compressed, functionally organized parameter space could improve learning efficiency and transfer.

Method: Train a generative model g: Z -> Θ using a behavioral reconstruction loss so that Z is organized by functional similarity rather than parameter proximity. Optimize policies in the latent space Z, and argue that intrinsic dimensionality depends on environment complexity. Validate on continuous control tasks and demonstrate large compression with retained expressivity.

Result: The policy parameterization can be compressed by up to five orders of magnitude while preserving most of its expressivity. The learned latent manifold enables task-specific adaptation via Policy Gradient methods operating in Z.

Conclusion: The approach reduces sample inefficiency by leveraging a functionally organized latent space for policy parameters, reveals that the intrinsic dimensionality is environment-dependent, and enables efficient multi-task adaptation and transfer through latent-space optimization.

Abstract: Despite its recent successes, Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) is
notoriously sample-inefficient. We argue that this inefficiency stems from the
standard practice of optimizing policies directly in the high-dimensional and
highly redundant parameter space $\Theta$. This challenge is greatly compounded
in multi-task settings. In this work, we develop a novel, unsupervised approach
that compresses the policy parameter space $\Theta$ into a low-dimensional
latent space $\mathcal{Z}$. We train a generative model
$g:\mathcal{Z}\to\Theta$ by optimizing a behavioral reconstruction loss, which
ensures that the latent space is organized by functional similarity rather than
proximity in parameterization. We conjecture that the inherent dimensionality
of this manifold is a function of the environment's complexity, rather than the
size of the policy network. We validate our approach in continuous control
domains, showing that the parameterization of standard policy networks can be
compressed up to five orders of magnitude while retaining most of its
expressivity. As a byproduct, we show that the learned manifold enables
task-specific adaptation via Policy Gradient operating in the latent space
$\mathcal{Z}$.

</details>


### [322] [Learn the Ropes, Then Trust the Wins: Self-imitation with Progressive Exploration for Agentic Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22601)
*Yulei Qin,Xiaoyu Tan,Zhengbao He,Gang Li,Haojia Lin,Zongyi Li,Zihan Xu,Yuchen Shi,Siqi Cai,Renting Rui,Shaofei Cai,Yuzheng Cai,Xuan Zhang,Sheng Ye,Ke Li,Xing Sun*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SPEAR: a curriculum-based self-imitation learning framework for LLM agentic tools that balances exploration and exploitation across training stages using a replay buffer, intrinsic rewards, and entropy regularization to avoid entropy collapse and instability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Exploration-exploitation in long-horizon, sparse-reward LLM tool-use tasks is challenging; entropy-only methods destabilize training due to distribution shift; there is a need for progressive, experience-guided exploration that stabilizes learning.

Method: Extend vanilla self-imitation learning with a staged curriculum that gradually shifts entropy; use a replay buffer of self-generated trajectories; intrinsic rewards for skill exploration; tool-use exploration via early tool-call reward; strengthen self-imitation later to exploit successful patterns; recalibrate advantages in the replay; clip high-covariance tokens between probability and advantage to stabilize trajectory entropy.

Result: The abstract presents a training recipe and theoretical/empirical goals but does not report experimental results; claims improved stability and balanced exploration, but no numeric outcomes are provided in the abstract.

Conclusion: SPEAR offers a principled, curriculum-driven SIL framework to progressively balance exploration and exploitation in agentic LLMs, aiming for stable training, better tool-use skills, and reduced entropy-related instability.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) is the dominant paradigm for sharpening strategic
tool use capabilities of LLMs on long-horizon, sparsely-rewarded agent tasks,
yet it faces a fundamental challenge of exploration-exploitation trade-off.
Existing studies stimulate exploration through the lens of policy entropy, but
such mechanical entropy maximization is prone to RL training instability due to
the multi-turn distribution shifting. In this paper, we target the progressive
exploration-exploitation balance under the guidance of the agent own
experiences without succumbing to either entropy collapsing or runaway
divergence. We propose SPEAR, a curriculum-based self-imitation learning (SIL)
recipe for training agentic LLMs. It extends the vanilla SIL framework, where a
replay buffer stores self-generated promising trajectories for off-policy
update, by gradually steering the policy evolution within a well-balanced range
of entropy across stages. Specifically, our approach incorporates a curriculum
to manage the exploration process, utilizing intrinsic rewards to foster
skill-level exploration and facilitating action-level exploration through SIL.
At first, the auxiliary tool call reward plays a critical role in the
accumulation of tool-use skills, enabling broad exposure to the unfamiliar
distributions of the environment feedback with an upward entropy trend. As
training progresses, self-imitation gets strengthened to exploit existing
successful patterns from replayed experiences for comparative action-level
exploration, accelerating solution iteration without unbounded entropy growth.
To further stabilize training, we recalibrate the advantages of experiences in
the replay buffer to address the potential policy drift. Reugularizations such
as the clipping of tokens with high covariance between probability and
advantage are introduced to the trajectory-level entropy control to curb
over-confidence.

</details>


### [323] [Overclocking Electrostatic Generative Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22454)
*Daniil Shlenskii,Alexander Korotin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Inverse Poisson Flow Matching (IPFM), a distillation framework for electrostatic generative models (PFGM++) that speeds sampling across all dimensionalities D by training a generator to match the teacher's electrostatic field. As D→∞, IPFM recovers Score Identity Distillation (SiD). Empirically, IPFM yields near-teacher or better samples with few evaluations, with faster convergence at finite D than the diffusion limit.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce compute in electrostatic generative models (like PFGM++) that rely on expensive ODE sampling; enable efficient distillation across all D (including finite D) to improve sampling speed and optimization properties.

Method: Formulates distillation as an inverse problem: learn a generator whose induced electrostatic field matches that of the teacher. Derives a tractable training objective for IPFM. Analyzes asymptotic connection to SiD as D→∞ and demonstrates empirical effectiveness, achieving high-quality samples with few function evaluations. Reports faster convergence for finite D compared to D→∞.

Result: IPFM yields distilled generators that closely match or surpass teacher sample quality with only a few function evaluations. Finite-D distillation converges faster than the diffusion limit (D→∞), aligning with prior findings that finite-D PFGM++ models have favorable optimization and sampling properties.

Conclusion: IPFM provides a general, efficient distillation framework for electrostatic generative models across all D, reducing computational cost while preserving or improving sample quality; finite-D regimes offer additional optimization/sampling advantages.

Abstract: Electrostatic generative models such as PFGM++ have recently emerged as a
powerful framework, achieving state-of-the-art performance in image synthesis.
PFGM++ operates in an extended data space with auxiliary dimensionality $D$,
recovering the diffusion model framework as $D\to\infty$, while yielding
superior empirical results for finite $D$. Like diffusion models, PFGM++ relies
on expensive ODE simulations to generate samples, making it computationally
costly. To address this, we propose Inverse Poisson Flow Matching (IPFM), a
novel distillation framework that accelerates electrostatic generative models
across all values of $D$. Our IPFM reformulates distillation as an inverse
problem: learning a generator whose induced electrostatic field matches that of
the teacher. We derive a tractable training objective for this problem and show
that, as $D \to \infty$, our IPFM closely recovers Score Identity Distillation
(SiD), a recent method for distilling diffusion models. Empirically, our IPFM
produces distilled generators that achieve near-teacher or even superior sample
quality using only a few function evaluations. Moreover, we observe that
distillation converges faster for finite $D$ than in the $D \to \infty$
(diffusion) limit, which is consistent with prior findings that finite-$D$
PFGM++ models exhibit more favorable optimization and sampling properties.

</details>


### [324] [Quantile Advantage Estimation for Entropy-Safe Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22611)
*Junkang Wu,Kexin Huang,Jiancan Wu,An Zhang,Xiang Wang,Xiangnan He*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Replace the mean baseline in reinforcement learning with a group-wise K-quantile baseline (QAE) to stabilize entropy and improve RLVR performance; introduces a two-regime gate for hard vs easy queries and yields theoretical entropy bounds and empirical gains, highlighting baseline design as key to scaling RLVR.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Mean baselines in reward estimation can cause entropy oscillations (collapse or explosion) when reward outliers skew negative-advantage samples; a robust, quantile-based baseline could stabilize RLVR and improve scaling.

Method: Quantile Advantage Estimation (QAE) replaces the mean with a K-quantile baseline across samples, creating a response-level two-regime gate: reinforce rare successes on hard queries (p <= 1 - K) and target remaining failures on easy queries (p > 1 - K). Under first-order softmax updates, derive two-sided entropy safety bounds preventing entropy collapse and explosion.

Result: Entropy is stabilized; credit assignment becomes sparse (roughly 80% of responses get zero advantage); sustained pass@1 gains observed on Qwen3-8B/14B-Base across AIME 2024/2025 and AMC 2023.

Conclusion: Baseline design in RLVR—not token-level heuristics—is the primary lever for scaling; a quantile-based baseline can curb entropy issues and boost performance.

Abstract: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards (RLVR) strengthens LLM
reasoning, but training often oscillates between {entropy collapse} and
{entropy explosion}. We trace both hazards to the mean baseline used in
value-free RL (e.g., GRPO and DAPO), which improperly penalizes
negative-advantage samples under reward outliers. We propose {Quantile
Advantage Estimation} (QAE), replacing the mean with a group-wise K-quantile
baseline. QAE induces a response-level, two-regime gate: on hard queries (p <=
1 - K) it reinforces rare successes, while on easy queries (p > 1 - K) it
targets remaining failures. Under first-order softmax updates, we prove
{two-sided entropy safety}, giving lower and upper bounds on one-step entropy
change that curb explosion and prevent collapse. Empirically, this minimal
modification stabilizes entropy, sparsifies credit assignment (with tuned K,
roughly 80% of responses receive zero advantage), and yields sustained pass@1
gains on Qwen3-8B/14B-Base across AIME 2024/2025 and AMC 2023. These results
identify {baseline design} -- rather than token-level heuristics -- as the
primary mechanism for scaling RLVR.

</details>


### [325] [Nonlinear Optimization with GPU-Accelerated Neural Network Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22462)
*Robert Parker,Oscar Dowson,Nicole LoGiudice,Manuel Garcia,Russell Bent*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Reduced-space neural network optimization (gray-box) accelerates solver performance by not exposing intermediate variables; feasible for GPU-based evaluation and interior-point methods, demonstrated on MNIST adversarial generation and neural-surrogate security-constrained OPF.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Full-space formulations expose internal network variables and constraints to the optimizer, causing slower solves and more iterations. A reduced-space, gray-box approach keeps the network as a black box and evaluates outputs/derivatives on GPU to improve efficiency for optimization problems that incorporate trained neural networks.

Method: Develop a reduced-space formulation where the neural network is treated as a gray box; intermediate variables/constraints are not exposed to the solver. Network outputs and derivatives are evaluated on the GPU. Compare performance to full-space formulations using interior-point methods. Apply to two problems: (1) adversarial generation for an MNIST classifier, (2) security-constrained optimal power flow with a neural-network surrogate enforcing transient feasibility.

Result: The reduced-space formulation yields faster solves and fewer iterations than the full-space approach in an interior-point method. This benefit is demonstrated on two problems: MNIST-based adversarial generation and security-constrained OPF with a neural surrogate enforcing transient feasibility.

Conclusion: Treating trained neural networks as gray boxes in a reduced-space formulation is effective for optimization, enabling GPU-based evaluation and improved solver efficiency, with demonstrated gains on image-classification adversarial generation and power-system optimization problems.

Abstract: We propose a reduced-space formulation for optimizing over trained neural
networks where the network's outputs and derivatives are evaluated on a GPU. To
do this, we treat the neural network as a "gray box" where intermediate
variables and constraints are not exposed to the optimization solver. Compared
to the full-space formulation, in which intermediate variables and constraints
are exposed to the optimization solver, the reduced-space formulation leads to
faster solves and fewer iterations in an interior point method. We demonstrate
the benefits of this method on two optimization problems: Adversarial
generation for a classifier trained on MNIST images and security-constrained
optimal power flow with transient feasibility enforced using a neural network
surrogate.

</details>


### [326] [IA2: Alignment with ICL Activations Improves Supervised Fine-Tuning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22621)
*Aayush Mishra,Daniel Khashabi,Anqi Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: IA2 is a self-distillation priming method that aligns SFT models with ICL activation patterns, improving post-SFT accuracy and calibration across multiple benchmarks and model families.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: ICL can generalize well in data-scarce settings but incurs high inference cost; SFT and ICL adapt models via different internal mechanisms. Leveraging ICL's internal computations (activation patterns) could improve SFT performance.

Method: IA2 (ICL Activation Alignment) uses self-distillation to replicate ICL-like activation patterns in SFT models. It is applied as a priming step before SFT to encourage SFT models to adopt ICL-like internal reasoning.

Result: Using IA2 as a priming step before SFT significantly improves both accuracy and calibration on 12 benchmarks across 2 model families.

Conclusion: IA2 provides a practical method to boost SFT by borrowing ICL-like internal computations and offers a conceptual glimpse into the distinct mechanisms underlying model adaptation.

Abstract: Supervised Fine-Tuning (SFT) is used to specialize model behavior by training
weights to produce intended target responses for queries. In contrast,
In-Context Learning (ICL) adapts models during inference with instructions or
demonstrations in the prompt. ICL can offer better generalizability and more
calibrated responses compared to SFT in data scarce settings, at the cost of
more inference compute. In this work, we ask the question: Can ICL's internal
computations be used to improve the qualities of SFT? We first show that ICL
and SFT produce distinct activation patterns, indicating that the two methods
achieve adaptation through different functional mechanisms. Motivated by this
observation and to use ICL's rich functionality, we introduce ICL Activation
Alignment (IA2), a self-distillation technique which aims to replicate ICL's
activation patterns in SFT models and incentivizes ICL-like internal reasoning.
Performing IA2 as a priming step before SFT significantly improves the accuracy
and calibration of model outputs, as shown by our extensive empirical results
on 12 popular benchmarks and 2 model families. This finding is not only
practically useful, but also offers a conceptual window into the inner
mechanics of model adaptation.

</details>


### [327] [IIET: Efficient Numerical Transformer via Implicit Iterative Euler Method](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22463)
*Xinyu Liu,Bei Li,Jiahao Liu,Junhao Ruan,Kechen Jiao,Hongyin Tang,Jingang Wang,Xiao Tong,Jingbo Zhu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: IIET and IIAD offer an efficient, optimizable high-order Transformer framework that outperforms vanilla Transformers and PCformer, delivering notable accuracy gains and large reductions in inference cost with controllable trade-offs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: High-order numerical methods boost Transformer performance but bring substantial computational overhead; standard efficiency techniques like distillation may hurt such models; need an optimizable, efficient ODE-based Transformer architecture.

Method: Propose IIET (Iterative Implicit Euler Transformer) to simplify high-order methods via an iterative implicit Euler approach; introduce IIAD (Iteration Influence-Aware Distillation) to balance accuracy and efficiency; develop efficient variant E-IIET; evaluate on lm-evaluation-harness and compare to vanilla Transformers and PCformer.

Result: IIET increases average accuracy by 2.65% over vanilla Transformers and 0.8% over PCformer; E-IIET reduces inference overhead by 55% while preserving 99.4% of task accuracy; the most efficient IIET variant yields >1.6% average gain over vanilla with comparable speed.

Conclusion: IIET/IIAD enable superior performance-efficiency trade-offs for high-order Transformer architectures; distillation may be detrimental for such models; the iterative implicit Euler approach yields compression-friendly, faster models with robust accuracy improvements.

Abstract: High-order numerical methods enhance Transformer performance in tasks like
NLP and CV, but introduce a performance-efficiency trade-off due to increased
computational overhead. Our analysis reveals that conventional efficiency
techniques, such as distillation, can be detrimental to the performance of
these models, exemplified by PCformer. To explore more optimizable ODE-based
Transformer architectures, we propose the \textbf{I}terative \textbf{I}mplicit
\textbf{E}uler \textbf{T}ransformer \textbf{(IIET)}, which simplifies
high-order methods using an iterative implicit Euler approach. This
simplification not only leads to superior performance but also facilitates
model compression compared to PCformer. To enhance inference efficiency, we
introduce \textbf{I}teration \textbf{I}nfluence-\textbf{A}ware
\textbf{D}istillation \textbf{(IIAD)}. Through a flexible threshold, IIAD
allows users to effectively balance the performance-efficiency trade-off. On
lm-evaluation-harness, IIET boosts average accuracy by 2.65\% over vanilla
Transformers and 0.8\% over PCformer. Its efficient variant, E-IIET,
significantly cuts inference overhead by 55\% while retaining 99.4\% of the
original task accuracy. Moreover, the most efficient IIET variant achieves an
average performance gain exceeding 1.6\% over vanilla Transformer with
comparable speed.

</details>


### [328] [A Theoretical Analysis of Discrete Flow Matching Generative Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22623)
*Maojiang Su,Mingcheng Lu,Jerry Yao-Chieh Hu,Shang Wu,Zhao Song,Alex Reneau,Han Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A theoretical framework showing that end-to-end training of Discrete Flow Matching (DFM) yields distributions that converge to the true data distribution as training data grows, by bounding the generated distribution error via the risk of the learned velocity field and decomposing that risk into approximation (Transformer capacity) and estimation (finite-sample) errors.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To provide formal guarantees for discrete generative modeling with DFM, linking the learned velocity-field dynamics to distributional convergence and quantifying how model capacity and data size affect the outcome.

Method: Decompose the total variation distance between generated and target distributions into the risk of the learned velocity field. Bound this risk by (i) Approximation Error due to Transformer capacity in representing the true velocity, and (ii) Estimation Error due to finite-sample training. Combine these bounds to derive a formal convergence result showing TV distance → 0 as training data size grows.

Result: The paper provides the first formal proof that a trained DFM model's generated distribution converges to the true data distribution as the training set size increases, with explicit bounds arising from approximability of the velocity field and statistical estimation rates.

Conclusion: End-to-end DFM training is provably consistent: with sufficient data and appropriate Transformer capacity, the generated distribution converges to the true distribution. The analysis exposes the key drivers—model expressivity and data sufficiency—for practitioners and suggests avenues to optimize data utilization and architecture design.

Abstract: We provide a theoretical analysis for end-to-end training Discrete Flow
Matching (DFM) generative models. DFM is a promising discrete generative
modeling framework that learns the underlying generative dynamics by training a
neural network to approximate the transformative velocity field. Our analysis
establishes a clear chain of guarantees by decomposing the final distribution
estimation error. We first prove that the total variation distance between the
generated and target distributions is controlled by the risk of the learned
velocity field. We then bound this risk by analyzing its two primary sources:
(i) Approximation Error, where we quantify the capacity of the Transformer
architecture to represent the true velocity, and (ii) Estimation Error, where
we derive statistical convergence rates that bound the error from training on a
finite dataset. By composing these results, we provide the first formal proof
that the distribution generated by a trained DFM model provably converges to
the true data distribution as the training set size increases.

</details>


### [329] [Learning Admissible Heuristics for A*: Theory and Practice](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22626)
*Ehsan Futuhi,Nathan R. Sturtevant*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Cross-Entropy Admissibility (CEA) to train admissible heuristics, achieving near-admissible, better-guided heuristics on Rubik's Cube than PDBs, with theoretical sample-complexity and generalization guarantees for neural (ReLU) heuristics, including goal-dependent cases.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Admissible heuristics guarantee optimal A* solutions but deep learning often ignores admissibility, risking poor guarantees and generalization beyond training data. The work seeks to enforce admissibility during learning and to establish sample complexity and network-based generalization bounds.

Method: Formulates heuristic learning as constrained optimization using a Cross-Entropy Admissibility loss to enforce admissibility during training. Validates on Rubik's Cube with comparisons to compressed pattern databases. Theoretically analyzes sample complexity via PDB abstractions and graph structure; replaces the hypothesis class with ReLU networks to derive bounds depending on width/depth; provides generalization guarantees for goal-dependent heuristics.

Result: Near-admissible heuristics obtained with stronger guidance than PDB heuristics on Rubik's Cube. Tighter sample-complexity bounds for A*-generalization when using PDB abstractions and cube graph structure. Generalization guarantees for neural heuristics depend primarily on network size rather than graph size, and the authors derive the first such guarantees for goal-dependent heuristics.

Conclusion: CEA is a promising approach to enforce admissibility in learned heuristics, yielding better practical performance and solid theoretical generalization insights. The results connect structured abstractions (PDBs) with neural networks to achieve both strong guidance and provable guarantees for A*-search performance.

Abstract: Heuristic functions are central to the performance of search algorithms such
as A-star, where admissibility - the property of never overestimating the true
shortest-path cost - guarantees solution optimality. Recent deep learning
approaches often disregard admissibility and provide limited guarantees on
generalization beyond the training data. This paper addresses both of these
limitations. First, we pose heuristic learning as a constrained optimization
problem and introduce Cross-Entropy Admissibility (CEA), a loss function that
enforces admissibility during training. On the Rubik's Cube domain, this method
yields near-admissible heuristics with significantly stronger guidance than
compressed pattern database (PDB) heuristics. Theoretically, we study the
sample complexity of learning heuristics. By leveraging PDB abstractions and
the structural properties of graphs such as the Rubik's Cube, we tighten the
bound on the number of training samples needed for A-star to generalize.
Replacing a general hypothesis class with a ReLU neural network gives bounds
that depend primarily on the network's width and depth, rather than on graph
size. Using the same network, we also provide the first generalization
guarantees for goal-dependent heuristics.

</details>


### [330] [Bayesian Transfer Operators in Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22482)
*Septimus Boshoff,Sebastian Peitz,Stefan Klus*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Unifies Gaussian process regression with dynamic mode decomposition to address scalability and hyperparameter/dictionary learning in kernel-based Koopman methods, improving noise robustness and computational efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: The Koopman operator provides a linear framework for nonlinear dynamics, but kernel-based approaches suffer from poor scalability (sparsity) and require careful hyperparameter tuning and dictionary learning. Integrating Gaussian process regression offers probabilistic modeling and automatic regularization to address these issues.

Method: Proposes a GP-based Koopman/DMD framework that uses Gaussian process regression to estimate Koopman operators or modes from data, enabling compact representations and learning of hyperparameters and dictionary elements within the DMD/Koopman setting.

Result: The approach reduces computational demands and enhances resilience to sensor noise, with improved adaptation through data-driven hyperparameter and dictionary learning.

Conclusion: Unifying GP regression with dynamic mode decomposition yields a scalable, noise-robust kernel-based Koopman analysis framework.

Abstract: The Koopman operator, as a linear representation of a nonlinear dynamical
system, has been attracting attention in many fields of science. Recently,
Koopman operator theory has been combined with another concept that is popular
in data science: reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces. We follow this thread into
Gaussian process methods, and illustrate how these methods can alleviate two
pervasive problems with kernel-based Koopman algorithms. The first being
sparsity: most kernel methods do not scale well and require an approximation to
become practical. We show that not only can the computational demands be
reduced, but also demonstrate improved resilience against sensor noise. The
second problem involves hyperparameter optimization and dictionary learning to
adapt the model to the dynamical system. In summary, the main contribution of
this work is the unification of Gaussian process regression and dynamic mode
decomposition.

</details>


### [331] [Dual Optimistic Ascent (PI Control) is the Augmented Lagrangian Method in Disguise](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22500)
*Juan Ramirez,Simon Lacoste-Julien*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Establishes equivalence between dual optimistic ascent on the standard Lagrangian and gradient-descent-ascent on the Augmented Lagrangian, enabling ALM guarantees for optimistic dual methods and showing linear convergence to all local solutions with guidance for tuning the optimism hyper-parameter.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Constrained optimization is a powerful tool for enforcing neural-network requirements. Existing first-order min-max Lagrangian methods suffer from oscillations and may miss some local solutions. Although Augmented Lagrangian methods (ALM) address these issues, practitioners favor dual optimistic ascent (PI control) on the standard Lagrangian, which works well empirically but lacks formal guarantees.

Method: The paper proves a previously unknown equivalence: dual optimistic ascent on the Lagrangian is equivalent to gradient-descent-ascent on the Augmented Lagrangian. This allows transferring ALM’s robust convergence guarantees to the dual optimistic setting, leading to linear convergence to all local solutions and yielding principled guidance for tuning the optimism hyper-parameter.

Result: Proves linear convergence of dual optimistic methods to all local solutions by leveraging ALM guarantees; establishes a rigorous equivalence to justify PI control as a surrogate for ALM; provides guidelines for tuning the optimism parameter.

Conclusion: Bridges the empirical success of dual optimistic methods with rigorous theory, offering a principled framework for constrained DL and enabling reliable convergence guarantees for popular dual-optimistic schemes.

Abstract: Constrained optimization is a powerful framework for enforcing requirements
on neural networks. These constrained deep learning problems are typically
solved using first-order methods on their min-max Lagrangian formulation, but
such approaches often suffer from oscillations and can fail to find all local
solutions. While the Augmented Lagrangian method (ALM) addresses these issues,
practitioners often favor dual optimistic ascent schemes (PI control) on the
standard Lagrangian, which perform well empirically but lack formal guarantees.
In this paper, we establish a previously unknown equivalence between these
approaches: dual optimistic ascent on the Lagrangian is equivalent to gradient
descent-ascent on the Augmented Lagrangian. This finding allows us to transfer
the robust theoretical guarantees of the ALM to the dual optimistic setting,
proving it converges linearly to all local solutions. Furthermore, the
equivalence provides principled guidance for tuning the optimism
hyper-parameter. Our work closes a critical gap between the empirical success
of dual optimistic methods and their theoretical foundation.

</details>


### [332] [Adaptive Dual-Mode Distillation with Incentive Schemes for Scalable, Heterogeneous Federated Learning on Non-IID Data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22507)
*Zahid Iqbal*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes DL-SH, DL-MH, and I-DL-MH to address client heterogeneity and non-IID data in Federated Learning, plus incentives for participation; reports strong empirical gains over baselines in varied datasets and model architectures.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address core FL challenges: (1) some clients cannot train the same models due to resource/needs; (2) statistical heterogeneity (non-IID data) reduces global performance; (3) need for cost-effective incentives to encourage client participation.

Method: Introduce DL-SH for efficient, privacy-preserving, and communication-efficient learning under heterogeneity; DL-MH to manage fully heterogeneous models; I-DL-MH extends DL-MH with incentives to boost client engagement within FL; comprehensive experiments across IID and multiple non-IID distributions, diverse datasets and model architectures.

Result: Significant performance gains and reduced communication costs; DL-SH yields up to 153% improvement in global accuracy; I-DL-MH yields up to 225% improvement under non-IID conditions; outperforms current state-of-the-art baselines.

Conclusion: The proposed DL-SH, DL-MH, and I-DL-MH effectively tackle heterogeneity and incentivize participation in Federated Learning, showing strong empirical performance across varied settings.

Abstract: Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a promising decentralized learning
(DL) approach that enables the use of distributed data without compromising
user privacy. However, FL poses several key challenges. First, it is frequently
assumed that every client can train the same machine learning models, however,
not all clients are able to meet this assumption because of differences in
their business needs and computational resources. Second, statistical
heterogeneity (a.k.a. non-IID data) poses a major challenge in FL, which can
lead to lower global model performance. Third, while addressing these
challenges, there is a need for a cost-effective incentive mechanism to
encourage clients to participate in FL training. In response to these
challenges, we propose several methodologies: DL-SH, which facilitates
efficient, privacy-preserving, and communication-efficient learning in the
context of statistical heterogeneity; DL-MH, designed to manage fully
heterogeneous models while tackling statistical disparities; and I-DL-MH, an
incentive-based extension of DL-MH that promotes client engagement in federated
learning training by providing incentives within this complex federated
learning framework. Comprehensive experiments were carried out to assess the
performance and scalability of the proposed approaches across a range of
complex experimental settings. This involved utilizing various model
architectures, in diverse data distributions, including IID and several non-IID
scenarios, as well as multiple datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that
the proposed approaches significantly enhance accuracy and decrease
communication costs while effectively addressing statistical heterogeneity and
model heterogeneity in comparison to existing state-of-the-art approaches and
baselines, with DL-SH improving global model accuracy by 153%, and I-DL-MH
achieving a 225% improvement under non-IID conditions.

</details>


### [333] [JointDiff: Bridging Continuous and Discrete in Multi-Agent Trajectory Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22522)
*Guillem Capellera,Luis Ferraz,Antonio Rubio,Alexandre Alahi,Antonio Agudo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: JointDiff unifies continuous spatio-temporal data and synchronous discrete events in a diffusion framework to jointly generate trajectories and events, with cross-domain conditioning (CrossGuid) and controllable generation via weak-possessor-guidance and text guidance; introduces a unified sports benchmark with textual annotations; achieves state-of-the-art results in joint modeling for interactive systems.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional generative models treat continuous data and discrete events separately, creating a gap in accurately modeling interactive, multi-agent systems where these modalities co-evolve (e.g., sports plays with ball possessions). A joint model promises more realistic, controllable generation and better downstream utility.

Method: Proposes JointDiff, a diffusion-based framework that jointly models continuous spatio-temporal trajectories and synchronous discrete events. Introduces CrossGuid conditioning for multi-agent domains, plus two controllable generation schemes: weak-possessor-guidance (specifying intended ball possessors) and text-guidance (language-driven conditioning). Provides a unified sports benchmark enhanced with textual descriptions for soccer/football datasets.

Result: JointDiff achieves state-of-the-art performance on the proposed joint-modeling task, demonstrating effective non-controllable generation and two controllable modes. The CrossGuid conditioning and guidance signals enable fine-grained control over game dynamics, and the unified benchmark supports richer evaluation with textual descriptions.

Conclusion: Joint modeling of continuous and discrete modalities is crucial for realistic and controllable generative models in interactive systems like sports. The JointDiff framework, with its CrossGuid conditioning and guidance mechanisms, offers a versatile approach likely extensible to other multi-agent domains with combined modalities.

Abstract: Generative models often treat continuous data and discrete events as separate
processes, creating a gap in modeling complex systems where they interact
synchronously. To bridge this gap, we introduce JointDiff, a novel diffusion
framework designed to unify these two processes by simultaneously generating
continuous spatio-temporal data and synchronous discrete events. We demonstrate
its efficacy in the sports domain by simultaneously modeling multi-agent
trajectories and key possession events. This joint modeling is validated with
non-controllable generation and two novel controllable generation scenarios:
weak-possessor-guidance, which offers flexible semantic control over game
dynamics through a simple list of intended ball possessors, and text-guidance,
which enables fine-grained, language-driven generation. To enable the
conditioning with these guidance signals, we introduce CrossGuid, an effective
conditioning operation for multi-agent domains. We also share a new unified
sports benchmark enhanced with textual descriptions for soccer and football
datasets. JointDiff achieves state-of-the-art performance, demonstrating that
joint modeling is crucial for building realistic and controllable generative
models for interactive systems.

</details>


### [334] [ECHO: Toward Contextual Seq2Seq Paradigms in Large EEG Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22556)
*Chenyu Liu,Yuqiu Deng,Tianyu Liu,Jinan Zhou,Xinliang Zhou,Ziyu Jia,Yi Ding*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ECHO introduces a decoder-centric Large EEG Model that uses sequence-to-sequence learning with in-context learning and discrete support samples to enable cross-task generalization without parameter updates, outperforming single-task LEMs in multi-task settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current large EEG models are encoder-centric and miss decoders of comparable capacity, limiting full utilization of learned representations and cross-task adaptability across diverse datasets.

Method: Propose ECHO, a decoder-centric LEM paradigm that reframes EEG modeling as sequence-to-sequence learning, modeling layered relationships among signals, labels, and tasks in sequence space, and using discrete support samples to provide contextual cues for in-context learning.

Result: Empirical evaluations across multiple datasets show ECHO consistently outperforms state-of-the-art single-task LEMs in multi-task settings, with improved generalization and adaptability even when using basic model components.

Conclusion: Decoder-centric LEMs like ECHO can better exploit learned features for flexible, cross-task EEG modeling without parameter updates, achieving robust generalization across tasks and datasets.

Abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG), with its broad range of applications,
necessitates models that can generalize effectively across various tasks and
datasets. Large EEG Models (LEMs) address this by pretraining encoder-centric
architectures on large-scale unlabeled data to extract universal
representations. While effective, these models lack decoders of comparable
capacity, limiting the full utilization of the learned features. To address
this issue, we introduce ECHO, a novel decoder-centric LEM paradigm that
reformulates EEG modeling as sequence-to-sequence learning. ECHO captures
layered relationships among signals, labels, and tasks within sequence space,
while incorporating discrete support samples to construct contextual cues. This
design equips ECHO with in-context learning, enabling dynamic adaptation to
heterogeneous tasks without parameter updates. Extensive experiments across
multiple datasets demonstrate that, even with basic model components, ECHO
consistently outperforms state-of-the-art single-task LEMs in multi-task
settings, showing superior generalization and adaptability.

</details>


### [335] [Learning to Price Bundles: A GCN Approach for Mixed Bundling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22557)
*Liangyu Ding,Chenghan Wu,Guokai Li,Zizhuo Wang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A graph convolutional network (GCN) framework is proposed to solve bundle pricing by learning from a graph representation of the mixed bundling model; it yields near-optimal solutions with substantial computational savings and scales to 30+ products, even with non-additive utilities.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bundle pricing is intractable due to the exponential number of candidate bundles; graph-based learning can capture structural patterns to guide pricing decisions and improve solution quality and efficiency over traditional methods.

Method: Build a graph representation of the mixed bundling model (all possible bundles with prices). Train a GCN to learn latent patterns of optimal bundles. Use two inference strategies to derive high-quality feasible solutions from the GCN outputs. Apply a local-search refinement to further improve solutions. Evaluate on instances from small to large sizes, including non-additive utilities.

Result: The GCN-based approach consistently delivers near-optimal solutions (better than 97% of the optimum) on small instances with significantly lower computation. It outperforms other heuristics like BSP on larger instances and provides high-quality solutions for problems with more than 30 products, including non-additive utilities.

Conclusion: A GCN-based framework is effective for bundle pricing, delivering high-quality solutions with reduced computation and good scalability across instance sizes and utility structures.

Abstract: Bundle pricing refers to designing several product combinations (i.e.,
bundles) and determining their prices in order to maximize the expected profit.
It is a classic problem in revenue management and arises in many industries,
such as e-commerce, tourism, and video games. However, the problem is typically
intractable due to the exponential number of candidate bundles. In this paper,
we explore the usage of graph convolutional networks (GCNs) in solving the
bundle pricing problem. Specifically, we first develop a graph representation
of the mixed bundling model (where every possible bundle is assigned with a
specific price) and then train a GCN to learn the latent patterns of optimal
bundles. Based on the trained GCN, we propose two inference strategies to
derive high-quality feasible solutions. A local-search technique is further
proposed to improve the solution quality. Numerical experiments validate the
effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed GCN-based framework. Using a GCN
trained on instances with 5 products, our methods consistently achieve
near-optimal solutions (better than 97%) with only a fraction of computational
time for problems of small to medium size. It also achieves superior solutions
for larger size of problems compared with other heuristic methods such as
bundle size pricing (BSP). The method can also provide high quality solutions
for instances with more than 30 products even for the challenging cases where
product utilities are non-additive.

</details>


### [336] [Machine learning approaches to seismic event classification in the Ostrava region](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22574)
*Marek Pecha,Michael Skotnica,Jana Rušajová,Bohdan Rieznikov,Vít Wandrol,Markéta Rösnerová,Jaromír Knejzlík*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Machine learning (LSTM and XGBoost) applied to the SPF seismic dataset (1992–2002) to distinguish tectonic vs mining-induced events, achieving high binary-classification F1 scores (~0.94–0.95).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In seismically active mining regions, rapid differentiation between tectonic and anthropogenic events is crucial for monitoring, safety, and interpretation of seismic data. The SPF dataset provides labeled examples to train such discriminators.

Method: Apply sequence-based and gradient-boosted tree models to the SPF dataset of five-station, STA/LTA-triggered seismic records with labeled tectonic and mining-induced events. Specifically, use Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) recurrent neural networks and XGBoost for binary classification (tectonic vs mining-induced).

Result: LSTM and XGBoost achieved F1-scores of 0.94–0.95 on binary classification, demonstrating strong performance of modern ML techniques for rapid event characterization in this region.

Conclusion: ML approaches can effectively discriminate tectonic versus mining-induced seismic events in near real-time, offering valuable support for seismic networks monitoring mining-impacted regions and improving rapid event characterization.

Abstract: The northeastern region of the Czech Republic is among the most seismically
active areas in the country. The most frequent seismic events are
mining-induced since there used to be strong mining activity in the past.
However, natural tectonic events may also occur. In addition, seismic stations
often record explosions in quarries in the region. Despite the cessation of
mining activities, mine-induced seismic events still occur. Therefore, a rapid
differentiation between tectonic and anthropogenic events is still important.
  The region is currently monitored by the OKC seismic station in
Ostrava-Kr\'{a}sn\'{e} Pole built in 1983 which is a part of the Czech Regional
Seismic Network. The station has been providing digital continuous waveform
data at 100 Hz since 2007. In the years 1992--2002, the region was co-monitored
by the Seismic Polygon Fren\v{s}t\'{a}t (SPF) which consisted of five seismic
stations using a triggered STA/LTA system.
  In this study, we apply and compare machine learning methods to the SPF
dataset, which contains labeled records of tectonic and mining-induced events.
For binary classification, a Long Short-Term Memory recurrent neural network
and XGBoost achieved an F1-score of 0.94 -- 0.95, demonstrating the potential
of modern machine learning techniques for rapid event characterization.

</details>


### [337] [EPO: Entropy-regularized Policy Optimization for LLM Agents Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22576)
*Xu Wujiang,Wentian Zhao,Zhenting Wang,Li Yu-Jhe,Jin Can,Jin Mingyu,Mei Kai,Wan Kun,Metaxas Dimitris*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes Entropy-regularized Policy Optimization (EPO) to tackle the exploration-exploitation cascade in multi-turn, sparse-reward RL for LLM agents. It introduces three mechanisms—entropy regularization for multi-turn exploration, entropy smoothing to bound entropy fluctuations, and adaptive phase-based weighting—to ensure stable learning and monotonic entropy variance, reporting substantial gains on ScienceWorld and ALFWorld.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Training LLM agents in multi-turn environments with sparse rewards leads to an exploration-exploitation cascade: early premature convergence to low-entropy strategies, followed by late-stage policy collapse where traditional entropy regularization destabilizes training. A new entropy-control framework is needed for robust learning in such settings.

Method: Entropy-regularized Policy Optimization (EPO) framework combining: (1) entropy regularization adapted to multi-turn episodes to encourage exploration; (2) an entropy smoothing regularizer that constrains policy entropy within historical averages to avoid abrupt shifts; (3) adaptive phase-based weighting that modulates exploration-exploitation balance across training phases.

Result: The authors claim monotonic decrease in entropy variance with guaranteed convergence. Empirical gains include up to 152% performance improvement on ScienceWorld and up to 19.8% on ALFWorld.

Conclusion: Multi-turn sparse-reward RL for LLM agents requires distinct entropy-control strategies from traditional RL. EPO's combination of per-turn entropy, smoothing, and phase-aware weighting can stabilize training and improve performance in such settings.

Abstract: Training LLM agents in multi-turn environments with sparse rewards, where
completing a single task requires 30+ turns of interaction within an episode,
presents a fundamental challenge for reinforcement learning. We identify a
critical failure mode unique to this setting: the exploration-exploitation
cascade failure. This cascade begins with early-stage policy premature
convergence, where sparse feedback causes agents to commit to flawed,
low-entropy strategies. Subsequently, agents enter late-stage policy collapse,
where conventional entropy regularization becomes counterproductive, promoting
chaotic exploration that destabilizes training. We propose Entropy-regularized
Policy Optimization (EPO), a general framework that breaks this failure cycle
through three synergistic mechanisms: (1) adopting entropy regularization in
multi-turn settings to enhance exploration, (2) an entropy smoothing
regularizer that bounds policy entropy within historical averages to prevent
abrupt fluctuations, and (3) adaptive phase-based weighting that balances
exploration and exploitation across training. Our analysis justifies that EPO
guarantees monotonically decreasing entropy variance while maintaining
convergence. EPO achieves up to 152% performance improvement on ScienceWorld
and up to 19.8% on ALFWorld. Our work demonstrates that multi-turn
sparse-reward settings require fundamentally different entropy control than
traditional RL, with broad implications for LLM agent training.

</details>


### [338] [The Lie of the Average: How Class Incremental Learning Evaluation Deceives You?](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22580)
*Guannan Lai,Da-Wei Zhou,Xin Yang,Han-Jia Ye*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: EDGE is an evaluation protocol for Class Incremental Learning (CIL) that targets extreme class sequences to better characterize the full performance distribution, using inter-task similarity to adaptively sample these extremes and provide more accurate distributional bounds than standard random-sequence evaluation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Standard CIL evaluation using random sequences biases performance estimates, underestimates variance, and fails to reflect worst-case scenarios across sequences. There is a need to understand the full distribution of model performance over all possible class orderings, including extreme sequences.

Method: Introduce EDGE (Extreme case-based Distribution and Generalization Evaluation). The protocol theoretically justifies the importance of extreme sequences, shows a positive correlation between inter-task similarity and performance, and adaptively identifies and samples extreme class sequences using inter-task similarity to approximate the ground-truth performance distribution.

Result: Extensive experiments demonstrate that EDGE captures performance extremes and yields more accurate estimates of distributional boundaries, improving insights for model selection and robustness checking; code is released at the provided URL.

Conclusion: Robust CIL evaluation requires characterizing the entire performance distribution. Extreme sequences are crucial for reliable assessment, and EDGE provides a practical protocol to identify and sample them adaptively, offering closer approximation to ground-truth distribution and actionable guidance for practitioners.

Abstract: Class Incremental Learning (CIL) requires models to continuously learn new
classes without forgetting previously learned ones, while maintaining stable
performance across all possible class sequences. In real-world settings, the
order in which classes arrive is diverse and unpredictable, and model
performance can vary substantially across different sequences. Yet mainstream
evaluation protocols calculate mean and variance from only a small set of
randomly sampled sequences. Our theoretical analysis and empirical results
demonstrate that this sampling strategy fails to capture the full performance
range, resulting in biased mean estimates and a severe underestimation of the
true variance in the performance distribution. We therefore contend that a
robust CIL evaluation protocol should accurately characterize and estimate the
entire performance distribution. To this end, we introduce the concept of
extreme sequences and provide theoretical justification for their crucial role
in the reliable evaluation of CIL. Moreover, we observe a consistent positive
correlation between inter-task similarity and model performance, a relation
that can be leveraged to guide the search for extreme sequences. Building on
these insights, we propose EDGE (Extreme case-based Distribution and
Generalization Evaluation), an evaluation protocol that adaptively identifies
and samples extreme class sequences using inter-task similarity, offering a
closer approximation of the ground-truth performance distribution. Extensive
experiments demonstrate that EDGE effectively captures performance extremes and
yields more accurate estimates of distributional boundaries, providing
actionable insights for model selection and robustness checking. Our code is
available at https://github.com/AIGNLAI/EDGE.

</details>


### [339] [Transport Based Mean Flows for Generative Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.22592)
*Elaheh Akbari,Ping He,Ahmadreza Moradipari,Yikun Bai,Soheil Kolouri*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: One-step flow-matching with optimal transport improves fidelity and diversity for continuous-data generation, enabling faster inference without sacrificing performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Flow-matching models are powerful but slow due to sequential sampling; while Mean Flows reduce steps, they may not faithfully replicate the original multi-step process in many continuous domains. There is a need to retain fidelity and diversity while speeding up inference.

Method: Incorporate optimal transport-based sampling strategies into the Mean Flow framework to align one-step generation with the distribution of multi-step flow-matching trajectories.

Result: Demonstrates superior one-step inference accuracy in both controlled low-dimensional settings and high-dimensional tasks, including image generation, image-to-image translation, and point cloud generation. The approach preserves fidelity and diversity relative to the original process.

Conclusion: OT-enabled Mean Flows offer a practical, high-fidelity, and faster one-step generative modeling approach across diverse continuous domains.

Abstract: Flow-matching generative models have emerged as a powerful paradigm for
continuous data generation, achieving state-of-the-art results across domains
such as images, 3D shapes, and point clouds. Despite their success, these
models suffer from slow inference due to the requirement of numerous sequential
sampling steps. Recent work has sought to accelerate inference by reducing the
number of sampling steps. In particular, Mean Flows offer a one-step generation
approach that delivers substantial speedups while retaining strong generative
performance. Yet, in many continuous domains, Mean Flows fail to faithfully
approximate the behavior of the original multi-step flow-matching process. In
this work, we address this limitation by incorporating optimal transport-based
sampling strategies into the Mean Flow framework, enabling one-step generators
that better preserve the fidelity and diversity of the original multi-step flow
process. Experiments on controlled low-dimensional settings and on
high-dimensional tasks such as image generation, image-to-image translation,
and point cloud generation demonstrate that our approach achieves superior
inference accuracy in one-step generative modeling.

</details>


<div id='cs.CG'></div>

# cs.CG [[Back]](#toc)

### [340] [Algorithms for Dynamic Computational Geometry with Applications](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21681)
*Laurence Boxer*

Main category: cs.CG

TL;DR: Dynamic computational geometry extends classical CG to moving point-sets, tracing back to M.J. Atallah who introduced it. The field appears dormant; this paper seeks to revive it by examining new problems in dynamic CG.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Static computational geometry dominates the literature; there is a need to understand both momentary and long-term geometric properties of moving objects, to broaden CG to dynamic settings and stimulate renewed research in the area.

Method: A conceptual examination that identifies and formulates new problems in dynamic computational geometry; no empirical results are provided in the abstract.

Result: The paper identifies and frames new problems in dynamic CG; specific results are not reported in the abstract.

Conclusion: Dynamic CG remains a promising and underexplored area; the work aims to rekindle interest by proposing new problems for future study.

Abstract: Most of the literature of computational geometry concerns geometric
properties of sets of static points. M.J. Atallah introduced dynamic
computational geometry, concerned with both momentary and long-term geometric
properties of sets of moving point-objects. This area of research seems to have
been dormant recently. The current paper examines new problems in dynamic
computational geometry.

</details>


<div id='cs.RO'></div>

# cs.RO [[Back]](#toc)

### [341] [Language-in-the-Loop Culvert Inspection on the Erie Canal](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21370)
*Yashom Dighe,Yash Turkar,Karthik Dantu*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: End-to-end language-in-the-loop system (VISION) for autonomous culvert inspection using a vision-language model to propose ROIs with rationales, fused stereo depth for scale, and a constrained planner to reposition for close-ups; deployed on a canal-culvert quadruped; external eval shows 61.4% initial ROI agreement with experts and 80% after re-imaging.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Automate dangerous, geometry-challenging culvert inspections to improve safety and efficiency, leveraging open-vocabulary VLMs and planning without domain-specific fine-tuning.

Method: Prompt a vision-language model to generate ROI proposals with rationales and confidences; fuse stereo depth to recover scale; use a planner aware of culvert constraints to command repositioning moves for targeted close-ups; onboard see-decide-move-reimage loop; deploy on a quadruped in a culvert; produce high-resolution images for reporting without fine-tuning.

Result: External evaluation by NY Canal Corporation: initial ROI proposals agreed with subject-matter experts at 61.4%, final post-re-imaging assessments reached 80% agreement; system operates end-to-end on-board, delivering detailed images for reporting without domain-specific fine-tuning.

Conclusion: VISION demonstrates that language-informed perception combined with constrained planning can yield expert-aligned, grounded findings for infrastructure inspection in challenging environments, with potential generalization to similar inspection tasks beyond culverts.

Abstract: Culverts on canals such as the Erie Canal, built originally in 1825, require
frequent inspections to ensure safe operation. Human inspection of culverts is
challenging due to age, geometry, poor illumination, weather, and lack of easy
access. We introduce VISION, an end-to-end, language-in-the-loop autonomy
system that couples a web-scale vision-language model (VLM) with constrained
viewpoint planning for autonomous inspection of culverts. Brief prompts to the
VLM solicit open-vocabulary ROI proposals with rationales and confidences,
stereo depth is fused to recover scale, and a planner -- aware of culvert
constraints -- commands repositioning moves to capture targeted close-ups.
Deployed on a quadruped in a culvert under the Erie Canal, VISION closes the
see, decide, move, re-image loop on-board and produces high-resolution images
for detailed reporting without domain-specific fine-tuning. In an external
evaluation by New York Canal Corporation personnel, initial ROI proposals
achieved 61.4\% agreement with subject-matter experts, and final
post-re-imaging assessments reached 80\%, indicating that VISION converts
tentative hypotheses into grounded, expert-aligned findings.

</details>


### [342] [Developing a Mono-Actuated Compliant GeoGami Robot](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21445)
*Archie Webster,Lee Skull,Seyed Amir Tafrishi*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Mono-actuated soft-rigid robot GeoGami uses origami surfaces with a compliant skeleton to enable shape-changing locomotion with a single actuator.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Reduce actuator count and improve repeatability in origami-based robots with high DOF by integrating surface compliance and a mono-actuated design; enable environment-adaptive locomotion.

Method: Design a GeoGami platform combining origami surface compliance with a geometric compliant skeleton, driven by a single actuator via a central gearbox; analyze alternative cable-driven actuation; develop a stiffness model; demonstrate shape transformation and rolling.

Result: Prototype demonstration of shape transformation and locomotion; stiffness model; description of gearbox; evaluation of surface transformation and rolling capabilities; analysis of alternative actuation methods.

Conclusion: GeoGami enables shape-changing locomotion with reduced actuation, expanding capabilities of soft-robotic platforms to access varied environments; suggests a path toward underactuated, adaptable robots.

Abstract: This paper presents the design of a new soft-rigid robotic platform,
"GeoGami". We leverage origami surface capabilities to achieve shape
contraction and to support locomotion with underactuated forms. A key challenge
is that origami surfaces have high degrees of freedom and typically require
many actuators; we address repeatability by integrating surface compliance. We
propose a mono-actuated GeoGami mobile platform that combines origami surface
compliance with a geometric compliant skeleton, enabling the robot to transform
and locomote using a single actuator. We demonstrate the robot, develop a
stiffness model, and describe the central gearbox mechanism. We also analyze
alternative cable-driven actuation methods for the skeleton to enable surface
transformation. Finally, we evaluate the GeoGami platform for capabilities,
including shape transformation and rolling. This platform opens new
capabilities for robots that change shape to access different environments and
that use shape transformation for locomotion.

</details>


### [343] [Wall Inspector: Quadrotor Control in Wall-proximity Through Model Compensation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21496)
*Peiwen Yang,Weisong Wen,Runqiu Yang,Yingming Chen,Cheuk Chi Tsang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A suction-force model is developed for wall-proximity effects on quadrotors and a suction-compensated MPC (SC-MPC) is proposed to maintain accurate, stable trajectory tracking; validated experimentally with significant performance gains and open-sourced.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Near-wall flight incurs unmodeled aerodynamic effects (vortices and suction) that destabilize quadrotors and increase collision risk; existing controllers struggle to compensate for wall-induced disturbances.

Method: 1) Develop a physics-based suction force model dependent on rotor speed and wall distance. 2) Formulate SC-MPC as a factor-graph optimization that integrates system dynamics, trajectory tracking goals, input smoothness, and actuator limits. 3) Identify model parameters via extensive experiments across varying conditions. 4) Validate on a ducted quadrotor platform and provide open-source implementation.

Result: SC-MPC achieves RMSE of 2.1 cm (X) and 2.0 cm (Y) for position; improvements of 74% (X) and 79% (Y) over cascaded PID, and 60% (X) and 53% (Y) over standard MPC. MAE of 1.2 cm (X) and 1.4 cm (Y). Demonstrated on a ducted quadrotor with collision protection; implementation released publicly at the provided link.

Conclusion: A physics-based suction model combined with SC-MPC substantially improves safe, precise wall-proximity flights and offers a reproducible resource for the community through open-source release.

Abstract: The safe operation of quadrotors in near-wall urban or indoor environments
(e.g., inspection and search-and-rescue missions) is challenged by unmodeled
aerodynamic effects arising from wall-proximity. It generates complex vortices
that induce destabilizing suction forces, potentially leading to hazardous
vibrations or collisions. This paper presents a comprehensive solution
featuring (1) a physics-based suction force model that explicitly characterizes
the dependency on both rotor speed and wall distance, and (2) a
suction-compensated model predictive control (SC-MPC) framework designed to
ensure accurate and stable trajectory tracking during wall-proximity
operations. The proposed SC-MPC framework incorporates an enhanced dynamics
model that accounts for suction force effects, formulated as a factor graph
optimization problem integrating system dynamics constraints, trajectory
tracking objectives, control input smoothness requirements, and actuator
physical limitations. The suction force model parameters are systematically
identified through extensive experimental measurements across varying
operational conditions. Experimental validation demonstrates SC-MPC's superior
performance, achieving 2.1 cm root mean squared error (RMSE) in X-axis and 2.0
cm RMSE in Y-axis position control - representing 74% and 79% improvements over
cascaded proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control, and 60% and 53%
improvements over standard MPC respectively. The corresponding mean absolute
error (MAE) metrics (1.2 cm X-axis, 1.4 cm Y-axis) similarly outperform both
baselines. The evaluation platform employs a ducted quadrotor design that
provides collision protection while maintaining aerodynamic efficiency. To
facilitate reproducibility and community adoption, we have open-sourced our
complete implementation, available at
https://anonymous.4open.science/r/SC-MPC-6A61.

</details>


### [344] [DroneFL: Federated Learning for Multi-UAV Visual Target Tracking](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21523)
*Xiaofan Yu,Yuwei Wu,Katherine Mao,Ye Tian,Vijay Kumar,Tajana Rosing*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: DroneFL is a lightweight federated learning framework for multi-UAV target tracking that uses a frozen YOLO backbone and a shallow transformer, with altitude-based adaptive instance normalization, enabling real-time onboard operation and cloud-level model fusion to improve tracking accuracy and efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Multi-UAV target tracking faces resource constraints, heterogeneous data due to differing targets and fields of view, and tight coupling between trajectory prediction and planning. Federated learning promises distributed learning without centralizing data, but remains underexplored for this domain. DroneFL addresses these gaps.

Method: Design a lightweight local model: a frozen YOLO backbone plus a shallow transformer for onboard training. Periodic cloud aggregation to share global models. Introduce a position-invariant architecture with altitude-based adaptive instance normalization to mitigate data heterogeneity. In the cloud, fuse predictions from multiple UAVs and compute optimal trajectories balancing target prediction accuracy and tracking performance. Realizes real-time operation on a Raspberry Pi 5 and maintains a low cloud data rate (~1.56 KBps).

Result: Compared with a distributed non-FL baseline, DroneFL reduces target prediction error by 6%–83% and tracking distance by 0.4%–4.6%. It runs in real time on a Raspberry Pi 5 and maintains an average cloud data rate of about 1.56 KBps.

Conclusion: DroneFL demonstrates the feasibility and practical gains of applying federated learning to coordinated multi-UAV target tracking, delivering improved prediction and tracking with limited onboard resources. Future work could address greater data heterogeneity, scalability, and robustness in diverse, dynamic environments.

Abstract: Multi-robot target tracking is a fundamental problem that requires
coordinated monitoring of dynamic entities in applications such as precision
agriculture, environmental monitoring, disaster response, and security
surveillance. While Federated Learning (FL) has the potential to enhance
learning across multiple robots without centralized data aggregation, its use
in multi-Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) target tracking remains largely
underexplored. Key challenges include limited onboard computational resources,
significant data heterogeneity in FL due to varying targets and the fields of
view, and the need for tight coupling between trajectory prediction and
multi-robot planning. In this paper, we introduce DroneFL, the first federated
learning framework specifically designed for efficient multi-UAV target
tracking. We design a lightweight local model to predict target trajectories
from sensor inputs, using a frozen YOLO backbone and a shallow transformer for
efficient onboard training. The updated models are periodically aggregated in
the cloud for global knowledge sharing. To alleviate the data heterogeneity
that hinders FL convergence, DroneFL introduces a position-invariant model
architecture with altitude-based adaptive instance normalization. Finally, we
fuse predictions from multiple UAVs in the cloud and generate optimal
trajectories that balance target prediction accuracy and overall tracking
performance. Our results show that DroneFL reduces prediction error by 6%-83%
and tracking distance by 0.4%-4.6% compared to a distributed non-FL framework.
In terms of efficiency, DroneFL runs in real time on a Raspberry Pi 5 and has
on average just 1.56 KBps data rate to the cloud.

</details>


### [345] [Plan2Evolve: LLM Self-Evolution for Improved Planning Capability via Automated Domain Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21543)
*Jinbang Huang,Zhiyuan Li,Zhanguang Zhang,Xingyue Quan,Jianye Hao,Yingxue Zhang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Plan2Evolve is an LLM self-evolving framework where the model generates planning domains to produce symbolic problem-plan traces, converts these into extended CoT explanations, and uses the resulting data to fine-tune a planning-enhanced LLM with better planning success, generalization, and lower inference costs.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses limitation where planning domains are viewed only as search utilities and CoT data is costly; seeks scalable, self-generated reasoning data to improve planning and generalization.

Method: Base model generates planning domains; these domains act as engines to produce symbolic problem-plan traces (reasoning traces). The model then expands these traces into natural-language extended CoT trajectories, aligning symbolic structures with natural language reasoning, and uses the data to fine-tune the model.

Result: Data enable fine-tuning to yield improved planning success, stronger cross-task generalization, and reduced inference costs.

Conclusion: Plan2Evolve demonstrates a self-evolving loop that expands the model's reasoning data outside its intrinsic capacity, improving planning performance and generalization while reducing inference costs.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have recently shown strong potential in robotic
task planning, particularly through automatic planning domain generation that
integrates symbolic search. Prior approaches, however, have largely treated
these domains as search utilities, with limited attention to their potential as
scalable sources of reasoning data. At the same time, progress in reasoning
LLMs has been driven by chain-of-thought (CoT) supervision, whose application
in robotics remains dependent on costly, human-curated datasets. We propose
Plan2Evolve, an LLM self-evolving framework in which the base model generates
planning domains that serve as engines for producing symbolic problem-plan
pairs as reasoning traces. These pairs are then transformed into extended CoT
trajectories by the same model through natural-language explanations, thereby
explicitly aligning symbolic planning structures with natural language
reasoning. The resulting data extend beyond the model's intrinsic planning
capacity, enabling model fine-tuning that yields a planning-enhanced LLM with
improved planning success, stronger cross-task generalization, and reduced
inference costs.

</details>


### [346] [PL-VIWO2: A Lightweight, Fast and Robust Visual-Inertial-Wheel Odometry Using Points and Lines](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21563)
*Zhixin Zhang,Liang Zhao,Pawel Ladosz*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: PL-VIWO2 is a filter-based visual-inertial-wheel odometry system that fuses IMU, wheel encoder, and camera (mono/stereo) with a line-feature framework, SE(2) wheel pre-integration, and MCC for dynamic feature rejection, delivering robust, real-time long-term odometry in urban driving and outperforming state-of-the-art methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Vision-based odometry often degrades in complex outdoor urban environments due to dynamic objects, textureless regions, and drift. Integrating wheel measurements and geometric line information aims to enhance robustness, accuracy, and long-term stability for autonomous driving.

Method: PL-VIWO2 introduces three main components: (1) a line feature processing framework that exploits the geometric relationship between 2D points and lines for fast, robust line tracking and triangulation; (2) an SE(2)-constrained SE(3) wheel pre-integration that leverages the planar motion of ground vehicles for accurate wheel updates within a filter-based estimator; (3) an efficient motion consistency check (MCC) that jointly uses IMU and wheel measurements to reject dynamic features. The system supports monocular and stereo cameras.

Result: Extensive experiments on Monte Carlo simulations and public autonomous driving datasets show that PL-VIWO2 achieves higher accuracy, efficiency, and robustness than state-of-the-art methods.

Conclusion: PL-VIWO2 provides robust, real-time long-term visual-inertial-wheel odometry for autonomous driving by effectively fusing IMU, wheel, and camera data through line geometry, plane-constrained wheel pre-integration, and IMU-wheel MCC, outperforming existing methods.

Abstract: Vision-based odometry has been widely adopted in autonomous driving owing to
its low cost and lightweight setup; however, its performance often degrades in
complex outdoor urban environments. To address these challenges, we propose
PL-VIWO2, a filter-based visual-inertial-wheel odometry system that integrates
an IMU, wheel encoder, and camera (supporting both monocular and stereo) for
long-term robust state estimation. The main contributions are: (i) a novel line
feature processing framework that exploits the geometric relationship between
2D feature points and lines, enabling fast and robust line tracking and
triangulation while ensuring real-time performance; (ii) an SE(2)-constrained
SE(3) wheel pre-integration method that leverages the planar motion
characteristics of ground vehicles for accurate wheel updates; and (iii) an
efficient motion consistency check (MCC) that filters out dynamic features by
jointly using IMU and wheel measurements. Extensive experiments on Monte Carlo
simulations and public autonomous driving datasets demonstrate that PL-VIWO2
outperforms state-of-the-art methods in terms of accuracy, efficiency, and
robustness.

</details>


### [347] [Autonomous UAV-Quadruped Docking in Complex Terrains via Active Posture Alignment and Constraint-Aware Control](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.21571)
*HaoZhe Xu,Cheng Cheng,HongRui Sang,Zhipeng Wang,Qiyong He,Xiuxian Li,Bin He*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A GPS-denied UAV-quadruped docking framework using a DRL-stabilized quadruped torso and a three-phase UAV controller to achieve robust docking on challenging terrains, validated in simulation and real-world.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable autonomous docking in GPS-denied environments and heterogeneous systems. Existing work focuses on wheeled platforms; quadrapeds offer better terrain adaptability but require stable landing surfaces amidst posture variations.

Method: Quadruped: Hybrid Internal Model with Horizontal Alignment (HIM-HA), learned via deep reinforcement learning, to actively stabilize the torso and provide a level platform. UAV: three-phase strategy—(1) long-range acquisition with a median-filtered YOLOv8 detector; (2) close-range tracking with a constraint-aware controller integrating a Nonsingular Fast Terminal Sliding Mode Controller (NFTSMC) and a logarithmic Barrier Function to guarantee finite-time convergence under field-of-view (FOV) constraints; (3) terminal descent guided by a Safety Period (SP) mechanism that verifies tracking accuracy and platform stability.

Result: Validated in both simulation and real-world experiments, achieving docking on outdoor staircases higher than 17 cm and on rough slopes steeper than 30 degrees.
